PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Mr Humphreys:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to support the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. Before I proceed to speak on the Bill I would like to make a couple of comments in response to the address by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) last evening on the Bill. He attacked the economic record of the Government. I might say that he has a particularly short memory as he was a supporter of the Government that saw the greatest Budget explosion in this country's history when the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was the Treasurer. His bungling led to a deficit blowout from $1,760m to an estimated $9 1/2 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member also made a comment about the cost of computers. It is not really the responsibility of the Government to purchase computers for the pharmacists. Many of the pharmacists in my area have investigated the matter and found a far more useful machine. As the honourable member said, the Government is encouraging the pharmacists, by use of an incentive, to move into this area to facilitate the payment system. If it suits both parties I think that is a benefit all round. The honourable member forgot to mention during his address that the pharmaceutical benefits scheme now contains a safety net, which has been particularly useful.

When the Australian Labor Party Government came to office in 1983, the Commonwealth's pharmaceutical benefits scheme was just trundling along, as it had been for some time, contributing toward the cost of a wide range of drugs supplied on the prescription of doctors and dentists without much consideration to cost effectiveness. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, as its name suggests, monitored the list of drugs available on the schedule of pharmaceutical benefits for subsidy under the scheme, as it still does. This Bill makes some changes to the guidelines on which the Committee will advise the Government and it also strengthens support for the work of the Committee. The Government will be asking the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee to take factors other than therapeutic efficacy into consideration when recommending that a drug be put on the list.

A drug being on the pharmaceutical benefits schedule practically ensures its wide use. The Government is now indicating to the Committee that it should, to use the words of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys):

give consideration to alternative forms of treatment, for example, surgery, in making recommendations. The Committee will not be allowed to recommend the listing of a particular drug which is substantially more costly, unless it is satisfied that, at least for patients, the drug provides significant therapeutic advantages over alternative therapy.

Currently, nearly 600 ready prepared drugs are available on the pharmaceutical benefits list, and they come in over 1,200 forms and strengths. As well, there are nearly 2,000 manufacturer's brands which may be prescribed from the list. It is a comprehensive list of drugs which provide suitable therapy for most medical conditions. As we all know, eligible pensioners and their dependants-and at the moment there are about 2.4 million of those-can get pharmaceutical benefits free of charge. Low income earners, including unemployed beneficiaries and other pensioners who are not entitled to fringe benefits, pay a patient contribution of $2.50.

Words like `pharmaceutical benefits' sometimes do not mean much to people who are affected by changes of this sort. It is easy for us to forget that people out there deal in much more basic terms. I know that `scheduled pharmaceutical benefits' is the correct terminology, but it is more commonly known, and somewhat inaccurately, as the free list. I shall use the correct term-namely, `pharmaceutical benefits'.

I want to make clear that what we are really talking about here are medicines and the cost of prescriptions. When the measures in the Bill are translated into those simple terms I think everybody will begin to listen. We all know that the cost of medicines has risen, and that being so it is quite obvious that the cost to the Government must have risen as well. In our first two Budgets of 1983-84 and 1984-85 this Government held the price of benefits under this scheme to $2 for concessional beneficiaries and $4 for the general public. The charge for the general public rose to $5 in July 1985. Then, in the 1986 Budget, we signalled some major changes to be implemented in November of that year.

The major change was a very important innovation for families and the chronically ill, and I refer to the safety net provisions. I want to spend some little time on this because it is to important. It is a new concept in this area, and it is such a rational, humane and practical one that it deserves commendation from us all. The major problem facing governments is the need to contain costs. As the Minister said in his second reading speech:
If these changes-
that is, the November 1986 changes to which I have just referred-
had not been implemented, expenditure on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme would have reached an estimated $970m in 1987-88, an increase of 58 per cent in the two years since 1985-86.

Responsible governments are always faced with cost-service dilemmas. We cannot ignore the cost of programs. But this Government is not in the business of harming those who are the most vulnerable in our society, namely, the ill and the infirm. It was necessary to come up with a way of protecting those needing constant medication from the cost burden of expensive drugs.

Thus, the `safety net' system was devised. For both the general public and people who have concession cards, after a patient has used 25 pharmaceutical benefit scheme prescriptions in one calendar year any further prescriptions on the scheme will be provided absolutely free of charge. However, this does not happen by magic: after an individual or a family has been supplied with 25 pharmaceutical benefit scheme prescriptions in a calendar year, that person or family becomes eligible for the issue of a pharmaceutical benefit entitlement card, and after that, of course, any further prescriptions will be free. In other words, we have provided protection for the chronically ill by placing a ceiling on the amount that an individual or family will have to pay for pharmaceutical benefits from January to December each year. In fact, on average, the ceiling-that is, the full quota of 25 pharmaceutical benefit scheme prescriptions registered with a pharmacist for an individual or a family-should cost the patient about $185.

At the same time, the Government has entered into a pricing agreement with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia which has ensured that a wide range of essential medication will continue to be available to the general public at sensible and affordable prices. Certainly, the rest of us will be sharing some financial cost because the charge for us was increased at the same time as the safety net provisions came into being. A maximum of $10-I say `maximum', because many drugs will be available for less than that-has been introduced for those of us who are not recognised as low income earners. I have no intention of being defensive about this extra cost to people like us. I contend that it is entirely appropriate that those of us who enjoy good health and good incomes should help to subsidise the costs of those who are less fortunate. The safety net is not a burden on those who are healthy, although it is available to all of us should we need it. Hopefully, most of us will not, but we should not complain about its provision for people who have enough to worry about in coping with their illnesses without having the extra burden of financial stress over the costs of their medication. I understand that around 92 per cent of general users of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme use only 10 prescriptions or less per annum. So the pharmaceutical benefits scheme prescription limit of 25 really does benefit those who suffer from illnesses requiring a lot of medication, as well as families with children, particularly young children with chronic illnesses such as asthma.

The Government was concerned about increasing costs in this area but, instead of bulldozing changes through, the then Minister for Health, the present Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), did what no government had done before: he consulted the professional group which would be most affected-the pharmacists. The safety net scheme is, in fact, very similar to a proposal put to the Government by the Pharmacy Guild. Pharmacists are the ones who act as the Government's agents for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. They dispense the medication on supply of a doctor's prescription. The Government has come to an arrangement with pharmacists-it is a little too complicated to go into here-and that is a very pleasing result.

In this Bill there are provisions to encourage pharmacists to use modern technology in their claims under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The Government is providing a very real incentive for pharmacists. Those who choose to forward their claims using compatible computer equipment, either on floppy disks or by using a modem, will be financially rewarded. The Government is prepared to pay a cash incentive of 2.5c per pharmaceutical benefit. The return to the Government will be in the form of increased efficiency. Faster and more accurate processing will be a boon all round. Here is another example of this Government moving effectively following extensive investigations. The Minister has told us that this incentive arose from an efficiency scrutiny of the payment of pharmaceutical benefits. There is no doubt that the proposals will help in containing costs for the Government. To return to the Bill before us, I will quote from the Minister's second reading speech where he refers to the role to be played by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee in also helping to contain costs. I imagine that Opposition members would be rather pleased about the containment of costs. It is usually their only consideration. The Minister said:

The Government has no objection to paying high prices for new drugs that offer significant therapeutic advances over existing drugs or other forms of treatment. But it does not believe the taxpayer should foot the bill for very expensive drugs that offer only minimal advantages over much cheaper alternatives.

This Government has actually taken a good hard look at the way the system works for providing subsidised pharmaceutical products to ensure that the price of a wide range of medication remains within the reach of those who need it. We have examined delivery of services to the Australian community, and we have looked at the delivery of services to pensioners and low income earners. We have come up with sensible solutions to the problem of containing costs, while improving the level of service to those most in need.

I want to congratulate the Government on introducing all these changes and, in particular, I commend the Minister responsible-the Minister for Community Services and Health-for initiating many of them. As the Minister for Health, he has presided over some of the most fundamental changes in health care seen in this country. Medicare, the Government's universal health care scheme, is so successful that it has passed into the very fabric of the whole area of health. Some radical right-wingers on the other side of the House like to boast that they will enjoy destroying Medicare if they ever get a go at government. Not only do I not believe that they will get that chance, but I do not believe that the Australian community will allow them to touch Medicare. Ordinary Australian men and women know and value the Medicare system. Many health professionals support the Medicare system. It is the best system we have ever seen in this country. But it is not a static system. If changes need to be made-and just recently we saw some adjustment to schedule fees-this Government is always prepared to negotiate and consult to iron out problems or to make improvements.

To return to the other matter in hand, I can give another example of this process at work in the area of provision of pharmaceutical benefits. I was particularly pleased, on behalf of many of my constituents, to see a partial reversal of the decision to take some over the counter items off the schedule of pharmaceutical benefits last year. In the main, the drugs removed were mild analgesics. The cost to Government of a prescription for one of these drugs which, of course, can be bought for a couple of dollars in supermarkets, plus the cost of subsidising a visit to the doctor to have the prescription made out in the first place, meant that excessive costs were being incurred by the Government for drugs which in many cases could be seen as of questionable value. Nonetheless, some people were quite seriously affected by this decision. When the Government realised that, the Minister announced an adjustment to allow some of these medications to again be available through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

I note that this Bill contains proposals to give the Minister the power to act quickly to remove an item from the schedule of pharmaceutical benefits. I am sure that this will prove to be a valuable tool, given the rate of new developments in the pharmacological field. It is also important to note that the Parliament will be able to scrutinise any decisions which are made under this new provision, because a declaration to remove an item from the list must be tabled in the Parliament.

Accountability of this sort, particularly when the decision making process lies directly with the Minister, is fundamental to the proper working of our democratic style of government. I recall an occasion when the present Minister for Community Services and Health, not long after introducing the November 1986 changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, was called to account, as it were. I had the opportunity to welcome him to my electorate of Ballarat. I asked whether he would be happy to meet some of my local pharmacists, and he readily agreed. I was very grateful for his courtesy, as were the pharmacists. In fact, the meeting took place over breakfast. It was generally conceded to be very successful. The pharmacists were able to approach a very approachable Minister and I am pleased to say that the Minister took the opportunity to listen to many of the points which the pharmacists felt were important to them.

That breakfast brings me back to the point of this Bill. Ballarat pharmacists pointed out that there were problems with the flow of payments from the Government to individual pharmacists. This Bill, as we know, proposes a number of improvements to the method of payment and it also includes incentives for pharmacists to use computer systems compatible with those of the central claims processing facility. There have been problems in this area. I am particularly pleased to be able to support the Minister in his efforts to sort out these problems. I also take this opportunity to invite him to visit Ballarat or, indeed, Ararat-I hope that he will take up the invitation-another important part of my electorate, to do the same as his predecessor and visit that beautiful and historic part of Victoria to meet pharmacists. Of course, since he wears another hat, that of Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I am sure that we can incorporate some contact with the veteran community as well. I know that the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), who knows some members of my veteran community, will concur that they would be very happy to meet him.

In conclusion, I reiterate that the provisions in this Bill have important consequences for health care in this country. The pharmaceutical benefits scheme has been particularly successful in meeting the needs of the targeted population. The amendments contained in this Bill should ensure not only the continuation of the Government's efforts in this area, but also that the cost effectiveness of the scheme is in accordance with the Government's economic responsibilities. Therefore, I support the Bill and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, at the outset I say that I am delighted to see that you are occupying the chair at the moment. I know that the reason that you are looking so happy is the knowledge that the President of the Senate, once again, has to carry certain additional burdens associated with his office this year, as he did last year. I am sure that that is a very welcome fact.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 relates to and arises from the Budget. It is an important piece of legislation which the Opposition does not oppose, but to which we will move amendments in the committee stage. I will comment briefly on the comments by the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) in relation to Medicare now being part of the fabric of this nation. It may well be, at this time; but I have to add that it is a very expensive part of the fabric of this nation. It is a very large component of Federal Budget outlays and the section of the Federal Budget being spent on Medicare is escalating almost out of control. One of the reasons why this related measure is before the Parliament today is to try to wind back some of the explosive growth which has taken place in one area related to Medicare, namely, pharmaceutical benefits. I am delighted that students from Albury High School happen to be in the gallery today.

Some interesting comparisons ought to be made in relation to what this country is spending on drugs and what the Federal Government is spending on drugs for its people, pursuant to various programs. The best comparison I can make is as follows: let us take as an example the country of Nepal, located between India, Tibet and China. The population of Nepal is 16 million. The population of Australia is 16 million. The total annual Budget of the Government of Nepal is just a fraction under $A1 billion. The expenditure of the Australian Federal Government on drugs for its people, pursuant to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme, is $A1 billion. So, the Australian Federal Government is spending on drugs for its people the same amount as the Government of Nepal is spending in its annual Budget. I thank the dedicated staff of the Embassy of Nepal for making available to me this information relating to the most recent Budget in that country, presented on 9 July.

This matter becomes more serious when we realise the rate of growth in expenditure by the Federal Government on drugs, pursuant to all programs for its people. In 1986-87, the total figure was $864,574,000. This financial year, even allowing for the wind back measures, the Federal Budget will provide for an expenditure of $994,484,000, or just a fraction under $1 billion. So, there has been an increase of 15 per cent in Federal Government expenditure on drugs for the Australian people, quite apart from the commitment required from taxpayers. I am not for one moment reflecting on the need for safety nets to be created for people in need, particularly for the quite separate category of veterans' affairs, ex-service personnel and disabled veterans. Nevertheless, it begs the question: has this nation turned into a nation of neurotic, subsidised pill takers?

I make an appeal at this point: every time people feel the urge to take yet another round of drugs relating to their perceived or actual condition, in the interests of the nation and the national Budget and in the light of the very serious economic situation at the moment, they might try to hold off for 24 hours and stare down the problem that might be affecting them to see whether their own will power and psychological approach might enable them to avoid taking those drugs. Of course, as doctors tell us, drugs are not without their side effects and onward ramifications and do not always bring about improvement.

Having said that, I am not running rough-shod over the need for Federal governments to accept a proper and responsible role in this area. I acknowledge that many Australians are unlucky enough to be reliant on taking pills and drugs of one kind or another throughout their lives. However, I wonder about whether this reliance is often self-generated and is necessarily essential or even in veterans' interests, but it is not for me as a lay person to make that judgment. It is incredible that this nation is reaching its 200th year, its Bicentennial, and the Australian Federal Government is about to cross the threshold and spend $1 billion on drugs for its people by way of subsidies. Of course, the total expenditure on drugs by Australians is very much more than that, the reason being that not everyone qualifies for, or is in receipt of, the various subsidies and programs under both the national health pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the quite separate and totally justifiable repatriation Bicentennial benefits scheme.
The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), in his second reading speech on this Bill, said:

The Government has no objection to paying high prices for new drugs that offer significant therapeutic advances over existing drugs or other forms of treatment. But it does not believe that the taxpayers should foot the bill for very expensive drugs that offer only minimal advantages over much cheaper alternatives.

I agree with that. There has to be an element of performance related to the expenditure on high cost, state of the art technology drugs. It is also a very difficult area because, when new drugs come in, often we are met with massive resistance from veterans and others who do not want to change from the drugs they have been using to the new drugs even though it may have reached the stage where the old drugs are no longer helping those veterans. Nevertheless, that effort must be made. I believe the Government has a right to monitor very closely the nature of drugs being distributed and the nature of the drugs it is subsidising in this country to the tune of $1 billion.

Also embraced in this particular measure is a new approach to provide some incentives for the pharmacists to overcome the mass of red tape that they face in dealing with the Federal Government to obtain the refunds and payments for which they are eligible. The red tape often leads to huge delays and threatens the viability of so many small businesses throughout my electorate and throughout Australia. Embraced in this measure are a number of new initiatives which seek to overcome these delays and to simplify the system.

One initiative I wish to highlight in this legislation-the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) also highlighted it in his speech-is the payment of pharmacists on the basis of a random sample of prescriptions submitted in each claim. This is breaking new ground, but the Government is not asking for actual accounts to be totalled or for actual amounts to be arrived at. It is merely taking a sample of the accounts and saying, `This is running at approximately this ratio and, therefore, we will pay taxpayers' money out to the pharmacists in question, based on that random sample'. I think Auditor-Generals of yesteryear would turn in their graves if they knew random sampling was being utilised for the payment of government moneys to, in this case, pharmacists. I say to the House, and to the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) who has taken a very close interest in this legislation, that this Government, this Parliament and the Joint Committee of Public Accounts need to monitor this initiative very closely to see that this provision does not lead to rorts, to see that it does not lead to a massive blow-out in expenditure, and to see why there has been the need to introduce, for the first time as I understand it, random sampling of submitted claims. The Government is exposing itself to the veteran community. The totally and permanently incapacitated pensioner, I am sure, would like the Government to take a random sample to establish his claims for a special rate of pension. This approach, this aspect of the legislation, removes specific accuracy from the submission of claims for refund by pharmacists.

I put it to the House what whilst there is precedent for this action-I understand that even Qantas Airways Ltd in its balancing operation each month with other international airlines now operates on random sampling in exchanging coupon values-the Government's adoption of this measure does require very careful scrutiny to ensure that it does not lead to the introduction of rorts and to an absolute blowout in costs. As the honourable member for Richmond suggests, it makes us wonder why the administration has reached the stage that we have to move to a random sampling method to arrive at what should be paid to the pharmacists. I know it is only one of the alternatives embraced by the proposals in this legislation, but it is an important one and it is for that reason that I highlight it for the House.

To put this area of pharmaceutical benefits into perspective, the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme has been the subject of a number of changes, as well as the national health pharmaceutical benefits scheme. This Government-not under the present Minister for Veterans' Affairs, but his predecessor-chose to eliminate completely war widows from eligibility for the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I know that would have been of concern to you, Madam Speaker, as it was to many people around Australia and to war widows in particular. It also chose to cut back on certain other categories of eligibility to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme and a number of drugs available under the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme have now been deleted from the list. Frankly, I supported the deletion of some because those changes reflected developments in the state of the art technology available and the types of drugs available to veterans, to ex-service personnel and indeed to the nation. The deletion of others may have been seen in a different light, and it has caused considerable concern and hardship to many war widows and ex-service personnel, and, of course, as Ben Chifley put it, this nation, this Parliament, has a responsibility to see that the right thing is done by ex-service personnel.

I take this opportunity to say to the House, while the Minister for Veterans' Affairs is pre-sent, that in dealing with this measure we should not lose sight of the fact that it involves also the equally sensitive repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme, and it has a vital role to play in the well-being of our veterans, our ex-service personnel and our war widows. The Government needs to act very carefully in relation to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme, quite apart from the changes it is implementing by virtue of this legislation in respect of the national health pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

I am delighted that a group from the Albury High School has been present in the chamber for this morning's session thus far because I know that they also would share a deep interest in the proceedings of the Parliament, which they are lucky enough to see on this occasion. In conclusion, I just reiterate to the House my concern that this nation is not only turning into a nation of narcotic takers, a nation of people who take illicit drugs, but also it is turning into a nation of neurotic, subsidised pill-takers. That is reflected by the fact that the Federal Government is spending this financial year $1 billion on drugs for its people. We ought to reflect on that because it does not necessarily show the healthiest direction for this nation to proceed along so far as the health of its people are concerned, quite apart from the economic situation obtaining at this time. I do not oppose the passage of this Bill. I join with the honourable member for O'Connor in supporting the amendments he will be bringing forward in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, by way of introduction I will make a couple of comments on remarks made by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). He was concerned about the cost of pharmaceuticals and their supply. I would have to agree with him. He was concerned with overall health costs. I share that concern too. However, I think that a few points should be made to put the matter in perspective. The cost of pharmaceuticals and health products in our community as a percentage of the total health bill has declined substantially. The cost of health itself has dropped as a percentage of our gross domestic product (GDP), and has stabilised under Medicare, compared with health costs under the Fraser Government. Whereas in Australia health costs as a percentage of GDP are in the region of 8 per cent, in the United States of America, with its freer and more privatised market, it is nearer 12 1/2 per cent to 13 per cent. I think that we should use those figures to put the matter in perspective when talking about accelerating costs.

SPEECH.PARA: During the election campaign last July, Medicare was a significant issue. The people came out strongly in favour of the Government's proposal for maintaining Medicare and our pharmaceutical benefits scheme. That was a point made quite forcefully by the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) this morning, and I agree with him that Medicare and the pharmaceutical benefits scheme have become part of the fabric of our health system which is supported by the people.

I have to agree with the honourable member for Farrer that the average citizen is relying too much on the quick fix for either imagined or actual ills. Perhaps people are reaching for Aldous Huxley's Brave New World solution of soma as a quick fix. I was talking with the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) just before this debate and we discussed the very problem raised by the honourable member for Farrer. We thought it might be a good idea if consideration were given by the Government and by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee to including on the pharmaceutical listing several placebos-the sugar-coated, lactose pills which are inert in their reaction on the body but which have a physiological effect-and perhaps in that way bringing about the desired improvement in the health of the individual.

I return to the subject of the National Health Amendment Bill. I think that some very important changes associated with the pharmaceutical benefits system are included in the Bill. There has been much public debate recently about many aspects of the scheme such as changes in charges to patients. The honourable member for Ballarat dwelt for some time on some of the significant changes to charges that were brought in in the Budget last year. There has been debate about items on the list and I will return to that later. There has been debate also on how and when drugs should be delisted and the total cost of the scheme, including also payments made to the dispensers of our pharmacy products. The Bill touches on most of these changes. The Government is continuing its constant efforts to keep costs down and under control and to ensure that the taxpayers get value for their health dollar. It is ensuring that there is improved efficiency generally within the pharmaceutical dispensing industry, if I can call it that.

We are facing significant costs. Last financial year the cost of drugs for pensioners alone, which averaged $8 a prescription, increased by 24 per cent on the previous year's cost. If the changes in the last Budget had not been introduced and accepted by Parliament, this financial year we would face costs for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme of almost $1 billion-$970m. That would represent a significant rise of some 58 per cent over the last two years. Such cost escalation cannot go on. Certainly, such growth is not matched by our population increase or even in the growth in our age pensioner population. The cost of the drugs themselves and the cost of their delivery is increasing. The Government faces many different options in reducing costs. It can reduce the number of drugs available on the pharmaceutical list; it can drop unnecessary drugs from the list; it can clamp down on prices either of the drugs or the dispensing fees, or it can cut into administration costs.

Any outcome is a compromise between making sure that all essential drugs are available to the public, ensuring that cheaper pharmaceutically equivalent substitutes are listed ahead of dearer drugs, and straight cost-cutting. In this setting, the Government has introduced changes to the charter of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. In the past, the Committee has not been required, in its statutory charter, to take costs into account when making its recommendations. In practice, it has taken price into account when considering drugs of similar efficacy and toxicity, but that has been only a secondary consideration. The obligation to consider comparative effectiveness and cost will require the Committee to give consideration to alternative forms of therapy, of treatment, in making its recommendations.

Under this Bill, the Committee will not be allowed to recommend listing of a particular drug which is substantially more costly, unless it is satisfied that, at least for some patients, the drug provides significant therapeutic advantages over alternative therapy. We have had moves by drug companies which wish to establish new patents to introduce to the market slight molecular changes to pharmaceutical compounds of drugs, which have had minimal improvement in their therapeutic effect. The job of the Government is to make sure that it is not caught up in the patents argument and into the argument about profits of the industry, but to concentrate upon providing, at the cheapest cost to the public, the most therapeutically desirable drugs.

The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has said that the Government has no objection to paying high prices for new drugs that offer significant therapeutic advances over existing drugs or other forms of treatment, but he does not believe that the taxpayer should foot the bill for very expensive drugs that offer only minimal advantages over much cheaper alternatives. We have some real problems there because it is very hard to measure what is meant by `significant'. It will be one of the jobs of the Advisory Committee to work that out. The Minister has quite properly enlarged the size of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee to include more expertise. There will be three more doctors with expertise for specialist evaluation of the particular drugs that come on to the market. In addition, he has bolstered its work by the establishment of sub-committees, membership of which is not limited to members of the Advisory Committee. The Committee can draw on outside advice and expertise to work on what is `significant', what differentiates a new drug from an old drug and so on.

I believe that there may have to be some examination of a system which takes account of the fact that some patients, there might be very few, do not have a similar therapeutic reaction with a substitute drug. This happens because individuals are individual in their reactions to drugs as well. They are all idiosyncratic. I would not like to see a position where individuals, and I am talking about a small number of people, have to pay privately for drugs because the dearer substitute, although not `significantly' therapeutically different in general terms, is denied to them on the list. That is a difficult question, and I do not envy the work of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. But I would not like to see those few individuals who, because of some allergic reaction or sensitivity, are not able to take the drugs that satisfy, for both cost and therapeutic efficacy reasons, the general population, being denied their drugs on the list.

In addition, this Bill deals with the Minister's power to remove an item from the list of pharmaceutical benefits for any reason. The proposed amendment will enable the Minister to act quickly when circumstances change. For example, a cheaper alternative, a substitute or a generic may come on to the market. This amendment will encourage generic production in this country. I remind the House that the Government is conscious, as the Advisory Committee will be, that it has to be a therapeutically equivalent generic to be an acceptable substitute for the patented drug or the drug which is out of patent. It will also encourage drug manufacturers to operate under licence, if possible, in this country, to bring about cheaper production of a patented drug. All of this will lower pressures on costs.

A year or so ago there was some debate in this House over many months about the dropping from the list of some mild analgesics and some antihistamine preparations. The then member for Petrie, Mr Hodges, who, like me, is a pharmacist, made quite a point about this. I think some of his criticism had merit, but the rest of it was political posturing. Of course, it goes with being in opposition that one must over-exaggerate, that one must be hyperbolic in one's rhetoric to try to make a point. But the fact is that following legal advice to the Minister and to the Government it was found that the only way that drugs could be put on or off the list was through the recommendation of the Advisory Committee. It was interpreted by our legal eagles that as a drug could not be put on the list without the advice of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee it followed that one would not be removed either. The Government accepted that advice and in fact did not contravene it.

The then Minister for Health, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), did not unilaterally or on his own initiative remove those drugs. He asked the Advisory Committee to review unnecessary drugs on the list and the recommendation came back that several of them should be removed. I was critical of that recommendation. My colleagues in the pharmaceutical industry approached me and said that they feared that doctors would be tempted to prescribe less appropriate and more expensive drugs which were on the list in order to save pensioners, in particular, money. Even though those drugs are available to pensioners relatively cheaply, it is not easy for these people to pay for them. That is exactly what happened. The Minister quite rightly asked the Advisory Committee to review its decision again. The Advisory Committee came back and said that certain of the milder analgesics and some of the antihistamines should be returned. Proper processes were adhered to. I have no criticism of the Minister. I have no criticism of the former member for Petrie for raising his concern. My only criticism was the way he went about it but I will not dwell on this matter because he is not here to defend himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll defend him.

—I thought the honourable member might do that. Another criticism is that there is no consumer representative on the Advisory Committee, that there should be someone to represent the pensioners and the patients who take pharmaceuticals for their health. The Minister has said that, if he should remove any drugs from the list, he will have to give the names of the drugs and the reasons why and place that before each House of this Parliament. His decisions will be subject to consideration by the Houses and possible disallowance. In other words, the opportunity is now there for the representatives of the people to become an indirect de facto consumer representative of the Advisory Committee. I commend the Minister and the Government for doing this. We can see that this is going to take the political opportunism out of the debate on what is being listed. It is quite proper that what is on the pharmaceutical listing should be at arm's length from government. Governments should argue and debate the costing, but a medical consideration of what should be available should be left to the experts so that what is listed remains at arm's length from government.

SPEECH.PARA: Should the Minister, for many reasons which are desirable, decide to delist an item, he must do two things. First of all, he must have due regard to the recommendation, consideration, opinion and reports of the Advisory Committee. He will not be making decisions lightly or in a vexatious manner. At the same time, he has to table his decision in the Parliament, leaving it to further scrutiny by, shall I call it, the `patients' representative'-this Parliament.

I now want to turn to a matter which has for some time disturbed my professional colleagues, not only during the period of this Government but as far back as I can remember. Although I have been in pharmacy for some 30 years I have not been active in the last nine or 10 years because of other duties. In fact, I sold my pharmacy to my partner for the very good reason-one which the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) would agree with-that one must be a full time member of parliament, that one should not have another professional occupation at the same time. One cannot divide one's attentions and one's responsibilities equitably and professionally. So I sold my share to my partner so that I could devote my time entirely to my parliamentary duties. But I declare an indirect interest before honourable members today.

My pharmacy colleagues have been very concerned about the delays in payment. I believe the Government has taken two good steps to ensure that there is more rapid payment to overcome the delays of the past in paying pharmacists for the pharmaceutical products they have supplied under the scheme. The Government has chosen two very interesting ways of doing this. First, it has decided to encourage pharmacists to use computers to assist in the processing of their payments. Many pharmacists have installed computers for very good business reasons: it has made them more efficient; it has taken the tedium out of some of their activities such as repetitive typing, et cetera; it has improved their medical records system in their pharmacy and so on. Many computers had been installed before the encouragement to speed up payments came about. When the Government introduced the 2.5c per prescription incentive to increase the number of computers in the claim process, the proportion of pharmacists using computers for claims processing jumped sharply from 11 per cent participation in February to 37 per cent seven months later. I would not be surprised-the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) said this-if the figure is now up nearer the 50 per cent or 60 per cent mark.

When I was speaking to a pharmacist recently he said he had put in some expensive computer equipment just a couple of years ago. I reminded him that with the generous taxation write-off it had probably been paid for. He agreed with that but he said that he could not replace or upgrade it to participate in the new scheme. I pointed out to him that the 2.5c per prescription incentive was not to help him replace his equipment or to give him a capital advantage but merely to encourage people to participate and to forward their claims in computer readable form. But he will be able to participate in an incentive scheme to speed up his claims by going in for the sampling method. There was a lot of criticism from a couple of speakers in this Parliament about the sampling method. I point out that those who are not familiar with the pharmaceutical benefits scheme would not realise that 70 per cent of items dispensed are dominated by 12 to 20 drugs and they cluster around a certain price. In fact, I brought along a table which I want incorporated in Hansard. I showed it to the honourable member for Farrer earlier in the debate. The table is taken from the draft Industries Assistance Commission report on pharmaceutical products of 1985. It comes from page 2.13 of the report and is table 2.9. It shows the distribution of PBS prescriptions by dispensed price. I seek leave to have the table incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

Table 2.9 gives the distribution of PBS prescriptions by price range as at September 1984. The table shows a concentration of PBS prescriptions in the $3 to $6 price range. Drugs costing more than $6 account for less than one-third of total sales for each group of beneficiaries, and drugs costing more than $10 account for less than 7 per cent of total sales in all categories (and less than 5 per cent in the pensioner category).

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The salient feature of that table is the very thick clustering within a small band of prices of the majority of prescription costs in the general, concessional and pensioner categories. If one studied statistics, permutations, computations and the laws of chance one would realise that under this sampling method, there is a nine in 10 chance of a pharmacist being overpaid when the incentive payment is included but I would say that without that payment the costing would be almost spot on. There would be only a one in 1,000 chance of a pharmacist being underpaid by more than 50c in $100. No wonder pharmacists and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia have accepted this scheme as a fair and proper method of payment. There will be big savings-this is where the Opposition should be pleased-in the assessment costs that go with assessing each prescription individually by person. It is not a matter of poor administration; it is a matter of costing. These are progressive and desirable changes. The effects should be closely monitored so that if necessary fine tuning can take place. I am confident they will keep costs of the scheme within limits and expedite payments to pharmacists for professional supply of their services. I commend the Bill to the House.
-Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) for his generosity, as quali-fied as it was, in recognising that the former member for Petrie, who is also a pharmacist, was spot on in his criticisms of the former Minister for Health, the present Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), for deleting 45 or 46 items from the pharmaceutical benefits list. On another note, I take issue with another comment of the honourable member for Streeton and indeed with the comments of the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren). Both those Australian Labor Party members said that the election result of 11 July was an indication of the great support that the people of Australia have given the Australian Labor Party.
—A good win.

—The honourable member says that it was a good win but the realities are that the Liberal and National parties received 20,000 more first preference votes than did the Australian Labor Party and even after the distribution of preferences the Labor Party received only 50.3 per cent of the total vote.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I think relevance should be adhered to, Mr Deputy Speaker--
—They are very sensitive about this, Mr Deputy Speaker-this gerrymander business.

—Order! The honourable member for Moreton will resume his seat. The Minister raised a point of order on relevance. The honourable member for Moreton said that the honourable member for Ballarat had made some comments when I was not in the chamber. I draw the attention of the honourable member for Moreton to the fact that there might not be much causal relationship between the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) and figures on the last election. He might continue speaking on what is before the House.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, with one more sentence I can conclude my reference to that subject. Government members are deluded by the fact that 50.3 per cent of the vote has given them more than 58 per cent of the membership of this Parliament. That is why I have been saying that there is something radically wrong with the redistribution; I will leave it at that. I turn to the Bill. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) said in his second reading speech that in the last two years there had been an increase of 58 per cent in the cost of supplying medicines. I want to refer to the fact that the Government has also slugged the people. It is not that the increased cost of medicine has been borne by the Government. When the Labor Government came to power people who bought medicine under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme paid $4 a script. The Government increased that shortly after coming to office to $5 a script. But then it introduced a system under which people did not qualify for free prescriptions until they had paid for 25 scripts. Therefore, when people were up for $5 previously, which was an increase on the level that the previous Government was charging, the Government brought in a system under which it was ripping anything from $7 to $10 a scrip out of the pockets of ordinary people. Honourable members opposite acknowledge that and I appreciate that. They should not make out that it is a great Santa Clause Labor Government, because it has had its hands into the pockets of the people ever since it came to power. The whole health system is crumbling by virtue of the weight of the cost. The Government has been putting more and more and more back on to the shoulders of the people; so it should not parade itself as being a generous government.
—What would you do?

—I assure the honourable member that a Liberal philosophy would not be leading to a second rate health system. Some of the measures that are contained in this Bill are measures of desperation. The Minister, in his second reading speech, referred to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC), which decides which drugs will or will not be available under the scheme. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The obligation to consider comparative effectiveness and cost will require the PBAC to give consideration to alternative forms of treatment, for example, surgery . . .

Never in the history of this country has the PBAC-which I think will now comprise a group of 10 doctors and one pharmacist-been required to sit in judgment in the nation's capital to decide whether the people in the far-flung regions of this country would be better served by having an operation than by being given a drug. Surely decisions involving surgery are best left in the hands of the individual's local doctor. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who is at the table may well have a problem; part of his body may not be working as well as it used to, and how would he like this Committee to decide whether it is out or it is off. I would say that that is a decision for his doctor to make. Whether treatment by drugs would restore him to his former position of activity of health is for the Minister and his doctor to decide. It is not appropriate for a committee to be given powers to enable it to start suddenly deciding whether surgery is better than the continuation of medication. These are some of the steps that the Government is taking as a way of trying to curtail the escalating costs of health care in this country.

The next point that I wish to make is an extremely serious one. Last year we saw the charade when the Minister for Community Services and Health-a doctor of philosophy, not of medicine-virtually said to the PBAC, `Righto, the pensioners are getting into these drugs; you had better take those drugs off the list', and 45 or 46 analgesics and the like were removed from the pharmaceutical health benefits list. As the honourable member for Streeton generously conceded, the former member for Petrie who used to sit just behind me here, chased the Minister to find out what had gone on. As a result of severe speeches that had been made by the former member for Petrie the Minister came out and told this place during Question Time that is was all the recommendation of the PBAC. We were later to find that it was a recommendation of the Minister that was given to the PBAC, and four of the seven members voted for the Minister's wish to be endorsed. At that time the then member for Petrie said that it would cause doctors to start prescribing more expensive drugs-and that is exactly what happened. Then, in August this year the new Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) made a big man of himself by announcing to the world-on 7 August-in a news release:
Free analgesics for pensioners.

Pensioners will again be able to receive mild analgesics-aspirin and paracetamol-without charge. Veterans' Affairs Minister Ben Humphreys, who has responsibility for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, said today that these products would be available by prescription free of charge for all pensioners as from 1 October 1987.
And it goes on. But I scribbled across the Minister's Press release at the time-a copy of which I had faxed down to me this morning-the following comments:
Heaven help us if the PBAC couldn't have foreseen this-Government putting on screws-costing them more money.

The Minister relented only because he found that all the predictions were right-and why were those predictions born? They were born as the result of Government interference. Government members sought to interfere to save money. They interfered with the scheme, but it cost millions more as people sought alternatives. The point that I am trying to make is that this legislation is building in permanent interference. The Minister will now have the right to decide which drugs will be available. We are spending up to half a million dollars to expand and to better equip the Committee and yet, at the same time, the Government is formalising interference mechanisms. I look at the Minister for Veterans' Affairs who is at the table-a nice guy, but heaven help us if he is to be the one who makes decisions on subjects like this. I have a lot of respect for him-but a former service station operator deciding which drugs will be good for the populace of this country? That is exactly what is proposed. I believe that it is very bad legislation which starts to transfer decisions such as this into the political field.

The honourable member for Streeton referred to how democratic the legislation is because if the Minister interferes he will have to table his decision in the House of Representatives and in the Senate and there is provision for disallowance. So that was cited as democracy at work, and I think the honourable member for Streeton talked about where better could this matter be than in the hands of the members of parliament who represent the people. The honourable member indulged in fine words like that. But, quite frankly, with all the respect that I have for this institution and for those people who comprise the membership of his chamber and the Senate, when I look around at fellow members I am fearful about the proposal that we decide on the availability of drugs. What specialisation do we possess? If the Minister at the table is aware of the contents of the legislation he will know that even the recommendations of the PBAC are not to be made available to the Parliament. The Minister will go through the charade and the act of referring his decision to the PBAC and will take the view of the Committee into account, but if he does not like what it recommends he can ride roughshod over it and say, `No. I am taking this drug off the free list'-or the so-called free list, as there is very little left that is free these days. I plead with the Minister at the table to reconsider this matter. If in future we are going to have politicians deciding whether to allow or disallow the ministerial discretion that the Minister is granting himself-and heaven help us if we make as big a mess of medicine collectively as the Government has made of the economy-at least Parliament should be informed of the professional views of the PBAC. Will the Minister look up, please; he has his head down and is writing-I do not think he wants to hear this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am listening.

—He says he is listening-well, I believe that, but I want him to take this point on board, because I believe that it is a vital point, an important point, as there is a lack of competence in this place in terms of being able to make judgments of the kind that are being thrust upon us. I again pay a tribute to the former member for Petrie for his relentless pursuit of Dr Blewett and the matter of all those drugs being taken off the PSB. Some 45 or 46 drugs were removed, but they are now back on the list. They should never have been removed in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last few minutes available to me, I refer to the Government's intentions in relation to the new Pharmpay system, which reimburses pharmacists for prescriptions dispensed. We have been told that on average a pharmacist probably submits some 2,000 claims per month and is reimbursed an amount of some $14,000 to $15,000. Historically, and it is not the fault of the present Government, pharmacists have suffered in terms of reimbursement of outlays. The shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), told the Parliament last night that payments were being delayed for up to 102 days and, correctly, that that was not fair. I commend the Government for trying to establish a fairer system. This idea of paying 21/2c per prescription, in some instances, might be seen as generous, but the realities are that across Australia, I believe in every capital city, people were employed in the Department of Community Services and Health and their job, from sun up until dark, was to punch into computers the details of prescriptions that were forwarded from the pharmacies. Across Australia that would have amounted to millions per month. That system was costing the Government heaps.

There was also the problem of repetition strain injury. Someone who sits in front of a computer from sun up until dark punching in the details of those scripts is probably a prime candidate for such a condition. The Government has largely taken away the function from the government sector and has gained the co-operation of the pharmacists, who will prepare computer floppy disks, which they will send to the Department, use the 10 per cent system or stick to the old system. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who is at the table, nods his head in agreement; pharmacists can choose to stick to the old system, or they can opt for the new system. Under one new system, they choose the top 10 per cent in terms of value of the scripts and send them to the Department; the Department exercises its discretion in picking out, at random, about another 10 per cent and pays the remaining 90 per cent in accordance with the level that is established on that random sample. I believe the Opposition wishes to insert a sunset clause in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you read the amendment?

—Yes, I have, but sometimes one has to check to make sure that things are as they were yesterday. We seek to insert a sunset clause to ensure that, on 30 June 1989, the procedure is re-examined. What the Opposition is saying is that if the Government is going to use the Russian roulette system, it is crazy to legislate that it will never be reviewed. With all the goodwill in the world, in six months time the Government might be screaming about the fact that the system is working the chemists' way or the pharmacists might be screaming that they are not getting back what they are entitled to. In introducing an amendment to insert a sunset clause, all we are saying to the Government is that, as at 30 June 1989, we would like the mechanism to exist whereby the Government would be forced to review the system. I do not believe that that is an unreasonable request. Perhaps it can even be met by the Minister outlining some alternative that the Government might have in mind, our having drawn the weaknesses of the Russian roulette system to the Government's attention.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier in my speech, I believe that it is totally outlandish and ridiculous that the Government, for the first time in history, has given the Minister the powers to decide which drugs will be available to the people. I have referred to the very generous abilities of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who is at the table. The Lord smiled upon him when He created him. But who is he to decide what is good for people when there is a body of 10 doctors and a pharmacist to decide? For the Minister to say in his second reading speech `the proposed amendment will enable the Minister to act quickly when circumstances change' indicates that he thinks we are devoid of intelligence. Nothing is that urgent that the alternative of convening a meeting of the specialist group to make a decision could not be used. Nothing is so urgent that the Minister has to move in and decide himself.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to a couple of comments made by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron). First of all, I thought that he made a very ungracious remark about the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys). He seems to feel that the Minister's background as a service station proprietor somehow did not befit him for his high office.
—I did not say that.

—He seemed to imply that. I inform the honourable member for Moreton that not only has this Minister a small business background of which this Government is particularly proud but also many honourable members on the Government benches have a small business background and we feel that they make a very important and valuable contribution to the Government. The Minister is well fitted and suited to exercising his responsibilities in this area. The honourable member commented on the incentive or, should I say, incentivation of paying 2.5c per prescription perhaps being seen as generous. If he had listened to his shadow Minister, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), he would have heard his shadow Minister arguing that it was far from generous.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow Minister began his contribution to the debate by making some comments on the economy. Then he started to attack this Government for making, he claimed, a virtue out of correcting mistakes. It is true to say that this Government has had a lot of experience in fixing up the mistakes of those hard seven years of the Fraser-Howard Government. So to that extent, I think that we are very skilled. Frankly, I do not think that the shadow Minister has much to be proud of in terms of the previous Government's record.

This debate is typical of most debates that occur in the House. Firstly, the Opposition attacks the Government, but it says, at the same time, that it supports the legislation. Even though there has been an election recently, in which the Government won an historic third term, the Opposition makes no contribution by way of offering alternative solutions or proposals. That is most disappointing. In the last election campaign, the Opposition undertook that it would commit radical surgery on the Federal Government's expenditures. So what would it do, what should it do and what must it do under its Liberal philosophy in respect of this area of Government undertaking? Anyone listening to the debate would be no wiser as to the Opposition's policies and approaches. The Government had to take the painful decision in November 1986 to restructure the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The Government has introduced a scheme whereby families can submit 25 prescriptions at a maximum cost of $10 per prescription-the average cost of prescriptions in a calendar year is probably $7.00-and after that there is no charge. We did that on the very reasonable basis of fairness and equity. We have tried to provide maximum benefit to those who have had an extended period of ill-health.

The measure has saved us some $100m. That is not an insignificant amount when one considers that the total expenditure in this area will be about $800m. I think it is a very effective measure; it certainly promotes efficiency. As I say, what would honourable members opposite do? Would they completely dismantle the scheme? Is that their idea? Would they try to privatise it? If so, how would they privatise it? We have no clear understanding of any proposals or policies.

I take issue with some of the remarks of the honourable member for O'Connor. He commented on the Pharmpay system. It is true-and no one seeks to deny it-that the delays in payments to pharmacists were intolerably long. I think the figure cited was 102 days. We ought to place on record the average time at present. I will give two examples: in Melbourne I think the current delay is about seven working days and in Sydney it is 13 working days. Perhaps the Minister will correct me if I am wrong. So there has been a considerable improvement.

One of the key strategies, of course, is to get the pharmacists to supply the information, using compatible computer equipment, on floppy disks or by sending it via a modem straight into the mainframe. This is the trend for the future. I would like to think that it will not be very long before I will be able, using a modem in my electorate office, to tap into a Parliament House computer and extract parts of Hansard or insert some information. This is not a revolutionary approach. It is becoming increasingly prevalent, particularly in the government sector, and so it should. We should be efficient and effective if we are using the latest technology. That is a key factor in reducing these delays.

The honourable member for O'Connor went on to argue that the 2.5c per prescription incentive that was being offered was not very cost-effective as far as pharmacists were concerned. He cited some figures. He suggested that the purchase of a computer would cost $8,000. I am inclined to disagree with that figure as it is too high, but for the purposes of the argument, I am happy to accept it. I would have thought that the honourable member for O'Connor, as the former shadow Minister for small business, would appreciate that one of the things that will revolutionise small business is the introduction of computers in regard to their day-to-day management, operations and planning, be they for budgetary matters, stock, sales or even prescriptions. Personal computers these days give small businesses the oomph and the power that only the large corporations used to have and at a fraction of the cost. That cost is coming down. I make the point that pharmacists would not purchase a computer merely to carry out this sole prescription transaction. That is a very unfair argument.

The honourable member referred to other prescription costs. He suggested that pharmacists who process 2,000 prescriptions a month would get back $50 a month, and that the other costs would greatly outweigh that sum. The critical thing that he ought to look at-again, using the figures of the honourable member for O'Connor -is that if a pharmacist on average is getting $9 per prescription and he is processing 2,000 prescriptions a month, he is receiving about $18,000. If the delay in processing is about two months, the figure would be about $36,000, and that figure would increase as the delays increased. There are holding charges, and an overdraft that must be paid. If we can reduce the delay in payments, the holding charges will be reduced. That is the most significant area of advantage for the chemists. It is pleasing to see the rapid take-up of computers by pharmacies in meeting the Government's keen desire to provide the information on floppy disks or straight into the computer.

It surprised me that one Opposition member referred to the alternative system as Russian roulette. Another Opposition member conjured up pictures of Rookwood cemetery and hordes of Auditors-General rolling over in their graves regarding the alternative system that is being proposed. They suggest that because there is an element of random sampling, it is somehow outrageous or would not be tolerated. Let me say that in my dealings with the Department of Finance, I have never seen the Department keen to permit any system that would lead to overpayments. I think that the Opposition is showing a lack of confidence in the Department of Finance and also in the Australian Bureau of Statistics. In this day and age, as the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) said, there is a clustering around certain drugs and a certain price, and we ought to be using this sort of approach. I point out that the pharmacist is allowed to extract up to 10 per cent from the sample, for full processing. This will usually concern the higher priced items. I am surprised that these issues have been raised.

I thought that the most curious aspect of the Opposition's policy was to insert a sunset clause. One must understand what the alternative system is all about. It is to be used by those people who do not have computers. So the Opposition is happy about those pharmacies that have been able to install new technology and get all those benefits. But the Opposition says that the system for those pharmacies that, for whatever reason, have not installed that technology-maybe because of lack of money-will end on 30 June 1989. What does the Opposition have against those pharmacies that do not have computers? Does the Opposition see this as a way of forcing the industry, by using the brute hand of government, to be 100 per cent computerised? Is this the intention of the Opposition? Perhaps we will find that out during the committee stage.

Most honourable members have commented on the other aspects of the Bill that relate to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. The change proposed is that the Government, whilst not wishing to avoid the purchasing of the most expensive drugs, will now require that Committee to take account of costs. I am pleased that that is so.

I conclude by mentioning one area that I do not think has been commented on by any other member-that is, the area of the person doing the prescribing. We have talked about the technology that pharmacists can use in managing their business. We do have a serious problem in Australia. Plenty of studies have been done in this area, that is, the ability-I think it is related to pressure-of general practitioners to be able to know and prescribe the best and most useful drugs. One will often find that there have been changes as far as the availability of drugs is concerned, but some doctors have not caught up with those changes. I am not trying to launch into a vicious attack on doctors. I am proposing that maybe we ought to start to think about how we can computerise a database of those drugs that are available under this service and, of course, those that are not available. Maybe we should allow doctors to use this facility to ensure that they have access at a moment's notice to the latest information on available drugs. I hope that, although the Minister has other matters to look after, he might look at that matter, talk to the medical profession and see whether he cannot bring about some changes in that area. I commend the Government and the Minister for introducing the Bill. I reiterate that I take particular pride in the fact that our Minister has a small business background.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HUMPHREYS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) for his kind words. I also thank all the honourable members who participated in this debate. It is interesting to note that the Opposition is not opposing this legislation; but, as was pointed out by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), the Opposition intends to move amendments to the legislation. I will refer to just a few of the things mentioned by honourable members, especially the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) and the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb)-it might also have been mentioned by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron)-in relation to Australia becoming a nation of pill poppers. I know that lots of people are concerned about that, especially people in the medical profession.

SPEECH.PARA: The majority of doctors are responsible people. They do not go around prescribing drugs willy-nilly. We all know that lots of people do not feel that they have been treated correctly if the doctor does not prescribe a drug for them, but I do not think there would be too many occasions when members of the medical profession prescribe drugs on that basis. We all know that certain people would be happy to scribble out a prescription just to get rid of the patient, but that does not happen on a great number of occasions.

I am very happy that the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), the honourable member for Streeton and especially the honourable member for Chifley have taken part in this debate. I also appreciate the contributions made by the honourable member for Moreton and the honourable member for Farrer. I will deal with some of the points they have raised. I will start with the comments made by the honourable member for Moreton because he suggested at one stage that if I had a problem with some part of my body-which I can assure him I do not-I would rather have my practitioner prescribing the type of medicine I needed than it being prescribed by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC).

I point out to all members of this House, especially the honourable member for Moreton, that, whilst I have been a Minister for only a very short time, responsible for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, I have the highest regard for that very responsible and eminent group of persons. We in the Government really appreciate the great work and dedication of that group in helping to work out the drugs that need to be on the pharmaceutical benefits list. That group spends a lot of time thinking about those sorts of issues. I know that the nation including the majority of members of this House and the other chamber, appreciate the great work that is being done.

The honourable member for Moreton was worried about the powers that the responsible Minister has-that I have-and that because I was a motor mechanic I might make some desperate decision for him not to have a proper oil change, or something like that. I might prescribe a bit of olive oil or castor oil on occasions for the honourable member for Moreton. But, other than that, I assure him that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and I would not make any decision in relation to drugs unless we had some good advice from all those eminent persons we have to deal with from time to time.

I will go back to the comments of the shadow spokesperson on health, the honourable member for O'Connor. He referred to the problems of Pharmpay and the serious backlogs that occurred during those times. The honourable member would know that the Government has acknowledged the problems that occurred with Pharmpay. But he should be aware that the Pharmpay process system was conceived in 1979 and was approved under the Malcolm Fraser Government, as he was reminded previously by some other members on this side. The Government had a tremendous task in tidying up quite a considerable mess when we took control of the treasury bench-and we are still trying to tidy up the mess. These amendments are just part of a strategy to overcome most of these problems.

The honourable member for O'Connor also talked about a private member's Bill for interest to be paid on late payments by the Commonwealth. As a businessman-he heard that I was a businessman-I know that it is not normal commercial practice to pay interest on late payments. The honourable member knows as well as I do that when in business we used the old 30-day system as much as we could and a lot of our customers used the 90-day system on us. So, he is well aware of the problems associated with business. I do not think that we, as business people, would have been able to charge our account customers who were not paying their accounts on time interest on late payments. Nor do I think we should expect the Commonwealth to do that. As I explained, we had problems with Pharmpay. They are being overcome now; but we could not really pay interest. It is not normal commercial practice.

It is interesting to note that the payment times for pharmacists now are quite acceptable. All processing centres are now taking less than 20 days to process claims fully. In the case of the Victorian processing centre, the delay is less than half that. These amendments, and other initiatives resulting from the efficiency scrutiny, will make it much less likely that payment times in the future will exceed 30 days. I am sure that all pharmacists will be very happy about that.

The honourable member for O'Connor also asked why we should pay the claims transmission system incentives for only two years. I think he is of the opinion that pharmacists should get a greater share of the suggested $5.75m savings from the claims transmission system. I just point out that pharmacists participating in the claims transmission system not only receive the 2.5c initiative but also receive payments 10 days earlier. I am sure the honourable member acknowledges that, if he could have been paid 10 days earlier when he was sending out his accounts, he would have appreciated that. That is also quite an incentive.

As I have also pointed out, if a person buys at the beginning of a month and does not have to pay until the end of the next month, and he is being paid earlier, he has that extra payment from the Government that can be used in his business to his best advantage. The honourable member used to do that. He would not have been a successful businessman if he had not done those sorts of things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not as good as that.

—He might not have been paid on time. But if he is a successful businessman he knows that he has to be up with all those sorts of issues. I also point out that, at the current overdraft rate of 19.5 per cent, this earlier payment is worth an extra 4.8c per prescription. On this basis, over the first two years the pharmacist is receiving some 90 per cent of the estimated 7.8c savings achieved by processing each script through the claims transmission system. I do not think that pharmacists will be too badly off.

SPEECH.PARA: The incentive payment is not intended to cover the cost of purchasing or operating a pharmacy computer, but to encourage those people with computers to participate in the claims transmission system. There are many advantages to pharmacists in using computers, which is why the trend towards computerisation commenced well before the claims transmission system was established.
