The honourable member knows as well as I do that if we have a computer in our business we can get ourselves organised and become more streamlined in the business. We would not put in a computer just to help out the Government. We would put it in to help ourselves. As a business person, the honourable member knows that. He would not do something that would not help to put him on top of the pile. He would not do it just to help the Commonwealth, although as a businessman and a taxpayer he would probably be helping the Commonwealth quite considerably in his business.

The efficiency scrutiny found that in February this year 43 per cent of pharmacists had compatible computers or intended to purchase them within 12 months, but only 11 per cent of pharmacists were participating in the claims transmission system. I am happy to announce that the proportion of pharmacists participating in the claims transmission system now is 44 per cent, which clearly means that pharmacists find the incentives sufficient to encourage them to use the claims transmission system. I think it is a great incentive. Hopefully, more pharmacists will use it. I am sure that it will be to their advantage to take up the Commonwealth's offer. I am sure that when that 44 per cent of pharmacists start meeting and talking at their different committees, many more pharmacists will take up the offer.

Computerisation of pharmacists' claims for reimbursement under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme has helped the Department of Community Services and Health to achieve greater accuracy and to process claims faster. The Government appreciates the great work done behind the scenes by the Department in this regard. Far too often bureaucrats and members of Parliament are accused of spending taxpayers' money unwisely. But not enough credit is paid to persons working behind the scenes; they have to work just as hard as politicians to get everything in order so these systems can work. The success of the new claims transmission system has resulted from close co-operation between the Government, pharmacists and the computer industry.

In order to qualify for the additional 2.5c per prescription, pharmacists must be ready to participate in the system by the end of the month-I stress: by the end of the month. The honourable member for O'Connor said that we should extend this period, but we have to draw the line somewhere. I hope that those pharmacists who are listening in today will take up the opportunity of using the system. If they do not have a computer I am sure we could be a little sympathetic in that regard, as the honourable member for O'Connor suggested. It is important that those who intend to take up the opportunity do so.

As well as speeding up the payment of claims, computerisation has enabled pharmacists to maintain more accurate records of drugs dispensed. As the honourable member for O'Connor realises this is an important issue. As a businessman he would realise how hard it is to keep track of the stock in his hotel and in his other business. He would know what stock he had so that he could keep it topped up. I am sure he uses a computer in his business and knows exactly what he has in stock. The honourable member would know how handy it is to be able to press a button to see, for instance, that one has 24 bottles of scotch, or whatever it may be, in the hotel and to be able to tell from that information what is needed for the month. He would appreciate that computers are more than just being of assistance to the Commonwealth.

I know I am giving the honourable member for O'Connor a work over today but he mentioned many issues and I think it is important to respond to his comments. He was worried about the Government closing down the Adelaide and Hobart processing centres. I can assure the honourable member that at this stage no decision has been taken to close down any of the processing centres.

The honourable member for Farrer and the honourable member for Moreton were concerned about random sampling. This reflects a nineteenth century approach to government accounting. The honourable member for Farrer was saying that Qantas Airways Ltd and other international airlines use this system now. It just goes to show that the Government is on line and that we are taking steps to ensure that we can do the best possible for the Commonwealth, the taxpayer and for those people who do not want to participate in the computer system.

As a result of the program of efficiency scrutinies, the Government has rejected the attitude that every cent has to be checked and double-checked, even if it costs the taxpayer dollars to check each cent. The fact that we are following Qantas in this regard-or probably it is following our example-proves that we do not want to be checking every cent.

The honourable member for Moreton was worried that pharmacists will be forced to accept the sampling method of payment. That is not the case. If pharmacists wish every script to be checked that will be done. The honourable member for O'Connor said that requiring the PBAC to consider costs and benefits will mean that patients will miss out on necessary drugs and that by comparing the cost of drugs with surgery, patients might be forced to have surgery. I can assure the honourable member and the House that this amendment will not mean that patients will miss out on necessary medication. As emphasised in my second reading speech, the Government has no objection to paying high prices for new drugs that offer significant therapeutic advantages. I can give honourable members an assurance on this matter. I appreciate the Opposition's not opposing this legislation. I appreciate all the contributions made by honourable members.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Administrator recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 6, page 5, line 21, omit ``An'', substitute ``Subject to subsection (6) an''.
(2) Clause 6, page 5, at the end of the clause add the following subsection:
`` `(6) No alternative payment election has effect on or after 30 June 1989.'.''.

The purpose of the amendments proposed by the Opposition is to save the Government money in a positive way, not by the negative process that this Government relies on entirely by redu-cing services to patients or remuneration to the health providers. Through that approach the poor in our community suffer. Today, an example of this was brought to my attention. The life of a Tobruk veteran was saved purely by the provision of an intravenous drip. But because of recent changes to the Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits schemes the service which saved the veteran's life is no longer rebatable-in other words, refundable under Medicare. The veteran is a pensioner and has no funds to pay the doctor. As a consequence, the doctor is forced to make a commercial judgment in an area of life and death. Naturally, the doctor made the decision in the patient's interest and the patient still lives. It is clear that the blanket decision of government which has been made in these matters-I highlighted it in my speech at the second reading stage-will always create these isolated problems which could cause a death. I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) to take note of the example I have just given the Committee. In that case, Medicare has imposed a moratorium on the use of intravenous drips and is still making that service rebatable but the Department of Veterans' Affairs is not. The Minister should take note of that; this case was brought to my attention today by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). I am sure he could give the Minister further information on this.

To get to the specifics of the amendment, the situation is, as has been explained during the second reading debate, that the legislation brings three proposals to the fore for the payment of pharmacists in comparison with the old Pharmpay system. I remind the Minister that Pharmpay itself, whether or not the system was introduced in 1975, is not where the problem started. The problem started in 1984 under this Government. Under the system of payment that existed in 1984, the worst scenario throughout Australia was a maximum delay in payment of 28 days. By March 1985 that had drifted to 102 days-as the worst example. Contrary to what the Minister said about that, the payment time is after lodgment of the claim. The pharmacist has already been providing that service and those drugs for a month. He lodges the claim and it takes whatever period it may be to pay. Pharmacists do not make much out of this quicker payment system-except that anything is better than what they had with the 102 days delay. There are three proposals, the first of which is the claims transmission service which the Opposition thinks is an excellent proposal and which was supported and argued for by the previous shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter). It is the electronic alternative which is straight-out data transmission via floppy disks or via a modem. That is very good and we understand that nearly half of the pharmacies in Australia have taken up that option. It is the alternative measure that the Opposition is greatly concerned about, the utilisation of random sampling to establish what the Government owes a particular pharmacy. We recognise that that will be a lot quicker, and we recognise that considering the disaster of Pharmpay it is an appropriate mechanism in the short term. We are not suggesting for a minute that it should be thrown out or deleted from this Bill. The amendment is quite clear, in that it says:
No alternative payment election has effect on or after 30 June 1989.

That means that the profession and the Government will be left with two options. I mentioned that there were presently three. The third option is the old established manual payment system. There has been plenty of evidence from both sides of the chamber that more and more pharmacies will take up the electronic option, the computer option or whatever, irrespective of the paucity of the Government's incentive. I am sorry, but I believe that, when a major initiative from Government providers, whether they be health providers or pharmaceutical providers, can be established that substantially pays the taxpayer money, there should be a good incentive for the innovator, or the co-operator, because if the incentive does not exist people will not take up the option. Whatever else happens, the community and the Government will be the loser as a result.

I made the point yesterday that, if $5.75m is available out of this to the Government and around $1.25m is to go to the pharmacy profession, that is a pretty uneven balance because the pharmacy profession is investing in new equipment and having to undertake other manual labour tasks associated with this arrangement. If the Government wants the rest in the scheme-and I am sure that would be best for everybody not only in regard to the time it takes to pay but also because of the accuracy of records, which the Minister said is advantageous to other areas of small business-and if it wants that sort of co-operation from a conscripted provider, it should encourage the providers to co-operate. The Opposition is saying that, if its amendment is accepted, as of June 1989-and let us hope this very inexact method of random sampling has been removed by then and that 80 or 90 per cent of pharmacies are using the electronic method, the preferred method-assuming that the Government gets it right and bearing in mind this is only the alternative method to get the Government out of the disaster that was Pharmpay, surely the Government ought to be able to handle that final 20 per cent, which would involve all small pharmacies, by the manual method, which, irrespective of its slowness, is an exact method. I know all about cost benefit; I know that it pays sometimes to lose a little on one side to gain it on the other, but we believe that this particular system could be open to considerable distortion and, in fact, to rorting in the end and we will have some desperate government of the future coming in and explaining how bad it is.

A couple of honourable members have chosen to talk about the safety net provision introduced into the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, and that provision basically says that a person can pay for the first 25 prescriptions but get paid for all the others. There is evidence in the community that that provision is being abused. People have woken up to the fact that they can get 25 very low cost prescriptions, irrespective of whether they need them, and then, are free to have open slather on all the rest, which could be hugely expensive.

These are some of the points that have to be raised. Whatever system we bring in that is not exact, that has a degree of flexibility in it, we will find sections of the community abusing it. It is the Opposition's view that the level of abuse will be such as to be quite expensive to the Government, and we do not see it as a long term alternative. We do not consider that this particular initiative needs to be in place for too long, and if there is a clear understanding in the pharmacy profession that after a period of time they will be left with only two options-namely, the electronic option or the manual option-that will be a further incentive for pharmacies to get into computer equipment which will enable them to get prompt payment and the Government to get an efficient and exact service. All of that seems to make a lot of sense to me and I hope, therefore, that that is what the Government does.

I repeat the points I have made: this is not a negative approach, but it is not the sort of approach that has been taken by this Government to everything to do with the delivery of health services. The $8,200m total is the second biggest one line item in the Budget. It is now worrying the Government, but its alternative is to screw down on providers and consumers without looking at the other option of getting more efficiency into the system. This applies not so much in this particular area as to the general health area, where in fact, were the Government to make more use of the private sector instead of frightening people away from it and if it had less inclination to be the owner of the shop instead of the provider of assistance to people in need, it would have a much more efficient system. We would not have the situation that we have about us now. I refer as an example to the Tobruk veteran who could have died had it been up to the Government to provide the service that the doctor was forced to provide for nothing. If that situation continues it will be the very poor and the underprivileged in our community who will be the losers, because the wealthy will always find the funds to meet whatever costs they face.

It is with pleasure that I ask the chamber to support these amendments. They are in the Government's interests, they enable more efficiency and less cost and they remove the long term opportunity for rorting the system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to a couple of points raised in this debate. First, just as the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) had something sprung on him yesterday, so too have I. The matter concerns the need for an orthopaedic procedure to be performed at a hospital. The specialist concerned is a visiting medical officer (VMO) at a public hospital and he also practises at a private hospital. He has informed the patient in question that the delay at a public hospital is 12 months. The procedure can be done immediately at the private hospital. This instantly conjures up great inefficiencies in the public hospitals, but of course that is terribly misleading. What he has not told the patient is that he has an operating list one day a month at that hospital. I happen to know, because the hospital is in my electorate, how desperate that hospital is, firstly, to increase the number of VMOs and, secondly, to increase the operating lists of those VMOs. But the specialist chooses to direct the poor, the rich or any patient that he has into a private hospital. Maybe he is a part owner, I do not know. The issue is not waiting lists at public hospitals; the issue is the amount by which specialists are prepared to increase their lists at those public hospitals.

SPEECH.PARA: Like the honourable member for O'Connor, I do not want to wander too far in this debate. I want to try to understand the purpose particularly of the second amendment that the Opposition has moved. The honourable member for O'Connor said that there are three systems, the first of which is the computer system. I agree with him in that if every pharmacist were on that system we would have a more efficient system and everyone would be delighted. We are all pleased at the rate of take-up. I do not quibble with that. But the second amendment proposes to take away from those pharmacists not on the computer system by 1989 their option to elect an alternative payment system. It removes the alternative random sampling method and, as the honourable member for O'Connor has said, it leaves them with the third option-the manual option.

Both the random sampling method and the manual option are manual systems. There are two differences. There is the incentive of 2.5 per prescription on the alternative system, and there is a quicker processing of bills. I agree with the honourable member that we ought to give every encouragement to pharmacists to move off manual systems and on to computer systems. I do not see it as the Government's role to force pharmacies that do not have computers to have computers or, alternatively, to penalise them after June 1989 if they remain on the manual system where every item is processed. I cannot understand the attraction for the Opposition in restricting these small businessmen, in their choice as to what system they have, by saying that if pharmacies stay in the manual system they will not benefit from the small remuneration of 2.5c per prescription and the shorter processing time. I would be most grateful if the Minister could explain why the Opposition is so down on those pharmacies that do not use computers. Why can they not be left alone to their own choice? If the Opposition is saying that it would like to have a review of the effectiveness and efficiency of the alternative payment system, I am sure the Minister would agree to that. Why should we not look and see whether that system is delivering? It is part of the managerial task anyway. However, I cannot understand why we should take away that option and that freedom of choice from pharmacists. I cannot understand such a suggestion, especially when it comes from the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want briefly to take up some points raised by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) in his speech earlier on the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, in particular, as they highlight some of the weaknesses of the health system. Government speakers have pointed out again and again that there are certain abuses of the system. Everyone supports efforts to rid the system of those abuses. However, what Government members fail to understand is what is causing those abuses. Furthermore, having tried to cut out those abuses, Government members still fail to understand that the methods they are using in fact, in many cases, penalise the genuinely sick and, in particular, penalise those who can least afford to seek alternative solutions to their health problems.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor raised the subject of a very interesting incident-it has just been drawn to my attention-which occurred recently in my electorate concerning one of the Rats of Tobruk, still a very famous group of people in our society. That veteran unfortunately collapsed and was taken to the hospital, where he was unconscious for two days. The only way the doctor could save his life was to give him intravenous infusions. I am glad to see that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) is at the table because I am sure he will be interested in following up this case. The Repatriation Commission refused to recognise the treatment. In fairness to the doctor involved, I ask whether he has or has not performed his duty. The answer quite clearly is that he has. However, the Repatriation Commission refused to recognise what the doctor had done and said that the doctor was entitled to be paid only for an ordinary hospital visit. This doctor saved the life of a man who served his country at Tobruk, a very famous battle of the last war-something of which I am sure the Minister would be well aware. That is what happened. This is the way the system has refused to recognise the support the doctor gave to that sick person. The repatriation system has ruled that our completely.

I think that incident is symptomatic of an overall problem in our society today resulting from the changes to Medicare in the May mini-Budget. In many cases the Government, in trying to stamp out abuses, will in fact encourage bad medicine. In other words, it will not reward doctors for doing what they believe is the right thing. It will penalise them because the Government is trying to stamp out abuses which a small minority of people is engaging in. The Government should look closely at why the abuses are occurring. The simple answer is that Medicare is failing. Medicare is failing because, as everyone knows, it was destined to fail right from the beginning. Such a system does fail. It has failed overseas. It has failed in Canada, on whose system we have modelled ours. However, we find now that not only are beds being closed in Canadian hospitals but, in fact, complete hospitals are being closed.

There is no doubt that the case which I have just highlighted is a serious indictment of what is happening to the whole health care system in Australia and, in this particular instance, not only what is happening to Medicare but also what is happening to the repatriation system. I hope that the Minister will move very quickly to rectify the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HUMPHREYS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot agree to the Opposition's proposed amendments to the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, as I am sure the honourable member for O`Connor (Mr Tuckey) would have known. In relation to the incident which the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) has mentioned to the Committee, I will certainly check this matter. Although I do not think that it has a great deal to do with the amendment, I will take that matter on board because both the honourable member for O'Connor and the honourable member for Wannon brought the matter up. I assure the honourable member for Wannon that I will look at the matter if he gives me the names and addresses of the gentleman and the doctor concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor said that his proposed amendments would save the Government money. That is incorrect. The sample processing is estimated to save $3m per annum in processing costs. The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) said that he did not know why the Opposition was not keen on pharmacies being allowed to operate in the way they have always done by, for example, taking part in the sample processing. I mention to the honourable member for O'Connor and other honourable members that the sample processing method has been checked by and agreed to by both the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Commonwealth Department of Finance. I am sure the honourable member for O'Connor will be interested to know that the sample processing method, in conjunction with the incentive payments being offered for this method, will ensure that over a two-year period pharmacists will have a nine out of 10 chance of being overpaid and one chance in 1,000 of being underpaid by more than 0.5 per cent. The pharmacists will be well in front in that regard. I do not think we will have problems there.

The honourable member for O'Connor will appreciate that probably all pharmacists will not be able to hook into the system we are suggesting. A lot of pharmacists in country areas do not have a tremendous clientele or a big job to do. They have plenty of time to check their stock and therefore may not need the use of a computer. Although a computer may help them in some degree, they probably would not have the number of prescriptions of local large pharmacists. The honourable member mentioned in his speech yesterday that we used to be able to go into the small pharmacy to buy our medication but that now we are tripping over vitamin pills and toys and all sorts of other things. I think that the honourable member would appreciate that in business people have to diversify a little, otherwise they will not be able to survive in those small areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only in small areas!
—I mean in small country towns. Therefore, I leave the Opposition with my earlier remark, that once again the Government cannot agree to the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Mr Tuckey's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Humphreys)-by leave-read a third time.
Debate resumed from 22 October, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That this House consents to termination by the Commonwealth of the Airlines Agreement 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, let me thank the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) for facilitating a debate on this most important issue, which deals with the deregulation of Australia's domestic airline industry. Also at the outset, let me say that, as a result of this Government's policies, two great Australian institutions-Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd-are in desperate financial straits. The motion before the House represents a belated recognition by the Government that deregulation is the only means by which the airline industry can be competitive and efficient and be responsive to the needs of the travelling public. This motion has been a long time coming.
—You did not do anything.

—I will tell the honourable member what we did. In 1981, we introduced a two-airline agreement which was a substantial improvement on the previous one, and we introduced legislation to turn Australian Airlines into a public company, legislation which this Government repealed in 1984. This Government has, after all, had the opportunity to terminate the two-airline argeement at any time since 26 January this year, but it is already nine months since that date, and only now do we have an opportunity to discuss this issue. For that reason, the Opposition is moving an amendment, which has been circulated in my name, noting the Government's delay in terminating the two- airline agreement and condemning it for certain aspects of the document which was released by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) on 7 October this year entitled Domestic Aviation: a new direction for the 1990s.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to point out to the Minister that the amendment that we propose was carried in the Senate, and that clause 22 (5) of the Airlines Agreement 1981 makes it clear that termination can be completed only if both Houses of Parliament pass the relevant resolution. It seems reasonably clear, although no doubt the Minister will want to take advice on this matter, that termination can take effect only if the Government is prepared to accept our amendment. Although I recognise that, in some respects, the amendment is critical of the Government, nonetheless what we say is that it is accurate and the Government should accept the amendment so that termination can take place as soon as this motion passes this House.

The coalition parties will not oppose the motion because the motion proposes a course of action that we have been advocating for some years now. In fact, very many of the phrases from the document on domestic aviation are taken almost word for word from the Liberal and National parties' domestic airline policy. Unfortunately, the document simply does not go far enough. I would like to spend some time detailing those areas with which the Government has failed to come to terms. It is a matter of too little too late.

The two-airline system has served Australia well over the years and it has facilitated through successive governments the growth of a dependable, consistent and safe airline industry in this country. In fact, our safety record on commercial aviation is the envy of every other country in the world. However, times change and so have the circumstances surrounding the type of regulation needed in the airline industry in order to provide the kinds of services the travelling public wants. The 1981 agreement recognised that change and that there was a need for improved competition. That agreement has been only partially successful in meeting its objective. The coalition parties recognised some time ago that there was a need for change and for most of the period that this Government has been in office we have been pushing for deregulation of the domestic aviation industry. We have constantly emphasised the need for the Government to reduce its involvement in regulation of the industry.

What we find very difficult to believe is that it has taken the Government so long to come to the realisation that deregulation is appropriate, and only then to come to it in half measure. This slow dawning on the Government that it can no longer afford the extravagance of interfering in the day to day running of airlines, let alone running an airline itself, is a recognition that the coalition's aviation policy has been the most appropriate one for Australia. Labor's attempts to deride what I have been saying have now shown themselves to be blatantly false. We condemn the Government for its failure to face up to one of the most crucial areas in the deregulation issue, and that is its failure to bite the bullet on what it plans to do with its own carrier, Australian Airlines. Deregulation of Australia's airline industry without any accompanying statement on what the Government intends to do with Australia Airlines is one of the most economically senseless and political cynical acts. The fact is that the Government knows it cannot promote an effective, efficient and competitive domestic airline industry without ensuring that Australian Airlines can compete on equal terms, and it knows this cannot happen unless the shackles of Government constraints are removed from that airline and that Australian has access to appropriate funding.

The Government has put its toe in the water by conceding that it must convert Australian Airlines to a public company and I venture to suggest that the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) will not be taking too many copies of the Hansard of today around his electorate because if he does his constituents will be asking, `Why have we got that dill in the Parliament?'. I need hardly remind the House that this was the same Government that in 1984 repealed legislation that would have permitted the transfer of what was then Trans-Australia Airlines (TAA) to public company status. The then Minister, in repealing the legislation, stated that public company status was not appropriate for TAA and that deregulation was not appropriate for the airline industry. It really does take some time for this Government to get its act together.

In any event, the Government has almost certainly made up its mind to privatise Australian Airlines. There is simply no other solution to the problems raised by public sector controls and lack of funding that would enable Australian Airlines to compete in the domestic market. The Government, in an attempt to circumvent its internal factional difficulties, has created the smokescreen of an advisory group which will, within six months, report to the Government on the alternatives for the future capital requirements of Australian Airlines. The composition of that group is fascinating in that the five appointees all come from what I might loosely call special interest groups. Their recommendation on future financing for Australian Airlines will lock in those interest groups, so that the Government can say to its party room, `Look, we have had this expert advisory group which comes from a spectrum of interests. We are bound to accept its recommendation'. That recommendation almost certainly will be to privatise Australian Airlines in order to give that company access to the very substantial funds it needs in order to compete effectively.

Of particular interest is the appointment of the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to that advisory group. In fact, the Secretary of the ACTU is becoming increasingly busy these days as he assumes a number of advisory jobs for the Government which, as we know, cannot make a decision in the economic area without the blessing of that organisation. The Opposition wishes the advisory group well. We have little doubt that it will recommend privatising Australian Airlines and our criticism of the Government is for building into the deregulation process a further nine months delay; that is, until after the Australian Labor Party conference in June next year. Then and only then, a year and a half after the Government was in a position to do so, will it commence the process of implementing the coalition's aviation policy.

The delay also has some unfortunate side effects for competition in the industry. For example, any potential new entrant would wish to be very careful about the extent to which it commits itself to become involved in the industry before the Government makes clear its plans for Australian Airlines. Even Ansett Airlines of Australia, which has competed against Australian Airlines very effectively over the past few years, takes the position that deregulation cannot be effective without privatising Australian Airlines. The coalition's policy has specific provisions relating to the maintenance of air services to isolated communities; Senator Evans's `new direction' does not. The coalition's policy details a specific level of cross-airline ownership; Senator Evans's `new direction' does not. The coalition's policy gives details of how the nation's airports will be managed; Senator Evans's `new direction' does not. In fact, the Government's Federal Airports Corporation is still in limbo, inappropriately staffed or alternatively overstaffed, its commencement date deferred again and financing details still to be resolved.

The coalition's policy gives detailed plans to make what was formerly the Department of Aviation more efficient and able to cope with a deregulated environment; Senator Evans's `new direction' does not. In fact, the Government has cast another smokescreen over this matter by saying that it will create a civil aviation corporation or a civil aviation authority, which is clearly designed to obscure its own inefficiencies. The coalition's policy outlines a review of regulations and Air Navigation Orders to improve their effectiveness and simplicity; Senator Evans's `new direction' shows hardly any interest in this area. In fact, in very many aspects the documents that the two Ministers have tabled are not `A New Direction for the 1990s' but `directionless' for the 1990s.

One other very important matter deserves comment. The `new direction' fails to deal with the great difficulties being experienced by international travellers returning to Australia. Such passengers have been lying in the aisles and lounges of airports around the world because there have been insufficient seats on flights returning to Australia. Furthermore, for example, there is demand in excess of the available seats for 400 tourists each week to go to Darwin, and so valuable tourist dollars are being lost to Australia. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) is quarrelling not only with the former environment Minister about the monorail from Ayers Rock to the Olgas but also with the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) about the provision of additional international airline seats. At the very minimum, the matter could be partially alleviated by privatising a minority interest in Qantas to enable it to begin the process of spending the necessary $400m or more that it needs to spend in order to re-equip its fleet over the next five years, and so provide more seats. Again, I commend to the Government this part of the coalition's aviation policy. I point out to the Government that as a result of its policies and its failure to fund Australian Airlines and Qantas properly it has put these two great Australian institutions in desperate financial straits. Until the Government bites the bullet and decides what has to be decided about ownership of Australian Airlines and Qantas, until it comes to the decision to privatise Australian Airlines, and until it comes to the decision to privatise, at the minimum, a minority interest in Qantas it will leave these two most important and revered Australian institutions at desperate financial risk.

It is all too little too late. The deregulation of the domestic airline industry will not be complete without privatisation of Australian Airlines and a more efficient Department of Aviation. The Government has failed in terms of time lost and it has failed in terms of plans to be implemented prior to the official termination of the agreement in three years. It has failed in terms of airport infrastructure, especially in Sydney, and it has failed in terms of air freight and the morale of the employees of Australian Airlines. Having given those reasons, while members of the Opposition do not oppose the motion itself, we commend our amendment to the House. I move:
That the following words be added to the motion:
``, and (1) notes the long overdue adoption by the Government of a substantial part of the Coalition's aviation policy:
``, and (2) further notes the Government's de facto decision to privatise Australian Airlines, which is the inevitable and proper consequence of the deregulation of the airline industry; and
``, and (3) condemns the Government for:

(a) the time lost since the first day that notice of termination of the Two Airlines Agreement could have been given (January 1987) and the effect this has had on the postponement of the commencement of deregulation of the Australian airline industry;
(b) its inaction during this period in not preventing the removal of competitors in the airline industry, which will substantially reduce competition;

(c) the repeal of legislation which the previous Coalition Government had in place to convert the then Trans Australia Airlines (TAA) into a company, thereby reducing the ability of TAA to readily adjust to the new deregulated environment;
(d) the absence of pre-1990 informal measures to facilitate deregulation;
(e) its failure to provide the necessary infrastructure at Australia's airports, especially Kingsford-Smith Airport in Sydney, so as to cope with present and, more importantly, future congestion;
(f) not completely deregulating domestic and international airfreight carried by Australian airlines; and
(g) creating unnecessary uncertainty amongst Australian Airline employees as to their future''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in support of the termination of the Airlines Agreement 1981 and the statement made by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), I point out that once again the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) has claimed in this chamber that the sole purpose of Government policy in this matter is to pre-empt debate on whether the public enterprises of Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd are to be sold off to private enterprise. I reject that claim as being sheer and unadulterated nonsense. The trouble with the Opposition in this House, and I refer to both the Liberal and National parties, is that it fails to grasp how the democratic processes in the Australian Labor Party (ALP) actually work. Of course, I am not going to deny that thoughts of privatising-what a terrible word that is-Australian Airlines are in the heads of some Ministers in the Government.
—Ha!

—Why does the honourable member not listen? He might learn something about the democratic processes undertaken in the Labor Party. A full scale debate on the issue of privatisation is presently taking place within the ALP and it will continue up to and including the June national conference of the Party. I have made no secret of my complete support not only for the retention of public enterprises in Australia but also for an extension of public enterprises to some of the commanding heights of the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no doubt that the supporters of public enterprise will win the debate. I have a notice of motion listed for debate in this House at a future time when I hope to be able to elaborate my views on this matter. Today, however, we are not debating the matter of public versus private enterprise; we are debating the termination of the airlines agreement and the new direction for domestic aviation in the 1990s. I consider that privatisation and the future of the aviation industry are entirely separate issues, and I intend to speak in this debate accordingly. Let me repeat: It does not follow that the ending of the airlines agreement will lead to the privatisation of Australian Airlines. I note that Australian Airlines has gone on record in its response to the May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation as follows:
Australian Airlines believes that its ownership is not relevant in any consideration of changes to the regulatory system.

I must admit that prior to my election to this House on 18 October 1980, I had had little experience of aircraft operations, either domestic or international. It is true to say that the majority of Australians do not travel regularly on domestic aircraft, although I believe that the number of people who travel at least several times a year will rapidly increase over the next few decades. In my view, the ending of the airlines agreement will be one of the reasons for an increase in air travel. Since I became a member of parliament I have travelled on at least 60 flights each year, mostly, of course, between Canberra and Melbourne.

My best experience of the operations of airlines was gained from 20 May 1983 to September 1985, as Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation while the Committee was undertaking a three-year inquiry into the effect of aircraft noise on the Australian population. Our inquiry was preceded by a House of Representatives Select Committee on Aircraft Noise and that Committee also made a number of recommendations, most of which had been implemented by 1983, although in the view of many people living close to or under aircraft flight paths not necessarily satisfactorily. By the time a report was submitted to the House in September 1985, the Select Committee on Aircraft Noise had taken over the work of the Environment and Conservation Committee of the Thirty-third Parliament, with myself as Chairman of that Select Committee.

In the course of my remarks I will refer to some of the recommendations of the Select Committee, which entitled its September 1985 report Aircraft operations and the Australian community. I commend the report to those new members of the House who may not have read it, and this applies particularly to those members who live in the Sydney metropolitan region. Having established my credentials to join in this debate, I should also add that as Chairman of the Select Committee, I had the thrilling experience of attempting a simulated take-off and landing in a jet airliner-not too successfully I might add. I also sat in the cockpit with the air- crew on a number of Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines flights, and discussed the practical problems of aircraft operations. I also had many discussions in the control towers of our major airports with air traffic controllers, and as well I talked with airline operators and Royal Australian Air Force personnel. The most lively meetings of all were with the people who live close to or under the flight paths of our major airports. Unfortunately, I do not have time to detail some of those discussions, but I am sure that members of the House would find them most interesting.

I believe that the report that was produced is one of the most comprehensive reports on the effect of aircraft operations on the environment surrounding airports, particularly in relation to aircraft noise. In this respect, I was pleased to read in the published response of Australian Airlines entitled Response to the Report of the Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation the following comment:

The 112 seat configuration of the Australian Airlines' Boeing 737-300 is an outcome of our desire to replace the 92 seat McDonnell-Douglas DC9 with a new, quieter, fuel efficient aircraft. The 737-300 was the only aircraft in production which met these criteria.

Whilst I appreciate that seating density was an important factor relating to the acquisition of the Boeing 737-700, it is gratifying to note that the matter of quietness was also an important factor. It is interesting to note that the first airline agreement originated in 1952, and since that time there have been a number of contractual and legislative arrangements. It is a pity that the Hansard report cannot record, amongst all the black print, pictures of the different types of aircraft, representing stages in the development of aviation policy in Australia. It would certainly make the Hansard more attractive for future reference.

The Minister referred to the 1972 airlines agreement and to the 1981 airlines agreement, and there is no doubt that those agreements have allowed the private aviation industry to grow to such an extent that by now Australian Airlines is smaller than Ansett, and it will need freedom to expand without the restrictions on its raising of capital which presently exist with the requirement that it be subject to the borrowing constraints exercised by the Loan Council. I have noticed that the Minister has said that the Government is examining the scope for removing the borrowing controls on Australian Airlines, among other controls on government business enterprises. I sincerely hope that the borrowing restriction will be lifted at the earliest opportunity to enable Australian Airlines to compete with some chance of economic survival against Ansett and any other business predator which may be seeking to make some privatisation gains at the expense of Australian Airlines. Australian Airlines has pointed out, and again I quote from its report:

In contrast to Australian Airlines, Ansett, which is owned by worldwide media and transport interests with immense financial strength, has used its commercial freedom and great resources to move to a position from which it could dominate the domestic aviation market in a less regulated environment.
It also said:

Australian Airlines stands ready to compete in a less regulated market, but in order to do so it is essential the Government affords it similar commercial freedom to its competitors including access to capital.

I will not repeat what I have said before in this speech, except to say that the Government's present initiative was something that had to be done to enable Australian Airlines to provide-and I quote the Minister-`effective competition across the travel route network'.

I would now like to make some references to the September 1985 report of the Select Committee on Aircraft Noise and to express my regret that the Government has not yet responded to the 31 recommendations of the Committee. While I appreciate the difficulties for the Government with regard to the July election, it seemed to me not unreasonable for the Government to have made a considered response to those of the recommendations which were less sensitive in the policy areas, the implementation of which could improve the efficiency and safety of aircraft operations. I refer particularly to recommendations Nos 1 to 9 inclusive, requiring the introduction of various studies and surveys on the effects of aircraft noise levels on human health and the value of land and buildings, and possible damage to buildings. Other recommendations were related to aircraft procedures involving flight paths and others were related to land zoning. Many of those recommendations could have been implemented with little opposition from the major users of airports and people living close to airports. Indeed, I would venture to suggest that the Government would have gained approval for implementing the recommendations. I quote from the second paragraph of recommendation 11:

The Department of Aviation investigate fully the feasibility of installing additional navigational equipment at noise sensitive areas which would enable flight paths to be designed to lessen noise impacts.

I think that what that pointed to was the need for an upgrading of navigational equipment in some of the major airports in general and the control towers in particular. I have been advised, however, that the Government is sympathetic to the Committee's recommendations and that the reason for the delay is that the report addressed difficult and complex problems involving the three levels of government-that is, Federal, State and local. I understand that the Government considers that many of our conclusions are interrelated and believes that a single comprehensive response addressing all recommendations would be more appropriate than an incomplete interim response.

I have noted specifically the Minister's comments on safety. Deregulation of the airline industry in the United States of America (USA) has resulted in a desperate shortage of experienced pilots, maintenance crews, accident investigators and aircraft controllers. The Minister has attributed the problems with the United States aviation work force as due to cost, but I think that they are also due to an intransigent government which refuses to recognise the dangers which cost cutting and the so-called free flow of market forces can cause in a deregulated industry.

Several weeks ago I travelled on an aircraft which was held up for 50 minutes because it had suffered a hydraulic failure. In the deregulated aviation industry in the USA, that plane probably would have been used. But I am glad that in Australia we operate with a higher level of safety standards. Many accidents are occurring in the United States as a result of deregulation. I was most pleased to note the Minister's comments on safety regulations and the paramount importance of continuing to apply safety regulation and surveillance when the airlines agreement terminates. I congratulate the Australian aviation industry on its high safety standards. I trust that the proposed review of the legislative framework for safety regulations, which is to be undertaken by the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), will ensure that `simplification and rationalisation' does not mean a lessening of the present safety standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I thank my colleague the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull). I want to raise in the grievance debate today the very serious problem that is developing in Australia as a result of the Commonwealth Government's intrusion into land-use management, an area that has always traditionally been under the powers of the State governments. This is not happening just in one State and it is not happening just in one area. A fundamental change has come over the division of powers as between the Commonwealth and the States as a result of the High Court decision relating to what is known as the Franklin Dam case. In that particular case the High Court ruled that, in fact, the Commonwealth Government had the power to intervene in matters that had traditionally been the responsibility of State governments and for the Commonwealth Government to effectively take over the land-use management in what is now known as the South West National Park or the Wild Rivers National Park.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of that particular case, the precedent the decision created is now being taken to much greater extent, particularly now in relation to the forestry issue and in relation to other environmental matters where the Commonwealth Government is using the precedent of the Franklin Dam case to intervene and to pass legislation giving instruction to the States as to how their land areas should be managed, that is, effectively to take over the land-use management of those areas. We are seeing this in the case of Kakadu National Park, the north Queensland rainforests and in certain forestry areas in Tasmania. In relation to the forestry areas in Tasmania, I will be fairly curbed in what I say in that particular matter as the issue is currently before the High Court and I would not wish to make too pointed comments because the matter could very well be ruled to be sub judice until such time as the High Court has made a ruling.

If we trace this issue back-I believe it is fair to trace it back-to the Constitution and to the point of Federation, if we read through the constitutional debates during the 1890s before Federation, we find that one thing overshadowed all those debates. It was the fear of the small States; the people representing the small States feared that if they came into federation as a country, as a nation of Australia, the interests of the small States would be overridden by the voting and numerical strengths of New South Wales and Victoria. It was because of that fear held by all the small States at that time that the Constitution was arranged in the way it was. It was the very purpose of having the Senate organised in the way it was: to give protection to the small States and to prevent those small States from being overridden by the interests particularly of Melbourne and Sydney, but generally of the larger, more populous States of Victoria and New South Wales.

We see now, Mr Deputy Speaker, that because of interests in Melbourne and Sydney in particular, the interests of the small States-Queensland, the Northern Territory and Tasmania-are being completely ignored; that the interests of people living in those States are being totally overridden because of demands of people living in Melbourne and Sydney.

I do not think any of us in this Parliament would believe that the present Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator Richardson, has suddenly had an insight and has become a born again greenie. None of us would believe that. Senator Richardson has looked at the political research, he has looked at opinion polls and has determined that there are perhaps votes to be won in Melbourne and Sydney if he overrules the interests of the small States and makes himself popular with the conservation movement. Because of that, because Senator Richardson and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) believe that votes can be won in Melbourne and Sydney, he is quite prepared to put thousands of people in Tasmania and north Queensland out of work simply to pacify those conservation people in Melbourne and Sydney. That was the very circumstance that people representing the small States so much feared during the 1890s when the constitutional conventions were being held. It was for that very reason that we had the Constitution framed in the way it is, the very reason for having the Senate arranged in the way it is: to give equal representation to the States and therefore give protection to the smaller States. But we are seeing all those constitutional and structural arrangements in Australia poured down the drain because Senator Richardson and the Prime Minister believe they can win votes in Melbourne and Sydney.

It may well be that this is the way the Australian people want to go. But they should not go down that road blind; they should know what they are doing before they go down that road. It is my view, Mr Deputy Speaker, that if we do want so fundamentally to turn the Constitution over, it should not be done by back-door methods such as those being used by Senator Richardson and the Prime Minister. It should be done by a change to our Constitution, by proposing a referendum to give all the people of Australia the opportunity to say whether they want the Constitution changed. But as a result of the High Court decision in the Franklin Dam case, the Government found that it could use a back-door method through the foreign affairs power, which was never intended to be used in the way it is. The High Court ruled that the Federal Government could use the foreign affairs power to take over powers that had traditionally been the province of the State governments.

If we continue down that road, we then have to question what will be the role of the State governments. What mechanism can we in Australia provide that will give comfort and security to people living outside the major population areas of Melbourne and Sydney. If no constitutional or institutional protection is given to those people, at any time their interests can be taken over and subsumed by the interests of people living in Melbourne and Sydney. It is a very dangerous situation and I would be surprised if my friend from the other side of the chamber, the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), would not share some of these concerns that I have, coming from the area that he does.

I think people who have a genuine and heartfelt interest in conservation should be reminded that in the case of the north Queensland rainforests, covering as they do an area 450 kilometres long by almost 100 kilometres wide at the widest point, only 20 per cent of that area is to be logged; 80 per cent of it will never be touched. In that 20 per cent that is to be logged, only four trees per hectare are to be taken and those trees will be nominated by officers from the Queensland Forestry Commission. Four trees will be taken per hectare each 40 years, which will give that area plenty of time to recover and to regenerate. I do not think any of us would consider that to be excessive use of the rainforest area.

In the case of Tasmania there is a very well planned and designed forest management program in place that is designed very substantially to improve the quality of forests over an 80-year period. But we should also be conscious that in Tasmania 27 per cent of its land area is currently in the form of national parks-27 per cent of the land area of that State, which takes in huge areas of our natural environment. Those areas will never be touched for forestry, mining or any other form of development. So the emotions that are generated in Melbourne and Sydney in very many cases are misplaced, although I understand the heartfelt concerns of people living in those areas.

What I believe is of more importance in this issue is the constitutional role and the protection under the Constitution that may or may not be given to the small States in the future. If the Commonwealth insists on taking over these areas of powers, traditionally the province of the small States, I believe it is running a grave risk of disintegrating the federation of Australia. I do urge my friends on the other side to think carefully about where they are heading.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate to raise an issue of particular importance to central Queensland but, I believe, also to the nation generally. I refer to the Byfield area, which is north of Yeppoon in central Queensland and which for the last 15 or so years has been proposed as a national park. It has been described by some who are involved in the environmental movement as the Cooloola on the Capricorn coast. I think this is understandable, because in comparison with Cooloola it is climatically similar and the area is rich in vegetation associations. It is an extremely interesting area, in fact. If you were to travel in the Stockyard Point area you would find part of it clothed in open and, in some cases, closed heath scrub. There are also the melaleuca open forests and low open forests and additionally interdunal swamps. In other parts of this 13,000-hectare area there are isolated pockets of rainforests, and many people appreciate now, because of the publicity given to the fact, that it is the home of the rare Byfield fern.

SPEECH.PARA: The region is also notable because other plant species are found there including the rare grevillea venusta. Although it naturally occurs in the Byfield-Port Curtis area, it is certainly a very important species found in the Byfield section itself. The region butts on to an area known as Corio Bay which itself is an important estuarine area with significant tracts of well-developed mangroves thriving on the large volumes of fresh water that flow out of Water Park Creek. I suppose one could go on talking about the sea front, expanding upon the low open woodlands, the Wallum community the eucalyptus, the shrub lands, the sand masses, the mountains, the rocky headlands, the plains, the beaches, the fast flowing streams and so on. But suffice to say that it is an important area and it is an area that has land forms and vegetation patterns that should be preserved. I stress `preserved', not to the advantage of a few individuals but to the advantage of all Australians.

The importance has been recognised by people from both sides of the political fence. In more recent times, there have been some promises by the Queensland National Party Government to declare the area as a national park. In fact, some of those promises seem to go back about 10 years, although it is very hard to tie them down to a time. Despite the promises there has been no action, although I think everyone has believed that something would eventually happen. Unfortunately now the question arises whether or not the declaration of a national park is assured, because there has been the exposure of a proposal by the Premier of Queensland to hand over about 8,000 hectares of this 13,000-hectare area to the Japanese tourism developer, Iwasaki. I note that today's Sydney Morning Herald denies this and the Deputy Premier of Queensland has come out and said that it is not on.

However, claims have been made in the central Queensland area and they have now been made in the State Parliament, particularly by the Australian Labor Party spokesman on the environment, Pat Comben, that Cabinet is acting on this matter. In fact, a submission was put to Cabinet on Monday 31 August, which was taken to the Queensland National Party Cabinet by the Premier himself. This submission pushes not a national park but an environmental park in the Byfield area. It also proposes that land should be made available for port access if that is required.

Some two weeks ago I was told by a very senior departmental officer in Queensland that a proposition was being put together by the Premier and Iwasaki whereby an environmental park would be developed; it would be declared and Iwasaki would be in charge of it. The management role would be his, he would be in charge of the running of the environmental park and he would meet the costs of the pathways, bridges and so on. It seems that that deal has been done despite the disclaimers. It seems that a scheme has been put together whereby a trustee arrangement has been prepared or proposed to get around Federal legislation.

The honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) talked about the Commonwealth taking over State responsibilities and his words were `using a back-door method'. I would suggest that he have a hard look at what is happening in Queensland and the proposal by the Queensland Premier to get around the Foreign Investment Review Board rules, to get around the laws brought down in this Parliament by the previous Liberal and National Party Government in 1978 designed to prevent the Iwasaki group from acquiring more land. It seems that the Queensland Premier is trying to get around it through this loophole of setting up a trusteeship arrangement. Instead of having a national park, the idea is to have an environmental park under the control of the Japanese, to cast aside a national park to the advantage of all Australians and instead give it to a commercially oriented group that is foreign and over which we would have no control.

The Queensland National Party member for Broadsound, Dennis Hinton, has said that the Premier has now changed his mind. I question that statement. Who would believe it? There is a commitment between the National Party and Iwasaki and I cannot see Bjelke-Petersen backing off. It may be just a coincidence that his own son-in-law, Lester Folker, is a director of the Iwasaki company. It may be just a coincidence that there has been this talk of an environmental park for some time in the hands of some commercial developer. It may be just a coincidence that there has been a push in recent times for Iwasaki to set up his own airport, which just happens to have a flight path that involves the Byfield area.

The original Queensland International Tourist Resort Act does not provide for any further acquisition of land by Iwasaki but it does not prevent a trusteeship arrangement. Plans have been available for over 10 years that clearly show that Iwasaki has had plans and proposals over a long time to manage the area, or at least to use the area. Some of those plans go back to 1977-78 where there was a bridge from the Iwasaki side-that is the tourist side-across Water Park Creek to the Byfield Park area. Those same plans show a scenic fishing settlement on Corio Bay, outside the franchise area. Those plans also show a proposed road system. So I believe there has always been a move, for the Japanese if not to own the area, at least to control it.

I can understand why, Mr Deputy Speaker, because this would certainly enhance the value of that tourist resort. The Byfield area is of international tourist importance. I can see enormous commercial advantages for Iwasaki if he is able to attach to his resort a magnificent area like the Byfield. I say through this chamber that the Premier needs to come clean. We do not want some denial by the Deputy Premier; we want the Premier himself to stand up publicly and say exactly what the plans are. I call upon him to release publicly the submission that he made to Cabinet. I call on him to state publicly his intentions and release the details of any deal that he has done with Iwasaki; and more importantly Cabinet, casting aside the Premier, should give an unequivocal undertaking that the Byfield will be declared as a national park.

Cabinet should set down a specific timetable. I respect Bill Gunn and Mike Ahearn in their opposition to what they now say the Premier is intending to do. But that opposition is not good enough verbally; it has to be done legislatively, because we know of the powerful lobby group that influences politics in Queensland, particularly the National Party. I mentioned before that it is not coincidental that Iwasaki is now announcing that he wants to go ahead with an airport, to build a 3,000-metre airstrip to take wide-bodied jets.

He is talking about international flights. There was talk that he had done a deal with Ansett but I have had that completely denied by the Deputy General Manager, Graham McMahon. He denies there is a deal or a signed agreement. But what we do know, because of a map that I have here, is that Iwasaki had selected a site which could be used for his own airport. The site has a flight path and site development area that could affect the Corio Bay and the fish habitat reserve there. It also could affect, in some ways, Water Park Creek and therefore the Byfield Park. I support development but not to the detriment of the region in the long term. I think few people realise how powerless this Parliament is, and this Government is, to stop airport developments, because if some private developers want to meet the technical and safety standards set down by this Government we cannot stop them unless it is on environmental grounds and unless we restrict their landing rights, that is, only international landing rights. We cannot stop the domestic landing rights. So we certainly need to review the Federal powers and amend the existing Act.

Irrespective of the airport proceeding, the Byfield land should not be handed over to Iwasaki. The foreign investment rules that have been in place here for some time should not be circumvented and the Queensland Premier should not be putting his Japanese mates before the State of Queensland. I take up the point made by the honourable member for Lyons. It is quite amazing that on the one hand the Premier will oppose the World Heritage listing of rainforests in north Queensland, which is to give the area protection, yet on the other hand he is personally involved in moves to beat Australian laws in order to give away control of an important part of central Queensland to a foreign tourism developer. It must not happen. The Premier should come clean and Cabinet should move immediately to declare the Byfield area as a national park.
