SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I first wish to acknowledge the generosity of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) in forgoing his place in this debate to enable me to grieve on a matter of the utmost concern to my electorate, to concerned Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) viewers, all lawn bowlers, former bowlers, and their families and friends throughout Australia. The ABC recently announced that it is abandoning one of Australia's longest running sports programs in circumstances which bring the ABC little credit. The program that I wish to speak about is Jack High. Interestingly, when an honourable member asked me earlier today what I was going to grieve about in this debate I said to him, `Jack High' and he said, `The bowls program'. I was surprised in a sense how readily recognisable that program is to people who hear reference to it.

SPEECH.PARA: I saw in a recent bowls journal-and I think it is rather interesting because even bowlers themselves thought a program on bowling would not greatly attract audiences or interest-this statement: `A TV series on bowls. It would be less exciting than watching paint dry.' That was the reaction of most people to the proposition that a 16-week television series on lawn bowls would be successful. Nevertheless, that program has become an annual world bowls event. It commenced in Victoria in 1980. Players in that year came from all around the world to Frankston. The program was televised by the ABC and it inspired a positive reaction from viewers around Australia. As a non-bowler but a long time supporter of this sport-and I must declare in this matter I have an interest; I am patron of the West Epping Bowling Club-I have personally watched the program and have come to know of its undoubted support in the community.

The idea for the program was simple. Eight of the world's best lawn bowlers, four Australian and four overseas players, in two sections would compete in a round robin held over one week. They would then contest the semi-final with the winner going on to compete for the prestige trophy. In 1981 the competition moved to Beaumaris, also in Victoria. Its reputation grew and for several years the program was produced from that location. The ABC editing skills improved and the best action shots were creatively used with the most perceptive comments to produce a tight and action-packed program. The bowling movement was delighted because the program excited interest and increased membership of younger people. There was an effective promotion of the game of lawn bowls and a greater appreciation and understanding of it. We can appreciate why the bowling movement was so pleased with the television production.

In 1986 a decision was made to move the event to Adelaide at the height of South Australia's 150th anniversary celebrations. Bowling fans from New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland travelled to Adelaide, particularly in 1987 when the Lockley's Bowling Club was the venue. For 1988, our bicentennial year, Sydney was chosen as the venue and the West Epping Bowling Club was chosen to host this unique event. The West Epping Bowling Club has engaged itself with great enthusiasm in organising and promoting the best Mazda Jack High event to mark Australia's Bicentenary. The ABC, having televised this yearly event, was also involved in the organisation of it. Interestingly, over 60 clubs in New South Wales applied to hold the competition. In that competition, West Epping was victorious.

Provision was made at West Epping for access for television cameras and parking, as well as an attractive landscape to provide a most pleasant backdrop for the presentation on television. The local council-Hornsby Shire-the Royal New South Wales Bowling Association and the Australian Bowls Council were all involved and committed themselves at considerable cost, in terms of staff, their time and organisational skills, to ensure that the proposal was accepted. Information about the event was circulated widely and it promoted the ABC. In March, at the presentation dinner at the Lockley's Bowling Club in Adelaide, the ABC's Federal Director of Sport, Mr Kevin Berry, announced that Michael Shrimpton, Controller of Programs Nationally, had confirmed the timeslot for Jack High as a Bicentenary event.

On 8 May at the West Epping Bowling Club, Al Mewett, an Executive Officer of the ABC, David Zweck, producer, and Peter Knevett, Executive Technical Producer, attended a meeting with representatives of the West Epping Bowling Club and the Royal New South Wales Bowling Association, as well as the national organisers. I would like simply to let the minutes of that occasion speak for themselves, and I quote:

Len Bainbridge welcomed all parties and elaborated on philosophy of Jack High. It has to look right for television; it is a promotion of the sport. He explained that the meeting was convened so that all parties understood their responsibilities in accepting the event and hopefully within the next week a decision would be made on the venue. He explained that the meeting was convened so that all parties understood their responsibility in accepting the event and announced that next week a decision would be made. Dates advised were 14-20 March 1988. The ABC outlined their role in the event. $4m-worth of equipment was to be used. Seventeen edited programs would be produced. Move in on 12 March 1988 and rehearse on 13 March 1988. There would be a total of six cameras-four fixed-a cherry picker and a scissor lift and background music would be supplied for the lunch breaks.

All that demonstrates that the ABC was privy to the discussions which followed, including the direction and organisation of the event, catering, parking, ticket selling, crowd control, on-site promotion and program advertising, as well as the hiring of grandstands and the like. Now we are at the point of time six months down the track, and the ABC, having participated in all these discussions, having allowed the organisers to commit themselves to money, time and resources, has not just given notice that in future years the program would not proceed, but has said by letter dated 27 August: `As advised to the Australian Bowls Council Jack High, although successful, will not be telecast during 1988'-the bicentennial year.

I know the ABC has been concerned at its dismal performance in attracting television audiences for some of its other programs. I know that, notwithstanding my own avid watching of its excellent current affairs programs, its usually balanced news presentations, as well as its United Kingdom-produced comedy programs, the ABC nevertheless seems to be beset with declining audiences and the new desire on the part of its management to radically restructure its programming. Obviously Jack High has got caught up in this new hype. Rumours suggest that even at the highest levels comments were made that this `weirdo sport' could be easily sacrificed.

I am astounded at this reasoning, Mr Deputy Speaker. Bowls has the support of some 550,000 participants throughout Australia. It caters for both men and women. On a non-racial basis, black or white, it provides support for the old and the young, the physically impaired and the able. Both as a social activity and as a competitive sport, it provides enormous enjoyment and satisfaction to a large number of Australians. I am amazed that the ABC should not only consider jettisoning this program but that it could also do so in such a shabby and commercially immoral way.

Whilst a formal agreement for five years telecasting existed, with an option for year by year telecasting thereafter, surely it was not too much to expect that at least one year's notice would be given of the desire on the part of the ABC to withdraw from this arrangement. Surely it is not too much to expect from a publicly funded, responsible statutory authority, that ordinary Australians-your constituents, Mr Deputy Speaker, my constituents, other members' constituents and in this case, constituents at West Epping-should be reasonably dealt with. It is preposterous that the Shire of Hornsby, the Australian Bowls Council, the Royal New South Wales Bowling Association, Mazda as sponsors and West Epping Bowling Club in particular should have been encouraged and allowed to commit themselves to this new program and to have undertaken six months work, to have entered into contracts, to have publicly promoted a major sporting function, and to have the whole rationale stripped away without apology and explanation.

I would implore the ABC at this late stage to consider again this decision at the earliest opportunity. It should not be difficult to redress the matter, to restore the ABC's reputation and to garner again the support of Australian bowlers. Should this not occur I would have to say that bowlers throughout Australia will mobilise. The ABC's reputation will be in tatters throughout the bowling clubs of Australia, and I am sure their members will want all members of Parliament in every electorate to make the same protest that I am making in this grievance debate today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I would like what I have to say to be given some consideration. I will start by saying that Nancy and I grieve today for the future of our great country. The Hawke Government has been a good government and it certainly came to power when the ship of state was without a helmsman and the captain and crew had shown themselves to be as incompetent a bunch of lily-livered landlubbers as you could ever find. Hauling the ship off the rocks, however, is only the first part of the job. Pumping the bilges, trimming the sails and setting them for new horizons and the promised land where prosperity, equity, dignity, compassion, optimism, good humour and confidence abound is the main task. The voyage to this new Australia is no journey for the faint-hearted, for it means avoiding the shoals of prejudice and preconceived ideas and not running easily before the winds of comfortable convention that often blow with gale force from the lush and mystical lands of myth and shibboleth, or being carried in the dangerous currents that blow from the isles of comfort and boredom.

SPEECH.PARA: I have alluded to the dangerous myth of multiculturalism that is foisted upon us with fascist ferocity. I have spoken at length about the dichotomy that is developing between rural and urban Australia and which, if left to go unchecked, will divide and destroy this nation. But today I want to talk about trade. Unless Australia can recover its reputation as a bold, innovative fair trader, the vision of the Australia we all want will forever elude us. There is a danger that we are allowing the government of this country to be taken over by pressure groups. I know the enormous forces these people can exert. I believe some of them are not motivated by self-interest and some of them may even be right, but they should all be exposed to the clearing winds of the common good and irradiated by the clearing sunlight of rational argument.

If they are allowed to go unchecked and get their grasping hands on the public purse, there is no long term hope for democracy, for nowhere in history has democracy failed in the long run against falling real living standards and inequality in the burden that is imposed by falling real wealth. This is something that those people who enthusiastically embrace trade sanctions against South Africa would do well to realise. I believe, and I speak with all the evidence of Hansard, that a few cliches are the salt and pepper of a good speech. If trade goods do not cross borders, armies will, is as hackneyed a saying as any, but it is no less true for that.

We live in a shrinking world of which our nation is part and in which no nation is an island entire of itself. We have an obligation to ourselves and an obligation to this entire planet. There is growing concern about the real problems of the free chlorine radicals attacking the ozone layer and the growing evidence of dangers of the glasshouse effect caused by increasing carbon dioxide and other agents, principally from the burning of hydrocarbon fuels.

It is in that regard that I raise the enormous trade potential of our uranium wealth and the obligation we have to store high level nuclear waste in Australia. We have in synroc undoubtedly the best technology for safely encasing nuclear waste, and I acknowledge the great service to mankind that Professor Ted Ringwood and his team at the Australian National University have done, and the vital role being played by the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) at Lucas Heights in developing this technology. What synroc does is to lock up in the synthetic rock, high level nuclear waste so that it cannot escape into the environment. In this regard it is as least one thousand times more leakproof than borosilicate glass, developed by the French and currently in use. Professor Ringwood suggests that after encapsulating the ceramic material it is encased in stainless steel cylinders and lowered into the bore holes that have been drilled 4 kilometres into the ground. Mr Deputy Speaker, that is a very common technology in Australia today and one in which we probably excel.

Honourable members will all know that Australia has the most arcane and stable rock formations in the world. It is in these solid granite or gabro belts where water seldom occurs and in any case is never found below a thousand metres that we should be looking for safe storage. When a cylinder of synroc is lowered into the hole it is surrounded by a high yielding benetonite clay. This material expands to twice its volume when it becomes wet and therefore acts as an extremely good sealing agent. The bore hole is then filled for a thousand metres with this material, then another capsule is added, and so on, until the hole is filled within one kilometre of the surface. The hole can then be filled with crushed and compacted sedimentary rock and the nearest anyone can get to this material is one kilometre. It is forever trapped in the most stable geological strata in the world, a geological strata that would look upon a million years as a mere flicker of an eyelid.

Mr Deputy Speaker, to fulfil our obligations to the world, if only to the extent of taking back the waste generated by the uranium we sell, we would need a capital expenditure of about $9 billion. This could be easily provided by equity capital inflow from overseas. Countries like Japan, United Kingdom and others, have enormous need for the service that we can provide. The capital inflow would be used mainly for steel and concrete construction, technologies in which Australia is as good as any country in the world. It would create an enormous number of jobs in Australia in the construction and would provide for us an annual export income of close of $3 billion. This is only if we sell uranium at our current rate and take back the equivalent amount of waste from that uranium. If we were to offer this service to the world, undoubtedly we would increase our sales of uranium and consequently our export earnings would rise dramatically.

This is a technology, I believe, that Australia for its own trade performance, for the future of our children, should grasp with both hands. It is an obligation that we owe the world. It is absurd for anyone to suggest that it is better, or more fitting, or more proper, for the Japanese to store nuclear waste in their fragile island, continually shaken by earthquakes. That material is far safer handled in Australia and I believe that we have an obligation to realise this truth.

It is an emotional subject and is unfortunate that we do not give enough attention to the realities. Every member of this House will know, and I am sure every member of this House does know, that every day throughout the world, coal-fired power stations pump into the atmosphere radiation in the form of polonium 210, lead 210, radium 226, thorium 230, thorium 232, radium 224 and radium 228, often in excess of the radioactivity allowed from nuclear power stations. All those products are by-products of the breakdown chain of uranium-thorium. That is the sort of stuff that every member of this House would know, but is often not realised by people outside. In addition, the fly ash residue from coal stations contains florium and uranium decay products that are three to seven times as radioactive as the emission that would be allowed from a nuclear power station.

No attempt is made to control how this material is disposed of. We could ask `how it is disposed of', whether it is disposed of by making cement, or used as land fill, in roads, in a filler as plastic from which are made lightweight cups, saucers and plates from which we eat, and many other things. The reality is, of course, that while this radioactive emission is greater than that allowed from nuclear power stations, it is in fact minimal. It is insignificant compared with the background radiation that we are all subjected to. When people can grasp this simple fact, I think we can start to get into perspective the whole uranium debate. We have this obligation to the world. I believe that we must reassess our position and we must confidently go forward using expertise developed by Australians, expertise in which we are world leaders, to provide for the world this service, and provide for ourselves economic salvation.

It is not just in this area that we should be looking. The enormously good work being done by ANSTO at Lucas Heights illustrates the advances that Australia is making in nuclear medicine. There are some real Australian initiatives that will provide some of the greatest cures for cancer in the future. I find it rather amusing when looking at Chernobyl. We must realise that this was the accident that all the environmentalists were waiting for, indeed, hoping for. The reality is that the problems have been exaggerated. It was an enormously difficult thing; it was a very bad thing; it was an incompetent thing, and that, I think has now been recognised by the Russians. But the results have been accurately predicted and they will be contained. As a result of Chernobyl, Sweden, for instance, says that it will statistically suffer eight more deaths. In that time, of course, countless thousands of people will be saved by the actions of nuclear medicine.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this is what has to be kept in perspective. I find it somewhat sickening that the United Kingdom is currently involved in expenditure of something like close to $300m to save what is statistically set at three lives. This seems to me to be a gross waste and a gross travesty.
