SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this grievance debate to make an appeal to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) on behalf of one of my constituents, Mr John Furness of Bowraville. Mr Furness, Mr Deputy Speaker, is dying of cancer. I wrote to the Minister early last week-and as yet I have not even had an acknowledgment-in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware of the demands on your time and that in the normal course of events individual representations would not be brought to your personal attention. However this is an exceptional case in that Mr Furness has been diagnosed as having terminal cancer.

Therefore, I respectfully seek your assistance in obtaining the Government's approval for Mr Furness to import 80, 30-gram I.V. ampoules of B17 Laetrile and 600, 500-mg oral tablets of B17 Laetrile in an endeavour to suppress the disease and thereby prolong his chances for life.
I would be grateful if this matter could be given consideration, keeping in mind that time is of the essence in this particular case . . .
I repeat that I know the demands on all Ministers, but I had hoped that I would have at least received an acknowledgment before this. In a letter to me dated 14 October, Mr Furness wrote:

Thank you for your telephone calls and advice regarding our request to import laetrile. I am enclosing copies of letters from myself to the Department of Health (requesting the permit to import laetrile) and their reply to this. Also a copy of my proposed letter to the Department of Health in reply to their non-approval of laetrile import permit.
Mr Furness continued:

I am quite desperate to try the laetrile treatment, as I have read many books on the various types of cancer treatment available around the world, and am quite fully convinced that a strict diet therapy with extra vitamins, minerals and enzymes and the added help of laetrile will give me a much better quality of life than the orthodox methods of cancer treatment such as radiation and chemotherapy.
I might say, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I do not raise this matter solely on behalf of Mr Furness, but on behalf of the many other Australians who are suffering from cancer. Mr Furness continued:

I have seen so many patients who have had chemotherapy treatment and their quality of life is just so bad that I really could not face it. The absolute agony they had to endure is quite unbearable and yet this, plus radiation (which has similar effects) is the only orthodox method of treating this fast spreading disease which is taking over our world. One in five persons will contract cancer! That is a phenomenal rate of progress for a disease that has not had any worthwhile breakthroughs in the last few years.

Surely a person has the right to try to use a substance which they feel will be of assistance to them in overcoming this disease, or at least bearing the pain related to it. Orthodox methods cannot give any guarantees of success, so why should a person be stopped from wanting to do his very best to improve his health and quality of life!
Mr Furness went on:

It would seem to me that the government has decided it alone has the right to decide a person's method of treatment of cancer. That fact makes me so very angry. What are they afraid of when they won't give me a permit to import this substance so that at least I can try to help myself?

All I am asking for is a permit. I don't want the government to pay for the substance, I am not asking for any financial assistance from them in any way, I just want the opportunity to try this for my own satisfaction-after all; it is my life, and the alternatives offer no guarantees.
I do trust you can see this from my point of view Mr Nehl, as you put my case to the powers that be.
I can assure Mr Furness that I do. He said:
I have tried to look at it from the government's point of view and can see no reason why they can't let me try it! I'm not hurting them or anyone else-just want the opportunity at life!
Of prime importance however, is the time factor as I do not have a lot of time left to try and help myself.
Trusting you can be of assistance to me in putting my case to the appropriate bodies, and praying for your success.

I am also praying for my success and I hope by my speaking in this debate the Minister might be able to assist. Mr P. Bohun, on behalf of the Assistant Secretary, Drug Evaluation Branch, wrote to Mr Furness on 8 October and said:
I refer to your letter of 24 September concerning the proposed importation of Laetrile (amygdalin) for your personal use.
Laetrile does not have approval for general marketing in Australia.
He does not want to market it; he just wants to cure himself. The letter continued:

The Australian Drug Evaluation Committee and its Anti-cancer Subcommittee have recently again reviewed the status of Laetrile. The conclusions from this review only strengthen their previous advice that importation of Laetrile for the treatment of cancer should not be permitted because of the demonstrated lack of effectiveness, definite serious toxicity and absence of knowledge of metabolism, excretion and serum levels. The Australian Drug Evaluation Committee is an independent body of clinical pharmacological experts which advises the Minister of Health on the availability of therapeutic substances in Australia.
The Department has accepted the Committee's recommendation concerning Laetrile. I therefore cannot recommend that approval be issued to you for the importation of Laetrile.
I would just like to go on a little further. Mr Furness wrote back to Mr Bohun on 14 October and said:
I would like to thank you for your early attention to the important matter of my proposal to import Laetrile (Amygdalin).
I would like to point out that the Laetrile is for my personal use only, not for general marketing in Australia.
This poor man is dying from cancer. He believes there is a substance which might help him and we are not prepared to let him try it out. He said:

The Australian Drug Evaluation Committee should get their facts straight about what is available for the `cure' of cancer. There are only two orthodox types of treatment for this terrible disease, and they are Radiation and Chemotherapy, and neither of these methods can guarantee a cure! They may put the disease into remission for a brief time, then the cancer rears its ugly head again in another form or place.

Chemotherapy would have to be the worst treatment to give a human being. The success rate is minimal, not to mention what the patient has to go through with this type of treatment. Definite life-time serious toxicity on the whole body-not just the affected part. The type I would be administered would have the substance made from mustard gas, would you believe!
I have had the orthodox methods of cancer treatment, so I am well aware of what is available in treatment of this disease.
It is my life, my body, and I am the only person that has to answer for the type of treatment I choose.
Mr Deputy Speaker, he is so right. He continued:

If there is anyone on the Drug Evaluation Committee who can guarantee me a cure, then I will be delighted to hear from them! If not, then they don't have the right to dictate to anyone else who wants to try something alternative that might be of help.

Laetrile just might be the answer to my problem, so why don't I have the right to try it-and maybe live a reasonable lifespan. I don't think any human being, group of so-called experts, or government, have the right to deny me this request.
Time is of prime importance-I don't have much time to play with in terms of expectancy.
Trusting you can be of some assistance to me and looking forward to your reply.

I feel quite moved having read that correspondence, because I can understand what Mr Furness is feeling. I can also understand what thousands of others of our fellow Australians are suffering. As I said when I began my speech, I just want to take this opportunity to try to highlight the need for something to happen. Perhaps if some of the Minister's staff are listening-and I will certainly send them a copy of the Hansard report of what I said-they might be able to take some quick action because for Mr Furness, as for so many other Australians suffering from cancer, time is short, time is of the essence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to discuss the report of the Advisory Committee on Trade and National Economic Management to the Constitutional Commission. I do so against a background in which the necessity for the Australian Government to have appropriate powers to allow it to respond to the international economic circumstances in which we find ourselves should be more self-evident than ever before. In this regard, the broad thrust of the Advisory Committee's report should be very much welcomed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Advisory Committee proposes that, rather than power in relation to the national economy being shared between the States and the Commonwealth, on the evidence presented to it `it is essential, from an economic and business perspective to treat the Australian economy as one nation existing as a federal parliamentary democracy within a global framework'. It went on to say:
The nation is subject to the economic vicissitudes of the framework, to which it is inseparably linked.

Of course, recent events bring that fact remarkably clearly home. Accordingly, the Advisory Committee recommended that the Constitution be amended to confer on the Federal Parliament authority over the national economy by inserting a new provision, a section 51 (ia), expressed as `matters affecting the national economy'. That is a priority with which I fully concur and one with which I believe that most members of this Parliament would also agree.

There is, however, a deficiency that exists at present in the Constitution on which the Committee was less able to form a substantive recommendation, and I refer to the provisions of section 92 of the Constitution. Section 92 represents an area of great uncertainty in a difficult document that already benefits lawyers substantially. In relation to this matter of uncertainty, let me refer to a recent judgment of Mr Justice Deane which is contained in the Advisory Committee's report. Mr Justice Deane, in his judgment in Miller v. TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (1986) 67 Australian Law Reports 321, at page 362, said this about section 92:

This is another case about the operation and effect of s. 92 of the Constitution. Both sides argued with apparent conviction on the basis of existing authority to support diametrically opposed conclusions. Perhaps that should not be seen as surprising since the more one becomes immersed in the decisions of the Privy Council and this court on the subject of s. 92, the plainer the impression becomes that one has entered an area where the ordinary processes of legal reasoning have had but a small part to play and where judicial exegesis has tended to confuse rather than elucidate. Indeed, it is as if the many voices of authority have been speaking differently at the same time with the result that, putting to one side some basic propositions, it is all but impossible to comprehend precisely what it is that authority has said.

This confusion would matter very little if the subject of section 92 had no impact on Australia's economic management. But section 92 is a provision that directly impacts on the capacity of the Australian Government to regulate the national economy. As Professor Colin Howard has observed, it is little if anything more than an impediment to the effective ordering of the economy on a nationwide scale. This is quite different to what section 92 was intended to be.

The framers of the Constitution inserted section 92 to prevent different States erecting discriminatory tariff barriers between themselves. The prime concern of the framers of the Constitution was to prohibit border tariffs. Section 92 provides that trade, commerce and intercourse amongst the States shall be absolutely free. Unfortunately, the court never accepted from the outset that only border tariffs were to be prohibited by section 92. The courts have engaged in an almost theological debate about what the provision must mean if it does not mean what it says. From the outset it has been accepted that `absolutely free' could not mean `absolutely free' for otherwise, for example, it would authorise the transfer of drugs or prostitutes across State boundaries without any impediment.

So the Court, in trying to frame a response to such difficulties, has been caught in a conundrum which is perhaps well illustrated in the language of Mr Justice Murphy in his landmark decision in Buck and Bovone. At page 135 of the [1976] 135 Commonwealth Law Reports 101, he said:

The consequences of giving full expression to the words `absolutely free' used in a wide sense not restricted to fiscal imposts are so intolerable that a doctrine has arisen by which the words `absolutely free' have been converted to `relatively free', that is, `subject to permissible regulation' on grounds such as health and safety.
And he continues-

Such a meaning can not be given to `absolutely free'. Under the doctrine of permissible `regulatory laws', laws on interstate trade and commerce may be regarded as regulatory, and therefore permissible, if they conform to certain tests. The tests are so obscure that (like the prophecies of the Oracle at Delphi) they can generally be shown to agree with any outcome.

The problem that this imposes for effective national regulation of the economy is that it prevents governments planning effectively because they must deal with an area of law in respect of which even those who work in the jurisdiction are unable to predict the outcome with any confidence. That situation plainly is unsatisfactory if one wishes to give, as the Committee obviously wishes to give, priority in the ordering of the national economy to the National Parliament. Unfortunately, the Committee itself has been unable to make a firm recommendation in relation to section 92.

The Chairman of the Committee, Mr Justice Everett, and Professor Coper recognise and accept that section 92 must be redrafted. They argue, as I do, that section 92 should be limited to its original purpose-that is, preventing States imposing tariff barriers-and that section 92 must therefore be confined to laws which discriminate against interstate trade. That is very important because at present many national economic initiatives may be struck down under section 92. That is a matter of concern because such initiatives can include very important national marketing schemes. Recently, a great deal of concern was expressed by those involved in the milk industry about the failure of governments to erect a suitable milk marketing scheme. Whilst there are very important schemes in existence at the moment which relate to industries such as the wheat industry-which benefits my State of Tasmania-the existence of section 92 is poised always as a prospective sword to strike down such arrangements. Such an impediment to proper economic management is something that really should be eliminated from the Constitution.

The Constitutional Commission now has an historic opportunity to give to the national Parliament powers which it ought properly have to enable it to respond to its proper national role. I would strongly urge the Commission, in its review of the Advisory Committee's report, to accept the views put forward by the Chairman and by Professor Coper and to follow what was the original intention of the framers of the Constitution, a view which efforts have been made to readopt and which has been brought into focus again by the judgments of Mr Justice Murphy, but which to this present date is surrounded by a mass of confusion which is only to the benefit of lawyers. It is a submission that I hope finds favour with the Constitutional Commission so that when it reports by 30 June next year, this impediment to national planning can be removed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the July 1987 Federal election, the electorate of Casey was one of the eight marginal seats targeted by the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Wilderness Society in their so-called `Vote for the Forests' campaign. At a public meeting organised by these two major lobby groups as part of their campaign tactics in Casey, I made several comments and observations based on specific and sincere concerns that I would like to reiterate in the grievance debate today.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe one of the most significant threats to both the short and long term protection and preservation of our fragile environment and irreplaceable natural heritage is that, unfortunately, some once reputable conservation and environment groups have been infiltrated-in some cases completely taken over-by activists and radicals who are motivated by political opportunism and party political loyalties rather than genuine care or concern for the issues and causes they espouse. Many of these groups were originally, and still claim to be, non-party political, but in reality they are now being used and manipulated by people who are prepared to sacrifice principles for political expediency. Claims by these irresponsible and very vocal elements that Liberals are unconcerned about environment and conservation issues are intentionally misleading, totally dishonest and demonstrably false.

The facts are that Liberal governments have an excellent record in regard to conservation and protection of Australia's environment. That record includes: the proclamation of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park; the prohibition of sand mining exports from Fraser Island; the establishment of the Frost Inquiry into Whales and Whaling, leading to a ban on commercial whaling in Australia; the enactment of the Whale Protection Act and the active participation of Australia in the work of the International Whaling Commission; the proclamation of Kakadu and Uluru national parks; the observation of the environmental recommendations of the Ranger inquiry; the signing of the Convention for the Protection of Antarctic Marine Living Resources; the development, and formal adoption, of the national conservation strategy for Australia and the adoption of the strategy by the Liberal Party of Australia, the first political party to do so; the enactment of major pieces of environmental legislation such as the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982, the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981, the Environment (Financial Assistance) Act 1977, the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act 1978 and the States Grants (Air Quality Monitoring) Act 1976; the decision to introduce unleaded petrol; the provision of grants for voluntary conservation groups such as the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, the World Wildlife Fund and the Australian Conservation Foundation; the establishment of the national tree program as part of the `Greening Australia' and bicentennial program; signing the World Heritage Convention; the nomination of the Great Barrier Reef and South West Tasmania for inclusion on the register; support for the recommendations of the Hope National Estate Committee of Inquiry; and action in support of the Australian Heritage Commission.

The Liberal Party has, by any yardstick, a more than adequate, in fact, an excellent record in regard to seeking and promoting acceptable, realistic and responsible solutions to the important environment and conservation issues and challenges that have confronted us in the past. We will continue our proven commitment to the conservation of the environment and preservation and protection of our natural heritage in the future.

It is, however, impossible to achieve positive and constructive government policies and community attitudes towards our environmental and conservation responsibilities by adopting divisive, confrontationist tactics. The not inconsiderable amount of money spent on party political electioneering by the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) and the Wilderness Society in the eight targeted marginal seats during the last Federal election would have been better directed towards an Australia-wide community awareness campaign, designed to encourage citizens of all political persuasions to contact their local members of parliament and aspiring candidates, irrespective of the party they represented, to impress upon them the concerns of the community about environment and natural heritage issues. By concentrating their efforts and resources on a spurious and misleading campaign in just eight marginal electorates, and overtly pursuing a pro-Labor, pro-Australian Democrat, anti-Liberal, anti-National Party line, the ACF and the Wilderness Society not only lost their credibility as non-party political organisations, but also lost an excellent opportunity to have presented a fair, factual and unbiased case to the electorate as a whole.

Along the way they also succeeded in alienating many of their most ardent, active and sincerely concerned advocates, who also happen to vote Liberal. There are hundreds of thousands of people who have no difficulty whatsoever in equating their conservative and free enterprise political philosophies and allegiances with their commitment to, interest in, and concern and support for, conservation and environment issues. Those who are genuinely concerned about protecting and preserving our natural heritage-and I have no hesitation in including myself in this category-appreciate that the successful achievement of our objectives does not depend on the attitudes of one or two political parties but on all political parties; not on the policies of one government or one level of government, but on all governments at all levels; not on pursuing a partisan but pursuing a bipartisan approach.

In short, we will not achieve our aims by confrontation but by co-operation. We may choose to close our minds to the opinions, the needs and the solutions proposed by others, but in doing so, we limit our ability to appraise objectively specific problems and issues as they arise. If past experience is any guide, we may also close off options which could potentially provide the basis for negotiating reasonable and acceptable alternative answers to difficult challenges.

I would like to offer some constructive advice to the organisers of the politically biased, ill-founded and consequently unsuccessful ACF-Wilderness Society-sponsored, anti-Liberal crusade in Casey: There were many people who, because of their sincere and genuine concerns about conservation and environment issues were initially responsive to your campaign. They believed it to be legitimate but soon discovered that they were being misled. They were less than impressed to find you were prepared to use them as pawns in your party-politically-motivated activities. You have deceived and disappointed people who are loyal to the cause you claim to represent, and as a result have lost, rather than encouraged, their sympathy and support. Antagonism is not a recognised method of winning friends and influencing people. By involving yourselves, and more importantly, your organisation, in party politics you lessen-not widen-your support base. To increase it, you must concentrate on being non-party political, as alignment with one end of the political spectrum can very often and very easily result in alienation of the other. Your political impartiality must not only be a matter of fact, it must be seen to be a matter of fact.

Finally, instead of pretending that there are only black and white-or in this case perhaps only green-answers to the questions regarding protection and preservation of our environment and the sensible management of our natural resources, be prepared to listen to and investigate the claims and opinions of others. They, too, have their story. It is by seeking and finding the common ground that we will successfully guarantee the long-term security and, therefore, the survival, of our fragile and vulnerable environment and our unique and irreplaceable natural heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this grievance debate I wish to raise an issue which I consider to be one which should be of concern to this country. We are part of South East Asia and we cannot afford to ignore signs of trouble in that region. I wish to focus on the internal problems of Burma and the effect those problems have on the refugee or displaced persons' problems in the world, and in particular, Thailand.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently, in an address to the 78th Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference held in Bangkok, I made reference to one of the lesser-known minorities who are living in camps in Thailand. These are the Karens who have fled from Burma as a result of military operations against them from Burmese forces in a war which has been raging since 1949. In my address I pointed out that the Karen minority in Burma are being persecuted simply because of their nationality and that the numbers arriving in Thailand have greatly increased in the past two years. This is causing overcrowding in the camps located close to the Thai-Burma border. The Karens are of Mongolian descent and were the first settlers in Burma some 2700 years ago. Later the Burmese came and conquered the country, stripping the Karens of their land, depriving them of their culture and forcing them to flee to the mountains and the jungles.

During the Second World War the Japanese took over, with the support of the Burma Independent Army. It should be noted that the Karens fought on the side of the Allies and some 2000 troops were evacuated to India with the British troops. As a result, many Karens left in Burma were arrested, tortured, raped and killed by the Burma Independent Army and the Japanese. After the war the Karens requested the British and Burmese governments to allow an independent state for the Karens to exist. This was refused and since January 1949 there has been a constant struggle between the Burmese military forces and the Karens organised in their National Liberation Army.

The Karens have formed their own state, called Kawthoolei, which lies in south-east Burma, straddling the border with Thailand, but this state is not recognised in the international scene. The Karens are, despite their history of struggle, a peaceful race and a minority are very strong and committed Christians. They do not want to take over Burma, but they do want a form of federalism in Burma in which the different ethnic races manage their own internal affairs. There has been, since 1949, this struggle on their part to maintain their independence. These ethnic minorities, besides the Karens, include the Arakanese, the Chin, the Kachin, the Karenni, the Shan, the Labu, the Uon, the Pa-o, the Palaung and the Wa. They have combined in forming what is now called the National Democratic Front (NDF). The main goal of the NDF is the creation of a genuine federal union with a full guarantee of liberty, equality and social justice to all the ethnic races and individuals in Burma.

Recently, I was able to meet representatives of the NDF and have a frank and full discussion with them on the issues involved. It was clear, from my discussions with them, that the people of Burma are weary of the civil war in their country. The NDF believes that since the civil war came into existence, due to political problems there is no way of solving it but by political means.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

TALKER.NAME: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret to inform the House that the Prime Minister is still unwell and will not be here during Question Time today. As a courtesy, I inform the House that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mr John Brown, will be absent from Question Time today for personal reasons. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, will answer questions normally addressed to Mr Brown.

—I refer the Treasurer to reports in the Press that foreign institutions are moving out of Australian dollar investments into `quality investments' overseas. Noting this, can the Treasurer indicate to the House why the Australian dollar has fallen against both the United States dollar and other major currencies in recent days?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House will be aware of the general exchange rate volatility overnight, when the volatility we have seen in the stock market moved into the foreign exchange market. In the belief that the basic tenets of the Louvre Agreement are at least ineffective, the markets have run past the policy makers and sought to take adjustments in the areas in which imbalances exist in the world. We have seen overnight the United States dollar fall further against the yen and the Deutsche mark, the European currencies depreciate against the mark, and the Australian dollar depreciate against the United States dollar. If one were to try to find some rhyme or reason for all this, I suppose one would argue that the markets believe that the United States current account will not adjust or they are trying to adjust around the intransigence on domestic policy changes so as to adjust the imbalance in their trade deficit. The depreciation of the European currencies against the mark is to try to repair the surplus that Germany enjoys against the other European countries. Australia is a commodity producer and we have a balance of trade deficit and a current account deficit. Of course, we will not improve our competitiveness unless there is a depreciation of the rate.

ANSWER.PARA: More importantly, the general volatility we are seeing in the shake-out is because so many of the supposed objectives of the G5 are not being met and the markets are less than convinced that they will be met. This, of course, is a fall-out from the sort of success of the Plaza Hotel meeting a couple of years ago. Policy makers thought that all they needed to do was to sit together, have a cup of tea and a scone, decide what the exchange rates ought to be and all the world's economic troubles would be over. This Government never thought that that was the right solution. It thought that the way to address the imbalance was to address the underlying policy problems. Maybe now some of those problems will be addressed in light of this volatility in exchange markets and the stock market.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations: In view of the wide interest in the resumed national wage case and in view of the speculation about the Commonwealth Government's position concerning it, could he advise the House what position was adopted by the Commonwealth Government in the resumed national wage case this morning?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. As the honourable member said, the Government's substantial submission on the national wage case has commenced today, following the conclusion of the opening submission of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The Government has given support for a $6.50 increase from 1 January. Let me explain to the House that the $6.50 figure represents 1 1/2 per cent of the latest figure for average weekly ordinary time earnings for adults. We can only get to $7 by taking 1 1/2 per cent of full average weekly earnings, including overtime, and we do not think that that is appropriate. In our view, the flat rate version of 1 1/2 per cent is $6.50.

ANSWER.PARA: We think that the 1 January start date is consistent with the position that we put in the national wage case earlier this year. It represents a variation from the Budget assumption, which, following the national wage decision to allow a second first tier increase claim by October, provided for a 1 1/2 per cent rise in mid-November. So that 1 January start date will mean a lesser wage outcome for the year as a whole than was forecast in the Budget. In light of recent events, the Government believes that it is even more important that its previously stated position as to date of operation, that is, 1 January, for this increase by adopted by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

I will briefly explain why we support an increase of this nature at this time. Firstly, our assessment is that, as the Treasurer has said, although, because of recent events, there is more risk associated with economic projections, current prospects for the Australian economy are not substantially changed from the assessment in the Budget Papers. Secondly, it must be recalled that second tier increases are coming through very slowly. Honourable members may be unaware of the fact that, although the second tier increase came from a decision of the Commission in March, with the technical possibility of such increases being obtained from July, in fact, at this stage, some months after July, only 11 per cent of the work force has so far received a second tier increase. Our assessment is that by 1 January only about 25 per cent of wage and salary earners will have a second tier increase. Thus, by the time from which we say this decision should apply, most workers will have had only the $10 increase, which came in March, since the previous increase which was in mid-1986. So, not to pay a wage rise now would mean a further fall in living standards that have already clearly been reduced by the wages policy pursued in that period.

Thirdly, there is a clear need for balance between the need for wage moderation in our present economic circumstances, the need for a viable wages policy and the need for a fair income distribution. The balanced approach has been very much part of what this Government has pursued. It contrasts markedly with the approach of the Opposition which, of course, has always talked about the need to act tough, to pursue draconian wages policies, but, in government, of course, always produced most inappropriate outcomes which culminated of course in the spectacular failure of its wages policy in its final years in Government. The House may be interested to recall that in 1982, at a time when our major trading partners had an average wage increase of 6 per cent, the Fraser Government produced a wages outcome of 16 per cent-a massive 10 per cent more than that of our major trading partners. Quite clearly, the kind of wages policy produced by people who talked tough, but acted in a way which brought about disastrous wages policies, is not the kind of advice that we want to listen to. We are pursuing a policy which is a balanced and appropriate one for the economy at this stage. We hope that the Commission will give effect to our submission.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. How much further will our stock market have to fall, and how much further will our dollar have to fall, before the Treasurer will abandon his irresponsible support for the Australian Council of Trade Union's push for another wage increase?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member was one of the people who were around during the last big wage explosion, I would have thought that a little bit of modesty and humility at this time would have been a more appropriate pose for him than an aggressive question. Let me just make the point that the Government, over a period since 1983, has introduced a wages framework which has allowed Australia to adjust and maintain its competitiveness. It is the ongoing wages system and compliance with an effectiveness of that system which will continue to be one of the important agents of adjustment in the economy.

ANSWER.PARA: My colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations has just given details of current support by the Commonwealth for the 1 1/2 per cent increase. Even with the 1 1/2 per cent increase, I expect that we will do better this year on wages than the Budget forecasts; that is, we will do better than 6 1/2 per cent. On real unit labour costs, we will still see a decline of about one per cent in 1987-88 compared with half a per cent last year. It seems to me that the effectiveness of the system over time is of more fundamental importance than the attitude we may take to one case.
There is an interesting quote by the honourable member for Wentworth in an article which he wrote with Professor Nevile on monetary and fiscal policy in Australia. The article said:

The policy conclusion is clear. Limit the rise in wage rates as much as possible. This does not mean striving for zero wage increases for a prolonged period. If too ambitious a program of wage restraint is pursued, it will break down and probably be followed by a wage explosion-
how true, how true-
which will increase inflation and unemployment. The appropriate policy is not to strive for the impossible but to see that genuine wage restraint is achieved.
All I can say, dear boy, is that they were more opposite remarks then than the ones made in the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade Negotiations. Against the background of the Minister's recent discussions in the Americas, Europe and Association of South East Asian countries, what further action can Australia take to ensure that fairness is restored into the world agricultural trade scene?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for McMillan for his question, particularly having regard to his long interest in these matters and the fact that he led a delegation to the United States last year in relation to these issues.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has played a key role in trying to restore fairness in world agricultural trade. Last year, we succeeded in forming a coalition of fair traders in agriculture, which has become known as the Cairns group. This has become an effective third force in the international debate on trying to reduce agricultural subsidies and other unfair trade practices. The group has worked extremely hard preparing a proposal for world agricultural trade reform. That was the focus of recent discussions with Ministers in Canada, South America and Asia.

As honourable members will be aware, the Prime Minister announced the proposal of the Cairns group in Geneva last week. The essence of the proposal is to get fairness back into world trade in agricultural products. We have argued more strongly than has any previous Australian government that our farmers should be able to sell products on overseas markets at fair prices and without unfair competition. The Cairns group has succeeded in advancing this issue more than ever before. We will continue to work with other countries to ensure that the words of intent which have been achieved after protracted negotiations are carried into effect.

In addition, we have worked strongly to protect our farmers from specific unfair trading practices of other countries. The Minister for Primary Industries and Resources and I have just returned from discussions with the European Commission in Brussels. It was a pleasure to work in those discussions with a Minister who has worked as hard as he has for the farmers in this country. I well remember the time, probably 12 months ago, when our highly esteemed colleague the honourable member for Leichhardt described the Minister as the Bob Hawke of the bush. Having seen the Minister at work, I must say that that accolade is one which he justly deserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

—The Minister has just interrupted me. Administrative arrangements have not sunk through to me, obviously, as well as they should have. The Minister's portfolio is Primary Industries and Energy-not resources. I apologise.

ANSWER.PARA: In those discussions we argued about the effect of the European common agricultural policy, not only on Australia but also on the Europeans. It was the Hawke Labor Government which achieved the Europeans agreement not to dump subsidised beef on Australian markets in Asia. That is one of the concrete results which are worth real dollars to our farmers.

It was also during the period of the Hawke Government that our officials studied in detail and reported on the cost to the Europeans of their policies, how the policies affected their unemployment, taxed other industries and inflated the prices of food to their consumers. This has been a major factor in the pressure that is building up for reform of the common agricultural policy in Europe. Similarly, in the United States, we have taken every opportunity, through ministerial discussions and our Government's diplomats and officials, to minimise the effect of the now in place United States farm Bill and the impending United States trade Bill.

The efforts of the Government were summed up in a Sydney Morning Herald report last Saturday in which a spokesman for the National Farmers Federation described the 10-year trade reform program announced by our Prime Minister in Geneva, and for which this Government has worked so hard, as `simply fantastic'.
An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Deputy Prime Minister. Two days ago the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories referred, in answer to a question asked by the honourable member for Robertson, to a monorail at Ayers Rock. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: It has achieved a notable amount of support from the Aboriginal communities which have control of Uluru National Park.
Yesterday in a television interview the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs said:
My office contacted senior officials of the Committee last night. They knew nothing about it and they were upset.
Will the Deputy Prime Minister please inform the House who is telling the truth?

TALK.START.PARA: —The type of answer which might be expected was suggested in the question. In other words, there was certainly some discussion as to whether the proposal had the merits that were suggested by a number of people. I am aware that various views have been put which clearly indicate that it would be an issue that would cause some controversy. I am also aware that my colleague the Minister did have some information-whether it was accurate or not I do not know-that there would be some support for the project.
—Which Minister?

—The Minister who is not here today, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. This was because it was the subject of some discussion at our own party meeting. I do not know whether the information he received was valid and I do not know the detail of it. It was indicated that there was some support for the project on the basis that it would not be a monorail in the normal sense, but something that would have a lower aspect from the point of view of visual effrontery and that it would be an effective alternative to the existing road. It was explained that there were some difficulties about the road also because part of the area is Aboriginal land. I can well understand why all Ministers concerned who have the respective responsibilities would be getting different advice. The matter is contentious. It certainly has not been resolved and I await with interest the final outcome of the deliberations.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Consumer Affairs been drawn to the marketing activities of a company, Family Heritage Australia Pty Ltd, of 23 Marquet Street, Rhodes, New South Wales, which includes forwarding standard word processor letters addressed to consumers at random indicating that a first edition book is being published by the company specifically titled using the name of the consumer to whom the letter is addressed-for example, as appeared in a letter from the company received by me, the book was titled The Book of the Sciaccas in Australia? Further, does the Minister agree that such marketing practices are at best grossly misleading and at worst grossly deceptive? Will the Minister investigate the activities of Family Heritage Australia Pty Ltd and ensure, if possible, that appropriate action is taken to warn consumers so that they will not part with the $39.90 payable for the purchase price of the so-called first edition book?

—I raise a point of order, Madam speaker. I submit that the second part of the question which asks, `does the Minister agree', is clearly asking for an opinion, for a comment, and as such should be ruled out of order.
—The Minister will take note of the point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of Family Heritage Australia. As many honourable members in this House would know from letters they have received, it formerly operated as Halberts SA Family Heritage. Its product has been investigated over the years by the Trade Practices Commission and many other consumer affairs agencies in Australia. Many thousands of people have been approached by this organisation and it appears that the book it publishes offers no more than a general work on surnames and a brief family history. Much of that information, of course, would come from other publicly available sources.

ANSWER.PARA: The organisation has had quite a deal of adverse publicity in a number of States and has been subject to numerous warnings by State consumer affairs agencies. As a result, the promotional material that is being issued now has been substantially modified. That action was taken by the New South Wales Department of Consumer Affairs. Probably because of such action, I have been advised that there have been very few recent consumer complaints. The indications are that consumers are now more aware of the value that such publications contain. The best thing that can be done about such products is publicly to advise consumers to be aware of the nature of the product and to be selective in their purchases. I thank the honourable member for the opportunity to do this. The honourable member for Bowman brought quite a deal of colour to this House in his maiden speech. In view of his subsequent contributions, by the time he decides to leave the House, which certainly will not be decided by those honourable members opposite, a substantial book may be written about him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support aware that 400 additional tourist seats per week on international flights into Darwin are required now to meet the current tourist demand in northern Australia? Has the Minister been approached to approve additional flights by airlines other than by Qantas Airways Ltd for a short term period to take advantage of this significant jump in demand? If so, what has been his response? If not, in view of the vacillations on Qantas's rights by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, will he either resolve the matter in Australia's immediate interests or admit that the Minister has annexed the aviation section of the Department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do not know what the honourable member was endeavouring to get at by his last comment and I will ignore it. However, this particular matter has been of some concern to the Government for some time. Every year, particularly at this time of the year, there is an increase in the demand for capacity for international airline seats into this country. The reason for that is twofold: first, spring and summer, of course, are the principal seasons for tourism to this country and as a result there is always a seasonal increase in airline business. Secondly, at this time of year approaching the high season, there are peaks because some of the discount fares that have been on offer in the low season must be used by a certain date. The result inevitably is that there is more demand for seats for people to come into the country just before the high season starts. We are having some of those sorts of problems at the moment. However, there is a considerable increase, a leap, in demand this year. We all applaud that. It is very good to see the benefits that flow to Australia from tourism. There is no doubt that it is of assistance to our economy. Given that, the Government has sought to increase the number of seats available into Australia. Honourable members may have seen the references in the Press recently to the fact that Qantas is looking at leasing a 747B jumbo aircraft and a 767 aircraft for up to six months. Arrangements, I understand, are in train. Qantas has contacted another airline company in Europe. I understand that those arrangements are well advanced. The effect will be that Qantas will be able to provide a considerable increase in the number of seats available into Australia over the next six months or so.

ANSWER.PARA: Apart from that, negotiations are going on with a number of international airline companies in relation to the issue of increased capacity and additional flights by those companies into Australia, but as has always been the case in the past, under coalition governments and Labor governments, the bipartisan policy in this country is that Qantas should get approximately 50 per cent of the business. We are seeking reciprocal rights for Qantas in exchange for granting rights to other airlines to operate additional flights into Australia. I anticipate that some of these negotiations will come to fruition in the near future, and when those agreements have been reached obviously they will be made public.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Can the Minister advise the House of what the Government is doing to encourage participation by local government as a positive response to the World Heritage listing of the north Queensland wet tropics?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I would like to pay tribute to the honourable member and to other members from Queensland, particularly the honourable member for Leichhardt and the honourable member for Herbert, for their involvement in this most important undertaking. I am pleased to be able to inform the House that my Department is working very closely with the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and has prepared a draft regional plan for consultation with local government in the proposed World Heritage area. The plan identifies possible alternative employment-enterprise creation opportunities in that area.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Local Government, Senator Reynolds, discussed the draft plan with 13 of the 14 local councils affected at a meeting in Cairns on 6 October. Officers of my Department subsequently met with all local government representatives, regional organisations and Aboriginal communities in the proposed listing area. Information was obtained on possible future employment projects and development strategies for each local area in the short, medium and longer term. The input of local councils and other community groups, as well as the advice of other Commonwealth agencies, will be incorporated into a revised regional plan. The completed plan, which will form part of the Government's consideration of positive adjustments in the World Heritage listing area, will set out an integrated strategy for the region and will focus on immediate projects aimed at providing employment during the wet season, as a self-help strategy involving local government to facilitate medium to long term opportunities, and a series of sectorally based programs to assist in the adjustment process.

I also point out that whilst the Government has come in for much criticism in terms of the World Heritage listing of the area, a lot of exaggerated claims are being made by the Queensland Government about the impact of employment in this area. The Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator Richardson, has made it quite clear that the evidence now being brought forward does not support the Queensland Government's view that all the job losses that may occur in that area will occur specifically because of the area's listing. In fact, the document prepared by the timber industry in collaboration with the Queensland Department of Lands, Forestry, Mapping and Surveying predicted that even at the current production levels 515 jobs, or 54 per cent of the work force, would be lost from November 1984 employment levels. So the industry has been in rapid decline since 1984, according to documentation which has now been sought from the Queensland Government. However, I think that in each of the exercises in which this Government has been involved, whether it be the Franklin Dam or the listing now of this area in Queensland, it has done everything possible to seek the co-operation of State and local governments by bringing forth some very expert views from our Department as to what can be done by local government authorities and other groups in those areas to make sure that we can have a great deal of impact on what job losses may take place as a result of decisions taken by the Government. To the extent that we have sought the co-operation of local government and to the extent that our members, including, as I say, the honourable member for Leichhardt, the honourable member for Herbert and other honourable members from Queensland, have been involved, I am sure that we will meet with the success that we have met in other areas throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support. In respect of the heads of agreement for the proposed Christmas Island casino, will the Minister explain why annexure D strangely limits use of the aerodrome in its present form to only BAe146 aircraft when it is currently used by several other aircraft types? It is a fact that the only Australian company with present and future access to BAe146s is Ansett-TNT?

—In my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, I can inform the House that the developer has asked for approval of the use of BAe146 aircraft. That approval has been given. It does not preclude applications for other aircraft, and of course any aircraft of lesser specifications can land in any case.

—On a point of order, Madam Speaker, the heads of agreement document, which I have in front of me, clearly specifies BAe146s only on page 12 and annexure D. Other lighter aircraft cannot land there because of the expanse of water over which they have to go. Any heavier aircraft--
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware of the brutal killing of the lawyer Ernesto Anaya, President of the non-governmental Human Rights Commission of El Salvador, by the notorious death squads? Will the Foreign Minister express the abhorrence of the Government, and indeed of the majority of the members of this House, at this latest brutality in El Salvador?

—I am not aware of the particular case the honourable member raises but I will certainly check the matter. On the general matter of human rights in Central America, Australia is quite active through its ambassadorial representation in Mexico City. We do not have permanent representation in Central American countries. Our Ambassador and/or other representatives from our embassy in Mexico City go to Central America regularly and raise these sorts of issues. As I say, I will look at this particular case and if I find there is substance in it I will take the appropriate steps to have a representation made.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the environment, arts, heritage, monorails et cetera. Is it a fact that the agreement made between the Commonwealth Government and Christmas Island Resort Casino Pty Ltd, dated 4 June 1987, specifically provides that the aerodrome is approved for use by BAe146 aircraft only, subject to certain conditions? How does the Minister reconcile the answer that he just gave, which implied otherwise, with the express terms of the agreement made between his Government and the resort developer?

—Madam Speaker, I have before me the advice from the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to the Minister's Private Secretary. I do not have annexure D before me. The answer I gave to the honourable member for Bruce summarises the position. Annexure D merely sets out--
—Order! Will honourable members please be silent. Let us hear the Minister.
—He has just been misleading the House.
—Come on, George. Annexure D merely sets out the upgrading--
—Madam Speaker--
—Order! The Minister will withdraw that comment.
—`George'?
—He knows exactly which comment, and he will not repeat it. He will just withdraw.

—Madam Speaker, I withdraw the comment `Come on, George'. Annexure D merely sets out the upgrading of the airport required by the Commonwealth for the use of the BAe146 aircraft, only during daylight hours. If the developer wishes to use any other aircraft or if his proposed BAe146 are to be used at night, the Commonwealth and the developer may agree on such other upgrading of the airport as is specified by the Commonwealth as being necessary to enable the proposed air services to operate. In other words, any other aircraft can be used if the airport is upgraded to meet whatever the requirements of the Department of Transport and Communications specify and the operation of the service complies with relevant legislation, international agreements and Government policy generally.
—My question to the Treasurer is a real question, unlike the surreal questions from the Opposition.
—Order! I ask the honourable member to ask his question.

—I ask: What co-ordinated action can the leaders of the major Western economies take to deal with the stock market collapse? Will Australia press for an international meeting to help achieve such a co-ordinated response?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over a period of a couple of years I have said that the policy imbalances in the United States, both in respect of the domestic Budget deficit and its broadening current account imbalance with other countries, in particular Japan, are of fundamental importance and can be substantially remedied only by both a combination of a depreciation of the United States dollar and more fundamental domestic policy shifts within the United States. That said, there has, of course, been some adjustment via the exchange rate and the United States current account deficit has been showing, until recently, signs of improvement. Also there have been attempts by the governments of Japan and West Germany to stimulate domestic demand to open up their domestic economies to a greater level of domestic product. To some extent, that has been successful. Also, there has been an agreement among the G5 countries for co-ordination in monetary policy and exchange rate interventions.

ANSWER.PARA: All of these things have, in some way, tended to moderate imbalances which exist. In fact, they have not been cured and some imbalances are growing. Until there are fundamental policy changes, I do not think the markets will be pacified in terms of their current attitude towards them. What has happened is that the markets have stampeded on the major Western governments and have taken charge of the process of adjustment, both in the stock market and in the exchange markets. I do not think that will be cured until the United States is able to get together a decent fiscal package, until Japan starts to open up its markets further to imports, and until Germany continues to stimulate its domestic demand, which means keeping interest rates down. Then we might see some of these imbalances worked out. These views have been put.

The honourable member for Calwell asked about a meeting of these countries. These countries tend to meet rather regularly. The G5 has a formal structure with a secretariat and meets intermittently. I suppose in the course of this current upheaval in markets it will meet again, if not as a group, certainly with some of the participants of the group meeting again. Australia's views are well known. I put all of these views to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in 1986. I put them to the International Monetary Fund at the end of 1986. I have put these views wherever I have had a chance in the course of the last couple of years. I think our position is well known. At this stage I do not think that we can do much more than that. Certainly, the meetings of the President of the United States with some of the senior policy makers in the United States such as Senator Byrd, representing the Democrats in the Senate, Senator Dole and senior members of the American House of Representatives, at least give some indication that the United States may be considering a package to try to deal with the problem.

I merely make the point, which I made this morning in an interview, that in May this year we cut $3 billion out of recurrent outlays. The gross domestic product of the United States is 30 times that of Australia. It is the equivalent of a $90 billion cut to their Budget. Between August 1986 and May 1987 this Government cut outlays by $7 billion, which is the equivalent of a $210 billion reduction in the United States Budget. Now if the United States Government were able to bring in a package of those orders of magnitude it would dramatically transform the climate of confidence in the United States.

I can only hope that at this late juncture there will be some progress on these changes abroad. However, not only should the United States be required to adjust but also Japan should be required to adjust, by taking a higher level of imports and trying to do what it can to moderate its imbalance, and Germany should be trying to lift domestic activity and demand to start to moderate its imbalance with the rest of Europe. I think that the fall in the exchange rates of the other European economies overnight is an attempt by the market to try to pull down the economic imbalance between Germany and the rest of Europe. I am sure that these issues now are uppermost in the minds of the policy makers in those countries. Our views have been put before.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The question is about the World Heritage listing. I ask: Does the Minister, as Chairman of the Australian Forestry Council, support the stated aims of the Council, which include advancing the welfare and development of industries based upon the forests and the formulation and recommendation of national forest policy for Australia? If so, can the Minister explain how he supports the Government's announced intention to nominate for World Heritage listing particular boundaries of north Queensland forests presently being selectively logged-the result of which will be to destroy the planned and supervised timber industry of that area? Can the Minister supply the House with any scientific evidence to support his views?

—As I understand, the wet tropical rainforests are presently being investigated for their heritage values to decide whether World Heritage listing should proceed. I was unaware of any World Heritage listing decision, as the honourable member's question implied. Yes, of course, we do have a Forestry and Forest Products Industry Council. My colleague the honourable member for Shortland will soon be chairman of the Australian Forestry Council. There are always many points of view about such issues. Of course the industry has a point of view. Of course people in the area have points of view. Of course people concerned about the environment in this country have a point of view. What the Government has put in place, after a very carefully thought through position, is a process whereby the heritage values of this area can be examined and assessed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to sub-section 25 (8) of the Public Service Act 1922, I present the 1986-87 Defence Report.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEALE; CHYNOWETH; KENT; MILTON; SAUNDERSON; SCOTT; WOOLDRIDGE
PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of food irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Chynoweth,Mr Kent,Mr Milton,Mr Saunderson,Mr Scott and Dr Wooldridge.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' as there is a disturbing uncertainty regarding the possible health effects of this process on humans. This process has also been shown to reduce the nutritional value and affect taste, colour and texture of food, thus necessitating further unwanted additives.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate (a) the `food irradiation' process by State Governments, and (b) the dumping of irradiated food products on Australia, to the detriment of our food producers.

We call on the Government to impose an immediate moratorium on all aspects of `food irradiation' in Australia. We urge extreme caution in processes involving radiation, where there is evidence indicating possible detrimental health effects.
We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of Cobalt 60, Caesium-137 or other radioactive substances.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BLANCHARD; CHARLESWORTH; HOLLIS; KENT; MILTON; SCOTT; SNOWDON
PETITION.NAMEIDS: UE4; TD4; DH4; PH4; DI4; 7J4; IJ4
PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned, call on the Federal Government to give notice to terminate the lease of the US base at Pine Gap before October 1986.
We believe that in the interests of world peace and the Australian people, this lease should be terminated and the base closed because Pine Gap is a spy base and a war base.
Since it was opened in 1969, it has eavesdropped on Australian telephone telex communications. Information obtained in this way was used by the CIA to destabilise the Whitlam Government in late 1975.

It provides communication facilities for CIA activity in countries throughout the world, much of which is connected with overthrowing other country's governments. Last year it became clear Pine Gap was spying on Greece.
The electronic and photographic information its satellites receive is used to select nuclear targets in the territory of the Soviet Union and its allies.
Many US military activities short of nuclear war are also co-ordinated by Pine Gap. These include the war against Vietnam and the invasion of Lebanon by US marines in 1984.
Pine Gap spends only a tiny percentage of its time monitoring arms control agreements, and even then the data gathered is so top-secret Australia has no access to it.
Pine Gap's role will be expanded under Reagan's Star Wars scheme to extend the arms race to outer space, threatening the existence of our planet.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blanchard,Dr Charlesworth,Mr Hollis,Mr Kent,Mr Milton,Mr Scott and Mr Snowdon.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.
2. Therefore your petitioners request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound, your petitioners, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron,Mr Rocher,Mr Ruddock and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experimentation on human embryos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron,Ms Crawford,Mr Lindsay and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card;

That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;

That we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life;
That we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dobie,Mr McVeigh and Mr White.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled.
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern:
About the evil caused by the fact that x-rated videos with their depiction of unnatural sex and often horrible violence, are allowed to circulate around Australia from Canberra.
And your petitioners, therefore humbly pray that such circulation be prevented.
The laws regarding obscenity in the media should also be revived and enforced.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron and Mr Lloyd.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation yet introduced, and that on all the evidence available, it will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID Card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayer's money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cobb and Dr Harry Edwards.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Maranoa Electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation ever, and that on all the evidence available will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to reject Labor's ID card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Dawson electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government has no mandate to introduce its flawed and costly ID card proposal, and that the card will not stop tax and welfare fraud and will invade the private lives of Australians.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to reject Labor's ID card proposals.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
The Federal Government has done nothing to ease concerns that it will support Telecom's plans to introduce timed charges for local calls; and
Call upon the government to undertake that such plans will not be implemented.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Any proposals to time local telephone calls gravely concerns all country people. Isolation and communication is the second biggest problem facing rural women according to the `Survey of Rural Women' questionnaire and any attempt at timing local calls will only add to this problem not decrease it.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to:
Ensure that Telecom do not proceed with the timing of local telephone calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tropical Rainforests: North Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the exceptional qualities of the Queensland Wet Tropical Rainforests. The rainforest and its adjoining reef are a priceless and irreplaceable possession of humanity. Unless this unique environment is protected by World Heritage Listing, its natural beauty and genetic diversity will be lost to future generations.
Your petitioners therefore ask that:
Government actions aimed at the earliest possible nomination for World Heritage Listing be applauded.
The Queensland Government be prevented from allowing further environmental damage in the area to be nominated.
Further logging be immediately stopped and alternative employment for timber workers be facilitated.
The Cape Tribulation-Bloomfield road be closed and revegetated to protect an adjoining forest and reef.
Increased scientific research into this unique ecological system be funded.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should not be considered any further, and in the event of it coming again before parliament it should be rejected because:
We do not accept the concept of an ID card as necessary to control social security fraud or tax evasion,

It would be an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy and our democratic society, in particular because it being required to work, operate a bank account, enter hospital or enter into any transaction,
It would cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on tax payers,
It cannot be guaranteed that the aggregated private information would not be misused for other purposes,
The people of Australia should be fully informed and consulted in a referendum before legislation for any such change with such wide-ranging effect is considered, and
We call upon the Government to cease immediately any endeavour to introduce this invasion upon our lives.
And you petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the proposal:
Is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud, and to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud,
Will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private matter,
Will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the tax payer, and
Cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other more effective methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Social Security
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we oppose the reductions in staffing of the Department of Social Security over recent years, and deplore the plans to reduce staff further. Social Security payments are the only source of income for many Australians. It is important that these people and their dependants receive their correct entitlement in a timely and efficient manner.
