This has been made difficult by the effect of widespread changes in the last Federal Budget and the May Economic Statement, combined with a continued reduction in staff. We believe that people who are dependent upon the Department of Social Security for their most basic needs of food and rent should not be expected to put up with inefficiencies in the Department caused by insufficient staffing and the resultant inadequate training.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to instruct the Department of Finance to accept the findings of the recent Joint Staffing Review (JSR II) and increase Social Security staffing levels accordingly.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kurnell Peninsula
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth.

Your petitioners, humbly pray that your honourable house direct that the existing 4 (C4) zoning on the Kurnell Peninsula, in New South Wales, be removed and that this be replaced by a zoning more appropriate to the unique ecology of the area and to the historical significance of the Kurnell Peninsula, being the birthplace of the nation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the honourable members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tropical Rainforests: North Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners hereby protest against the World Heritage Listing of North Queensland's Wet Tropics.
Your petitioners humbly pray that this Listing be rejected, if not, it will have a detrimental affect on the Timber and allied industries and the economy of Far North Queensland.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tropical Rainforests: North Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectively showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposed nomination of Wet Tropical Rainforests of North Queensland to the World Heritage List. The listing as a World Heritage of such a vast area, including areas of State Forest scheduled for Timber Harvesting on a sustained yield basis, will have a detrimental effect on the Timber and Allied industries and on the citizens and economy of North Queensland.
The listing as a World Heritage of such a vast area will inhibit the future development of North Queensland on a broad economic base.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the listing of Wet Tropical Rainforests of North Queensland as a World Heritage.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear-Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed National Identification Numbering System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australia Card' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justification for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The fringe benefits tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely-depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The fringe benefits tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this legislation and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Government by persisting with the Australia Card Bill has wilfully rejected the advice and recommendations of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia's `Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card' which unequivocally rejected the Government's proposal in these words:

`The majority believes the creation of a new bureaucracy of 2,000 public servants within the HIC (Health Insurance Commission), with the sole task of identifying every man, woman and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which the very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack of the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identifies, monitors, and updates information on every person in Australia.' (Report, 4.55, page 148)

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government now withdraw the Bill as being contrary to the Common Law and traditional freedoms we have hitherto enjoyed in Australia, and should the Bill be nevertheless re-introduced, that the members of the House without regard for party should unanimously reject the Australia Card Bill as being contrary to our personal liberties and the national interest.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives.
The petition of the undersigned do respectfully showeth that pornographic material relating to children is deleterious to the health and welfare of children and society as a whole.
We respectfully urge the Government to ban all child pornography from entering or from being produced in Australia.
And your petitioners in duty-bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Any proposals to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs gravely concern ex-servicemen, ex-servicewomen and their families, because they renege on clear and unequivocal commitments from various Commonwealth Governments to properly care for Australia's veterans.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to:
Ensure that the Department of Veterans' Affairs continues to exist as a separate and distinct Department of State servicing the needs of veterans and their families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government.
This cut has reduced the base for future adjustments. The Government has promised to restore the base as soon as economic circumstances permit.

Having regard to the state of the economy as portrayed by members of the Government in recent months and the interaction between Social Security pensions and the above mentioned adjustment, your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to restore the pension base for the calculation of future adjustments and that the restoration be effected in conjunction with the Social Security adjustments in November 1987.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed High Rise Development, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
This petition of certain residents of the Australian Capital Territory shows:
That we are totally opposed to the imminent construction of a highrise hotel on the parkland area between the Boulevard and the CAGA Centre and Akuna Street and Allara Street.
Your petitioners therefore request that the development of this hotel not proceed and the further destruction of parkland and recreational areas within the city cease.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Car Park Construction, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
This petition of certain residents of the Australian Capital Territory shows the attention of the House:
To the erosion of City Hill for car park construction.
Your petitioners therefore request that further destruction of parkland and recreational areas within the city cease.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's support of the vandalising Ayers Rock monorail proposal which would destroy the primitive and sensitive environment of Uluru National Park.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last 4 1/2 years, Australians have become rather shell-shocked after the flood of hare-brained, stupid and illogical proposals that this Labor Government has put to them. However, despite the fact that we are getting very used to these stupid ideas being put to us, over the last few days of this Parliament we have seen the one that takes the cake-the proposal put to us by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown). He is proposing to the Parliament and to the people of this country that a monorail be built at Ayers Rock in Uluru National Park to take tourists between Ayers Rock, the Olgas and the Yulara resort. I want to say to the House that the Minister has been able to achieve something that his Prime Minister has been unable to achieve, and that is universal consensus among the people of Australia because every person in Australia whose comments I have read or heard in the last 48 hours condemns the proposals that this Minister has put forward in relation to this monorail. One has only to look in the newspapers today and yesterday to see how true that statement is.

SPEECH.PARA: I say that it is true because the whole concept of a monorail at Ayers Rock is ludicrous. A number of things will happen. First of all, it will quite seriously damage the environment. It will certainly destroy the wilderness atmosphere at Ayers Rock, and it will be a complete and utter blot on the landscape. Do not let anybody try to tell you that it will be anything less than that. The other thing is that it will be incredibly costly. I predict that this project will cost, if it is implemented, anything in the order of $300m to $500m to put into practice. Of course, on top of that, the whole idea is totally impractical. There is just no justification, on looking at this proposal, on which one can base any logical argument. In the process of trying to argue the case, the Minister has, quite deliberately, I am sure, misled the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Gilmore cannot make that sort of allegation against a member without doing it by substantive motion.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will rephrase that. In the last couple of days, in order to justify his proposals, the Minister has given the House answers which I believe are totally wrong. I will substantiate that by quoting the Minister. Two days ago, when answering a question from the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) about the monorail, he said about the monorail:

SPEECH.PARA: It has achieved a notable amount of support from the Aboriginal communities which have control of Uluru National Park.

We take that on its face value. But yesterday morning, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), in a doorstop television interview with Peter Harvey, told him in answer to a question about the monorail:
My office contacted senior officials of the committee last night. They knew nothing about it and they were upset.

In other words, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is saying that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is completely wrong. There was no consultation with the Aboriginal people in Uluru and he was saying something that was not correct. Those are words that have come from two Ministers on the Government side. Those words are condemning. One of those two people is wrong, and we all know who he is.

Another point is that, during yesterday's Question Time, I asked a question of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. He was talking about sealing the road. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) interjected, `Seal it'. The Minister said:
The Leader of the National Party says that we should seal it. It is impossible to seal it.

What the Minister was referring to at that time was the sealing of the road to Mount Olga. The Minister tells us that it is impossible to seal it. I refer the Parliament to a Press release dated 7 March 1986 from the then Minister for the Arts, Heritage and the Environment, the honourable member for Robertson. In that Press release the former Minister said that the cost of sealing and realigning the Ayers Rock-Mount Olga road would be $3m. The statements of both those honourable members are opposite. The former Minister said that it can be sealed and it will cost $3m; the Minister just yesterday in the Parliament said that it is impossible to seal it. Either one of the two is wrong. Once again, I suggest to the House that the Tourism Minister is the person who is wrong. So in other words that honourable gentleman has misled this House and I would say that that is cause for the sacking of that Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is all right for the honourable member to say that someone is wrong; it is another matter, under the processes here, to suggest that a Minister has misled the House. I would draw the honourable member's attention to that and ask him to ensure that he does not make that allegation any more unless it is by way of substantive motion.
—Say that he has given the wrong impression.
—Honourable members on my left know what I am saying and the honourable member for Gilmore knows what I am saying. He might proceed now along those lines.

—Okay, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was referring to the ability to seal and realign the road to the Olgas. It is quite obvious that this can be done. The Tourism Minister is not right when he says it is impossible; it can be done. I was there two months ago and I can assure the Minister that the road, called the Lasseter's Highway, to Ayers Rock is sealed all the way to Ayers Rock. The soil type underneath is the same as that which runs from the rock to the Olgas. The Minister tried to tell us that the road to the Olgas is somewhat different because it is on shifting sands. It might be appropriate in future that this Minister be titled not the Minister for office furniture but the Minister for shifting sands. He is trying to shift the argument in this House away from the truth of the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: On top of that, he has tried to justify the need for a monorail on the basis that prospective visitors to Mount Olga cannot get there because the road is often so wet that trucks and buses are getting bogged in it every day, according to him. He says that people cannot get there: it is inaccessible because of the condition of the road in the wet season. I remind the House that we are talking about one of the driest regions in Australia. It rains very rarely indeed there and when it does rain it is usually during the months of January and February which, for the information of the Minister, is the low season for tourist visitors. So there is really no need to be so concerned about the inaccessibility of the Olgas at the wet time of the year because the visitors are not there in their usual numbers.

The Minister said that he wanted to get people to the Olgas so that they could see the waterfalls that run off them after it rains. I point out to him that there are only two or three occasions during the year when the rain is heavy enough to cause the waterfalls to run-and when they do run they last for only a couple of hours. So the Minister's whole argument is completely spurious. There is no justification for arguing that we need a monorail to get visitors there when it rains. It does not rain very often and when it does there are not many people in the area who want to go to the Olgas. That is a ridiculous argument.

I have been looking through the Hansard records of all the Minister's comments and I can assure honourable members that there is no logic in what he has said over the last few days. He tried to tell us that the monorail would be unobtrusive. He said in the House the other day that it will be two feet to three feet above the ground and it will not be seen by people. If it is to be two feet to three feet above the ground and 42 kilometres long how will vehicles cross over it? They could not cross over it and there is a need for them to cross over it. How would animals such as kangaroos, camels and donkeys that live in the area get from one side to the other? Would they learn to limbo? Would they hurdle it? How would they get across? How would people get across? Obviously the Minister is wrong. It would not be two feet or three feet above the ground; it would have to be 10 feet or 20 feet above the ground as the one in Sydney is. If it were that far above the ground it would be very obtrusive. The Minister has even suggested that it be painted a buff colour so that it would blend in. That is as ridiculous as any of the statements he has ever put forward.

I was also interested to note that in the defence for a monorail proposal put forward in the last few days, Professor Derrick Ovington, who is the head of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, has claimed credit for the original proposal to put a monorail there. Professor Ovington is a well known conservationist-some would call him a greenie. He is so much of a conservationist that he is not prepared even to allow anybody to build a dunny at the foot of Ayers Rock. Yet he is the one who proposes that we put a monorail at Ayers Rock. For goodness sake, where is the logic in that? I also noticed that Professor Ovington said that it would not be intrusive because the monorail would be run parallel to the sand dunes and that if one stands back from it one will not be able to see it. I inform the House that the sand dunes run perpendicular to the direct route from Ayers Rock to the Olgas; so the monorail would have to run over the tops of the sand dunes-or perhaps the good Professor thought that he would snake the monorail around the sand dunes and make the trip a really worthwhile journey of several hundred kilometres. That is the sort of argument that is being put forward to try to justify this proposal.

I turn to the cost of the proposal. I have had some fairly accurate estimations of what it would cost. On capital city prices, without a carriage or any engine to drive it, it would cost $4m a kilometre. The direct route involves at least 42 kilometres and that would mean the monorail would cost $168m-without any carriages. And of course to build anything in that part of the world costs twice as much as building the same thing in a capital city. So we are looking at a figure in the order of $300m to $500m to put the monorail into place if it goes over the tops of the sand dunes. How many visitors a year would we be building this very expensive monorail for? About 250,000 visitors will go there this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —About $1,000 a ticket.

—It would be about $1,000 a ticket, as the honourable member for Deakin suggests. Perhaps that will be the way we will promote tourism in this country. It is totally ludicrous on an economic basis to argue that we should have a monorail out in that part of the world. The interest cost on that amount would build four, five or six new roads to the Olgas every year and there would still be enough left to provide helicopters at the Yulara resort to fly everybody out on the odd occasion when it did rain and there was a waterfall at the Olgas. There is no argument that can be sustained that is based on logic for this monorail. I have to ask: How would the monorail be powered? All monorails that I have ever seen or heard of are powered by electricity.
—Solar power.

—It could be solar powered, as the Leader of the Opposition suggests. It is a very good suggestion but the one failing in that is that of course on the days when it rains and we have to get people to the Olgas the clouds will be over and there will be no solar energy. What would we do about that? Perhaps the Minister has thought of a better idea and he would run those big high-power transmission lines all the way from Alice Springs to the Olgas and right through the wilderness to provide the power. The proposal does not add up to anything that sounds sensible. I could go on about the economic and impractical insanity--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members-Go on!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members want me to go on but time does not permit me. Unfortunately, I have been interjected on a few times from higher authorities and I do not have time, but I have not even spoken about the environmental aspects, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—The honourable member for Gilmore must not reflect on the Chair, either.

—I will not reflect on the Chair, Mr Deputy Speaker. So far I have not even mentioned the environmental aspects of this proposal. The monorail would damage a sensitive and primitive environment. People go there for that very reason. They go there in large numbers because they want to get away from such places as Surfers Paradise and the capital cities and because it is the heart of Australia. It is where the wilderness exists and it is accessible. People do not want to go out there to find that they have arrived in Disneyland with state of the art technology all around the place. It is part of the wilderness of Australia. So despite all of these fairly convincing arguments that the monorail cannot be built there in the first place and that it should not be proposed, there is still one failure in the Minister's argument and that is that there still has to be a road to service the Olgas; there would still have to be a road to service the monorail if it were constructed because the road from the Olgas goes on to the Docker River settlement, where people live. People need to drive along that road anyway. The road has to be maintained. So there is a need for a road.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not be silly about this: why does not the Government just take up the proposal and the pleas of the Northern Territory Government and build a bitumen sealed road? It is the logical, sensible thing to do. These silly arguments about monorails just do not stand up to the test. I say that one cannot sustain any argument that will support the construction of this monorail. It is environmentally crazy; it is economically insane. All we have to do is what the Northern Territory Government suggests-build a decent, bitumen sealed road and the problem will be solved. I suggest to the Minister that he tear himself away from his desk, get out in the real world and discover what real people think about his stupid, crazy, bizarre ideas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is most significant this afternoon to get an indication of the priorities of the Opposition in this place. Given some of the events of the past few weeks, one would think that honourable members opposite would not bother to trivialise the forms of the House and to take up valuable time in the House today on the discussion of a matter of public importance. In his opening remarks, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) talked about hare-brained, stupid and illogical proposals: If ever there was a hare-brained, stupid and illogical matter of public importance before this House it is certainly the one that is before us today. I want to make it clear that there is no firm proposal before the Government for a monorail at Uluru National Park. I cannot understand why people are getting so excited about something which, essentially, as the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) said in the Senate yesterday, `is a gleam in the eye of some people in the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service'. However, it must be recognised that there are many steps to be taken regarding a suitable alternative, if it is to be developed, to the existing road from Ayers Rock to the Olgas.

SPEECH.PARA: The principle in this whole debate is very clear. Any solution to the problem-and all members in this House would concede that there is a problem-on a long-term basis must take into account the need to protect the environment but at the same time it must provide suitable access to the thousands of Australians, and, indeed, the thousands of international visitor who want to go to the Olgas, Ayers Rock and the Uluru National Park. It must also be recognised that the road which goes beyond the Olgas and to other places is in bad condition at present, as the honourable member for Gilmore indicated in his remarks this afternoon, and, clearly, an alternative has to be found. So far, budgetary constraints have meant a lack of funds for realigning and sealing the road. From this afternoon's comments I take it that perhaps the Opposition is suggesting that the Government, during this difficult time of budgetary constraint, should spend money here, there, and everywhere else on some sort of project that the Opposition thinks is very important. But everyone on this side of the House knows that at times of difficult budgetary restraints priorities have to be reassessed.

The cost of the project is estimated at $6m. I make the point that since 1980 the Commonwealth has spent about $1.5m in upgrading and sealing the road around Ayers Rock, as well as the access roads within the Park to Yulara. This year the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service will spend $300,000 on the road.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—An amount of $300,000-a fairly significant amount, given the difficult circumstances of budgetary restraint. It is planned to spend another $200,000 next year on the upgrading of the facilities there. So, the Government is not simply turning a blind eye to the difficulties associated with the bad road conditions in the area but is taking a very responsible attitude. The Government recognises that a problem does exist in relation to the current road and it is trying to do something, gradually, about it. Surely, by his comments, the member for Gilmore is not suggesting that the Government should rush in and spend $6m straight away in upgrading the facilities. As much as we would like to do that, I think that all governments must recognise that in difficult economic circumstances they have a responsibility to plan priorities and to do things when they can afford to do them.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the important thing to state at the outset, before the imagery of sweeping monorail towers gets too strong and the proponents of a monorail are accused of having some sort of one-track mind, is that before a decision on anything like a monorail, a new road, or any other form of access to the Olgas were made, several very important steps would need to be taken. So, at this time, any talk of a monorail suddenly appearing at this prime spot of natural beauty and tourist interest is, quite clearly, premature.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an Opposition beat-up, the whole thing.

—Absolutely, as my good friend the honourable member for Bendigo has said. Members opposite have no policy development: we never see any initiatives brought forward in this House to debate seriously the key economic issues that are before the Government at this stage. All we get is the trivialising of the time available for debate in this House with such ridiculous matters of public importance as this. Several options are being considered in general terms by the National Parks and Wildlife Service, as part of a plan to improve access to the Olgas. Since freehold title was granted to the traditional owners of the area, it should be borne in mind that there has been a 30 per cent increase in the area. Obviously, this great increase in tourism has done considerable damage to the existing road structure in the area. Over the past couple of years over 200,000 visitors have visited the national park. That is a very significant number of people coming into the area.

SPEECH.PARA: As I pointed out in my initial comments, any decision made in respect of increasing access at Uluru National Park must take into account the need to protect the environment. But there is no firm proposal. The various options have not been discussed in detail as yet with the traditional Aboriginal owners. I understand that there has been some informal discussion with some of the people in the area. However, options have not yet been discussed by the Uluru Katatjuta National Park board of management. Once the different options have been evaluated and the benefits and disadvantages critically assessed, details of those options will be submitted to the national park board for its consideration. The board will then advise the Minister for the Environment and the Arts of its views on the options put forward. As the next step, the Minister will then put forward a proposal for an environmental impact statement.

A further matter should not be overlooked, namely, that there is a plan of management for the Uluru National Park, and it is operative for about another four years. So, it may or may not be necessary to alter the plan of management. As I said earlier, the Government is trying to improve access to the Olgas in a way that will be cost effective while at the same time ensure the protection of the delicate and sensitive environment, and also, of course, the cultural values that are part of this very important region of Australia. The traditional owners of the region are concerned about the present alignment of the road, and I guess that anyone who has been there would come to the same conclusion. Obviously, the present alignment of the road makes its upgrading difficult and extraordinarily costly. As members of the House would recognise, there are difficulties involved in changing the alignment because of the necessity to protect the Aboriginal sacred sites which, quite clearly, would be threatened if the road alignment were altered.

So, it is not quite as simple as the good natured and humorous approach taken by the honourable member for Gilmore this afternoon would perhaps suggest. He made a quite entertaining speech; we had a laugh here and a laugh there, and he had a large number of people behind him cheering him on. I am not sure whether he is a member of Actors' Equity-he may do that as a sideline, I do not know. However, his performance again suggested something about the Opposition's priorities in this area. Another option provided in the plan of management is to construct a sealed road on a new alignment, which minimises the possibility of environmental damage and which meets with the approval of the local Aboriginal community and the board of management. That is another option. A whole series of options has been talked about, but because of the blind and very narrow vision of some Opposition members they just focus on a particular issue and run very hard with it. There is no firm proposal. There is no reason for the honourable member for Gilmore to get carried away with that idea, or any other idea, at this stage. He is being a bit premature. It is important to keep that in mind.

The honourable member said that the proposals were `hare-brained', `stupid' and `illogical'. I find it amusing that he, of all honourable members, the shadow Minister for tourism, should talk about vandalising primitive and sensitive environments when he was a proponent of that wonderfully sensitive structure known as the Big Merino at Goulburn! For the benefit of the House, I will read out a couple of remarks made by Mr Ian Warden in an interesting article in this morning's Canberra Times, because they place the honourable member's comments this afternoon in a laughable context. Mr Warden wrote:

When Mr Sharp calls anything `bizarre' it is timely to remember that he was an enthusiastic supporter of the construction of the Olga-proportioned Big Merino in environmentally fragile Goulburn. It comes as a surprise to find that a man who can be enthusiastic about placing a replica of a ruminant, three storeys high, beside a busy highway would find anything untoward about a discreet monorail.
Mr Warden later continued:

I have not seen the Opposition so passionate about a subject since the recent nation-racking issue, which set father against son, wife against daughter, cat against budgie, of whether the Speaker's chair should be moved from the old Parliament House to the new.

It is refreshing to find, after all the disunity we have seen among Opposition members in 1987, that they are finally united about the two most significant issues that have come before this chamber in 1987: the first being whether or not the current Speaker's chair should be moved, and the second being whether the Opposition should support or oppose the concept of a monorail at Uluru National Park.

In summary: The terms of this afternoon's matter of public importance seriously misrepresent the position in that they suggest that the Government has suddenly decided in the last few days, to construct a monorail at Uluru National Park when the actuality is that no such decision has been taken. There have been no formal consultations, no talk about environmental impact statements and no talk about anything else that is necessary in the steps leading up to such a decision, if it were ever to be taken. Secondly, the matter of public importance assumes that the Government may do as it pleases at any time in an area that is owned by traditional Aboriginals; in other words, that it can brush aside any consultations and not seek advice on the various options available and proceed without an environmental impact statement. It also smacks of hypocrisy coming, as it does, from the honourable member for Gilmore, who wholeheartedly supported, as I have just suggested, vandalising the historical Southern Tablelands City of Goulburn with the Kitsch Big Merino. The matter of public importance deserves to be condemned by all responsible honourable members because it has taken up the valuable time of this House. The Opposition will, at all times, trivialise the forms of this House as a very poor substitute for any economic or other policy development.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The debate is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
TALKER.ROLE: Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

For 11 years the Commonwealth and the States have been negotiating for a reference of powers from the States in respect of family law matters. Last year four States-New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania-enacted legislation referring to the Commonwealth powers over the maintenance, custody and guardianship of, and access to, all children and for the payment of expenses in relation to children and child bearing. The references of power do not extend to children who are the subject of orders under State welfare laws. The amendments being introduced in this Bill give effect to those references of powers. This means that in those States, and the Australian Capital Territory, Northern Territory and Norfolk Island, where the Family Law Act 1975 also has application, all children will be subject to the same law, and the procedures under the Family Law Act, including the provisions for counselling and conciliation, will be available in disputes concerning ex-nuptial children.

Queensland and Western Australia will be outside this uniform scheme. The provisions in this Bill applying the Act to ex-nuptial children will not extend to Queensland or Western Australia. In Western Australia, the State Family Court has jurisdiction to deal with all of the children in a family unit. It applies, as appropriate, the Family Law Act and the State law. In Queensland, however, it will still be necessary to bring proceedings in the State courts in respect of children who are not children of a marriage and in the Family Court in respect of children who are children of a marriage. The Bill seeks to avoid jurisdictional problems in some of these cases by giving the Family Law Court of Australia jurisdiction in matters concerning ex-nuptial children where the parties to the proceedings are residents of different States. In doing so, the Bill relies on the constitutional power in section 75 (iv) of the Constitution. In exercising jurisdiction in such a case, the Court would apply the relevant law of the non-referring State to those cases not covered by the Family Law Act as amended.

The Commonwealth is still hopeful that Queensland and Western Australia will refer similar powers to the Commonwealth. Alternatively, and the Bill provides for this, those States may adopt the provisions of this Bill in respect of their ex-nuptial children to ensure that such children are not disadvantaged compared with children in the referring States and the Terri- tories. In the present Act the provisions relating to children are scattered throughout a number of parts of the Act. The opportunity has been taken to restructure the Act to bring most of the provisions relating to children together in the one part, new part VII. That new part will operate in general terms in the referring States, the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island, but with no alteration to the substantive law in the non-referring States.
Amendments to the Law

The amendments to the Bill will change the present law on guardianship, custody and access in two ways. First, in the referring States and the Territories the provisions of the Family Law Act will apply to ex-nuptial children in the same way as those provisions now apply to children of a marriage. In the four referring States and the Territories there will be a uniform law for the guardianship and custody of all children. At present the parents of an ex-nuptial child have, under State and Territory law, varying status as guardians and custodians and these may differ from the guardianship and custody rights of parties to a marriage in respect of children of the marriage. This can create complex legal problems and parents of ex-nuptial children may be uncertain of their rights and responsibilities, particularly if one or both parents move interstate. The Bill provides that both parents of a child should, until a court orders to the contrary or the parents file a child welfare agreement in the court, be a guardian and share custody. Secondly, the Bill provides for the registration of enforceable agreements between the parents in respect of the custody, guardianship or welfare of, or access to, a child. The new procedure will simply involve the parents in filing the agreement at the court registry thus removing the need for expensive court hearings.

The Bill introduces Federal laws in the area of child bearing expenses. The States and Territories have long provided, not uniformly, for such expenses. It also provides for presumptions of parentage and paternity for the purpose of determination of these issues under the Family Law Act, thereby replacing for those purposes the operation of the common law presumptions and the non-uniform statutory presumptions that apply under State and Territory status of children laws.

The Bill makes substantial changes to the Family Law Act with respect to the main- tenance of children. The Government's proposals in respect of maintenance were spelt out in a ministerial statement to the Parliament by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) on 24 March 1987. The Government will be introducing separate legislation to establish the Child Support Agency in accordance with that statement.

The Bill effects a number of changes to the Family Law Act that were foreshadowed in that statement. In particular, the Bill seeks to ensure that children will receive a proper level of financial support from the income, earning capacity, property and financial resources of both their parents and that both parents share equitably in the support of their children. The Bill provides that the duty of parents to maintain a child takes priority over all other commitments of the parent, other than commitments enabling the parent to support himself or herself or any other person or child that the parent has a duty to maintain.

In developing its proposals for child main- tenance, the Government has been concerned at the very high level of social security payments being made to divorced parties who have not made adequate provision for spousal main- tenance in the course of conclusion of their financial arrangements. Section 75 (2) (f) has facilitated the drain on the revenue by allowing courts to take into account, in both spousal and child maintenance proceedings, the eligibility of either party to a marriage, to a pension, benefit or allowance. This Bill provides that in any future proceedings for spousal or child main- tenance, the court must disregard the eligibility for an income-tested pension of an applicant for maintenance. The Bill will still leave room for parties to reach their own agreements on child maintenance and spousal maintenance. Those agreements may be enforced so long as the effect of the agreements is not to cast a burden on the revenue by maintenance being so designed as to qualify the party concerned for an income-tested pension or benefit.

The Bill also inserts new provisions to enable the income testing, for social security purposes, of maintenance received other than by way of periodic sum. These provisions require the court, in ordering the payment of a lump sum or the transfer of property in satisfaction of main- tenance, to specify the proportion of the payment or the value of the portion of the property which is attributable to the provision for maintenance of the party to the marriage. A similar requirement exists in relation to maintenance agreements.

The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) said in his statement that the Government would consider changes to access laws and the enforcement of access orders, after it received the reports to be made by the Family Law Council on access and the Law Reform Commission on contempt of court. These reports have now been tabled in the Parliament and the Government will be assessing the public reaction to the reports. Further amendments may be made to the Family Law Act in the light of that consideration and of the Government's consideration of the separate report on matrimonial property by the Law Reform Commission.
Financial Impact Statement

Implementation of the references of powers will result in the transfer of work from State welfare departments and State courts to the counselling, conciliation and judicial services of the Family Court of Australia. The effect will be to transfer most jurisdictions in custody and guardianship cases affecting ex-nuptial children in the referring States from the State courts to the Family Court. There is expected to be some transfer of maintenance cases affecting ex-nuptial children from State magistrates courts to the Family Court. It is difficult to predict the extent of the transferred work, but potentially this could increase the cost of the operation of the Family Court in a full year by some $3.5m. To the extent to which matters now coming before State courts would come before the Family Court, there would be a corresponding decrease in the work load of the State courts.

The amendments to be made by the Bill that relate to the child support scheme may result in increased litigation in the Family Court in maintenance matters. The extent to which this may occur is, however, impossible to predict, given the number of factors that are likely to influence decisions to litigate maintenance applications. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act 1984 to enable the implementation of transitional arrangements for the marketing of Australian produced crude oil from a regulated to a deregulated or free market. The Bill is part of a package of measures which includes amendments to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Act 1984 and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Act 1984.

The three Acts constitute the Bass Straight freight adjustment scheme. This scheme provides partial compensation to refiners for the cost of transport by sea or pipeline of allocated crude oil-Bass Strait crude oil purchased at Western Port in those volumes and at the import parity price determined by the Government-to their refineries for processing. The amount of compensation is based on the actual transport cost incurred by refiners in transporting their allocated oil from Western Port to their refinery. While the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Act falls within the portfolio responsibility of my colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), I shall also address the proposed amendment to that Act which is contained in this package of Bills.

Under the existing marketing arrangements, refiners are subject to the requirements of the crude oil allocation scheme, under which they are obliged to lift over a calendar year an average of 350,000 barrels a day of crude oil from Bass Strait and the total production of crude oil from other producing areas, excluding Jabiru. Each refiner is required to purchase a share of the total allocation obligations, with the share determined according to its market share of sales of specified petroleum products. Crude oil purchases are made at the prevailing import parity price for the relevant producing area.

As announced on 21 June 1987 by the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, the allocation scheme will terminate on 31 December 1987 and be replaced by deregulated marketing arrangements from 1 January 1988. However, it is possible that a number of refiners may not have lifted their share of 350,000 barrels per day-that is, the 1987 target for Bass Strait crude oil-by 31 December 1987 and it is therefore necessary to implement some transition arrangements to ensure equity between all refiners. Refiners who are underlifted against their Bass Strait allocation obligations on 1 January 1988 will need to clear their underlift in 1988 before being permitted to purchase Bass Strait crude oil on the free market. This Bill provides for the continuation into 1988 of the collection of the Bass Strait coastal freight adjustment levy, at the same rate that will apply during December 1987. This levy, which is paid by producers, will apply only to liftings by refiners that have not met their allocation obligations and until such time as these obligations have been met.

The Bill also provides for the Minister to set a nil rate of levy. This rate would be set after all refiners have met their liftings obligations and thus effectively terminate the scheme. Amendments to the other Bills in this package remove the liability from the producers to pay the levy on exports and free market sales after 1 January 1988, and for the disbursement of the funds in the Foreign Adjustment Trust Fund that have been collected under these arrangements. It is envisaged that the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act and the other two associated Acts will be repealed in 1988, following finalisation of all outstanding payments. The Bill will have no direct financial impact on the Commonwealth. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT LEVY COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The principal purpose of this Bill is to amend the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Act 1984 to enable the implementation of transitional arrangements for the marketing of Australian produced crude oil from the current allocation scheme to a deregulated or free market. The Bill is part of a package of measures which includes amendments to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Act 1984 and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act 1984. The amendments in this Bill are consequential on those to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill, the purposes of which I have previously addressed in relation to that Bill.

The amendment contained in this Bill will remove the liability on the Bass Strait producers to pay the Bass Strait freight adjustment levy on all exports and free market sales of crude oil made on and after 1 January 1988. The Bill will have no direct financial impact on the Commonwealth. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT TRUST FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Act 1984 to enable the implementation of transitional arrangements for the marketing of Australian-produced crude oil from a regulated to a deregulated or free market. The Bill is part of a package of measures which includes amendments to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Act 1984 and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act 1984. The amendments in this Bill are consequential to those of the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Amendment Bill, the purposes of which I have previously addressed in relation to those Bills.

The amendments contained in clauses 4 and 6 of this Bill, in conjunction with the proposed amendments to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collections Act, provide a mechanism by which the Bass Strait producers will be deemed to have paid the levy on free market sales, including exports made on and after 1 January 1988. Clause 4 provides that, where such amounts are deemed to have been collected, then they are also deemed to have been paid into the Freight Adjustment Fund. These amendments contained in clause 6 of this Bill will allow disbursements from the trust fund to be made at the end of January 1988 to the Bass Strait producers on the basis of their exports and domestic free market sales during December 1987 and to those refiners that exported allocation sales of Bass Strait crude oil. Disbursements from the trust fund to refiners, on the basis of their purchases of allocation sales of Bass Strait crude oil, will be deferred until all refiners have met their 1987 Bass Strait allocation obligations. At that stage, the Minister shall set a nil rate of levy to apply to future sales of Bass Strait crude oil, which will effectively terminate the coastal freight adjustment scheme.

The base period for the calculation of these disbursements from the trust fund to eligible refiners will be extended from 1 July 1987 to the month in which this nil levy rate is set, in accordance with clause 3, while the amounts paid to refiners will be made in accordance with the provisions of the new sections 8 and 9. Sub-clauses 6 (3) and 6 (4) also allow for any arrears of levy, that is amounts of levy that should have been paid in previous periods, to be paid into the Freight Adjustment Fund and for corresponding disbursements to be made to the relevant parties on the basis that would have applied if the arrears had been paid at the time the liability became due.

Clause 5 of the Bill provides that no disbursements from the freight adjustment fund will be made at the end of December 1987. Payments of the amounts that accrued during that month are to be made in accordance with the provisions of clause 6 as outlined above. The Bill will have no direct financial impact on the Commonwealth. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUFFY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade Negotiations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill contains a range of measures which have been the subject of announcements of changes to the income tax law by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Three proposals included in the Bill are Budget initiatives. They are the removal of the `negative-gearing' limitation in relation to rental property investments, reduction in the rate of write-off for capital expenditure on new income producing buildings and income tax averaging arrangements for artists and sportspersons.

A number of provisions in the Bill are intended to deal with arrangements to exploit the operation of the income tax law. The most significant measure in this area is the introduction of thin capitalisation rules to limit interest deductions of foreign investors in circumstances where their investments are highly geared. Other anti-avoidance provisions deal with financial instruments in the nature of deferred annuities, discounted securities and similar instruments issued to non-resident associates and excessive private company dividends and non-arm's length income of approved deposit funds. The Bill also includes measures relating to the supervision of occupational superannuation funds, facilitation of shelf companies, extensions of the investment allowance and gift provisions and a number of technical amendments.
Thin Capitalisation Measures

The Bill will introduce the income tax law rules against thin capitalisation to prevent significant losses of revenue that can arise where foreign investors do not maintain an appropriate balance between debt and equity in respect of their income-producing activities in Australia. The thin capitalisation rules contained in this Bill were foreshadowed by the Treasurer on 30 April 1987 and generally have effect from 1 July 1987. They will replace an administrative measure that had previously been imposed as a condition for approval of investments under foreign investment policy. The proposals are directed at those foreign investments in Australia that are excessively geared up through the use of in-house loans, that is, loans made available by associated persons such as foreign parent companies and other related entities off-shore.

The measures will effectively impose statutory debt:equity ratios in relation to funding of foreign investments from non-arms' length sources where a non-resident has a 15 per cent or greater interest in an Australian entity or business. Where foreign debt from such sources exceeds debt:equity ratios of 6:1 for financial institutions and 3:1 for other investors, deductions for interest payments will be reduced to the extent that the relevant ratio is exceeded. While the amendments generally apply from 1 July 1987, under transitional measures borrowings that were approved under foreign investment policy and which exceed the new debt:equity ratios are to be free from the new rules. Transitional provisions are also to apply to companies engaged in mineral exploration.

Special provisions will also apply in the initial period of operation of the legislation in relation to the measurement of the level of foreign debt. As the level of debt will generally be taken at its highest point during the year, affected taxpayers are being allowed until 30 November 1987 to make adjustments to their financial arrangements to ensure that their in-house debts comply with the applicable debt:equity ratio. Asset revaluation reserves are to be taken into account in determining a company's equity for the purposes of the debt:equity formula and will, in the first year of the new rules, be valued as at 28 October 1987, rather than at 1 July 1987, to ensure that foreign investors are not unduly disadvantaged by the new rules. Associated measures, also announced on 30 April 1987, to counter tax avoidance arrangements arising out of certain kinds of corporate restructures, will be included in a later Bill.
Income Averaging for Artists and Sportspersons

The Bill will also introduce a new system of tax averaging for the specialist income of artists, composers, inventors, performers, production associates and writers. This measure will give effect to the proposal announced by the Treasurer in the 1986-87 Budget to provide, with effect from the 1986-87 year of income, special arrangements designed to smooth out tax liabilities where fluctuating incomes would push such people into higher tax brackets. The provisions of the income tax law which currently provide special treatment for the income of authors and inventors are to be repealed, although a taxpayer eligible to benefit from those provisions will be able to apply, in respect of the 1986-87 year of income only, for those provisions to apply in lieu of the new arrangements. The estimated revenue cost of the new arrangements is $2m in 1987-88.
Negative Gearing

The Bill will also give effect to the 1987-88 Budget announcement that the income tax restriction on the deductibility of interest associated with the negative gearing of rental property investments is to be removed, with effect from the commencement of the 1987-88 income year. Restoration of full tax deductibility of interest on rental property borrowings will mean uniformity of tax treatment of interest costs for all types of investment. This measure has been made possible only as a result of the Government's comprehensive tax reform program-in particular, due to the implementation of a capital gains tax and the reduction of the top marginal tax rate to 49 per cent. That reform program has brought a new integrity to the tax system and in so doing has relieved the tax paying community generally of the burden of the excessive tax benefits that negative gearing offered high income earners prior to July 1985 when the restriction now being lifted was introduced.
Deductions for Capital Expenditure on New Income-Producing Buildings

The Bill will also reduce the rate of annual deduction allowable for capital expenditure on the construction of new income producing buildings, from 4 per cent to 2 1/2 per cent. This reduction, which was announced in the 1987-88 Budget Speech, is complementary to the Government's restoration of full tax deductibility of interest on rental property borrowings. The reduced rate of deduction will apply to new buildings, as well as to extensions, alterations or improvements to buildings, that commence to be constructed after 15 September 1987.

Special provisions will preserve the 4 per cent rate for buildings commenced after 15 September 1987 in any cases where the taxpayers who incur the capital expenditure had effectively committed themselves to the construction project on or before that date. These changes are estimated to produce revenue savings of $3m in 1988-89, $10m in 1989-90, $29m in 1990-91 and $54m in 1991-92, continuing to rise significantly for many years and exceeding $500m per annum after 25 years.
Discounted and Other Deferred Interest Securities

The Bill will also make changes first foreshadowed in an announcement of 19 September 1986 to ensure that the investment return under certain financial instruments which are in the nature of deferred annuities, and provide substantial tax deferral advantages, are taxed on an accruals basis rather than under concessional measures applicable to annuities generally.

Although the financial instruments in question are considered to fall within provisions that require the application of an accruals basis of taxation to discounted securities and certain other financial securities, amendments are to be made to remove doubts that have been expressed as to the operation of those provisions in their case. The advantages of dressing up loan arrangements as annuities can be twofold: firstly, lower amounts of interest are assessed in earlier repayment years than would be the case if the money was lent by way of a loan with fixed equal repayment terms and, secondly, there can be a significant deferral of assessable income in the case of deferred annuities.

The amendments will ensure that the income element of affected annuities are taxed on an accruals basis and will apply respectively to relevant deferred annuities issued after 19 September 1986 and to immediate annuities issued on or after today. A later application date is proposed for immediate annuities because the announcements of September 1986 were primarily concerned with the tax deferral advantages of deferred annuities. The amendments will not affect the existing concessional tax treatment of traditional annuities such as those issued to individuals by life assurance companies.

The Bill will also modify the provisions that apply an accruals-based method of assessment of yields on discounted and certain other securities, to correct a feature that is capable of being exploited so as to give an unintended tax result. This proposal was announced on 23 April 1987.

As long as an affected security is not issued off-shore nor made payable to bearer, the existing law entitles the issuer to deductions for payments of discount or other deferred interest payments on an accruals basis that generally parallels the basis upon which the holder of the security is taxed on those amounts.

Amendments in this Bill will preclude the allowance of deductions on an accruals basis where the security is issued in Australia after 23 April 1987 to or on behalf of a non-resident associate of the issuer. That associate would typically bear tax only by way of interest withholding tax at redemption or prior transfer of the security on-shore.
The Bill also incorporates some minor technical adjustments to correct formula calculations for dealing with discounted securities and similar securities.
`Shelf' Companies

The Bill will also implement a change to a number of company grouping provisions of the income tax law to give effect to an announcement of 29 June 1987. The purpose of these measures is to permit a newly incorporated company, commonly referred as a `shelf' company, to satisfy the 100 per cent common ownership test that is applied in various company grouping provisions of the law.

Those provisions permit transfers within company groups of deductions for company losses, excess foreign tax credits, rental property interest and capital losses and for the roll-over of assets for the purpose of deferring liability for tax on capital gains.

The shelf companies affected by these amendments are ones introduced into a company group during an income year but which, although previously incorporated, had been dormant before their acquisition by the group. The changes will apply to shelf companies first acquired by groups in the 1986-87 income year.
Investment Allowance

The Bill will give effect to the decision announced by the Treasurer on 12 June 1987 to extend by six months, from 1 July 1987 to 1 January 1988, the date by which eligible property must be used, or installed ready for use, if it is to qualify for the investment allowance. The Government has decided to extend the investment allowance in the light of unavoidable delays that have occurred in the completion of some projects that in all other respects are eligible for the allowance.

In the absence of an amendment the delayed projects would have resulted in a windfall gain to revenue of an estimated $30m in 1987-88, with a corresponding loss of the same magnitude to the taxpayers involved. Extension of the cut-off date will defer to the 1988-89 financial year the cash benefit to taxpayers and the cost to revenue.
Gifts

Amendments are also being made to the gift provisions of the income tax law to permit gifts to the Ninth Australian Division Memorial of Participation (Alamein) Fund and to the Korean and South East Asian and Vietnam War Memorials Anzac Square Trust Fund to attract deductions. Gifts made to these two funds on or after 15 June 1987 and on or before 30 June 1989 will be deductible.

The estimated cost of admitting the Ninth Australian Division Memorial of Participation (Alamein) Fund is $100,000 in each of the years 1988-89 and 1989-90 and that for the South East Asian and Vietnam War Memorials Anzac Square Trust Fund is $50,000 in each of those years.
Approved Deposit Funds

The Bill also introduces measures announced on 12 January 1987 to tax excessive private company dividends and non-arm's length income of approved deposit funds (ADFs). The amendment will ensure that approved deposit funds do not abuse the tax-free status they were given when established as part of the Government's 1984 tax package for lump sum superannuation and other retirement payments. Income affected by this measure will be taxed at the rate of 50 per cent for the 1986-87 income year and 49 per cent for later years.
Occupational Superannuation

Also contained in this Bill are measures to effect the handover to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner of responsibility for supervision of certain aspects of the activities of superannuation funds and approved deposit funds currently undertaken by the Commissioner of Taxation. As foreshadowed by the Treasurer in his second reading speech on the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill earlier in these sittings, these amendments are part of the legislative package necessary to establish the new supervisory arrangements for superannuation funds. Superannuation funds and approved deposit funds which comply with operating standards and other relevant conditions administered by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner will continue to be exempt from tax on their investment income.

The Commissioner of Taxation will retain responsibility for the assessment of tax on income of non-complying funds, certain private company dividends and excessive non-arm's length income derived by funds and where any excessive or unauthorised benefits are paid from funds. The Commissioner of Taxation will also retain responsibility for allowing income tax deductions for contributions made to superannuation funds. To facilitate these changes, the Bill will also amend the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 to remedy certain technical and drafting defects as well as enabling a de facto spouse of a member of a superannuation fund to receive benefits from the fund in the event of the member's death.

Amendments of the Taxation Administration Act will permit the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to utilise the prosecution provisions of the income tax law against fund trustees who breach requirements in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act relating to the provision of information and documents. The amendments proposed to the occupational Superannuation provisions of the income tax law are not expected to have any significant effect on revenue.

The Government has also decided that, in view of the substantial increase in recent years in the number of superannuation funds and employees covered by funds and the possible significant revenue implications arising as a result of any across-the-board increases in the level of maximum permissible benefits, responsibility for fixing superannuation reasonable benefit limits will be transferred to the government of the day. This change will allow the Government to determine the reasonable benefit limits in the light of its budgetary and other priorities and is consistent with its policy of subjecting tax expenditures to greater scrutiny.

An explanatory memorandum which comprehensively explains the measures contained in this Bill is being circulated for the information of honourable members. I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FRINGE BENEFITS AND SUBSTANTIATION) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUFFY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade Negotiations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill will amend the fringe benefits tax and income tax laws. It will implement a large number of fringe benefits tax changes of a concessional kind that were announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 26 August and 29 October 1986. It also contains income tax amendments announced on 29 October 1986 to exclude from substantiation claims against travel allowances paid under award conditions where the amount of the allowance is not greater than was payable under the award on that date.

When introducing the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill last year the Treasurer described it as a major part of the Government's tax reform program. He did so against the background that for some years the income tax law had been increasingly exploited by predominantly higher income taxpayers converting substantial parts of their remuneration into non-taxed fringe benefits. That course had been open to them because there were technical deficiencies in the income tax law itself and because previous governments had displayed little enthusiasm to remedy them. This Government had no such hesitation.

The fringe benefits tax legislation, therefore, was a very important measure both in its content and its contribution to restoring public confidence in the equity of the Australian tax system. Like other tax reform measures, it has been more successful than we anticipated. At the time of its introduction, the revenue gain from the imposition of fringe benefits tax was estimated at $300m in 1986-87 and $540m in 1987-88. However, excluding payments by Commonwealth Government departments, actual revenue collections for 1986-87 were $535m, some $200m more than originally estimated. The estimated receipts for 1987-88 are $750m. These results demonstrate forcefully the merit of the Government's actions to correct the costly inequities that had arisen from the growing use of fringe benefit packages.

The measures contained in the Bill reflect a response by the Government to community concerns that the car log book and certain other record keeping obligations contained in the original legislation were overly burdensome, that some benefits-particularly those of a minor or compassionate nature-which were technically taxable should have been exempt, and that a greater degree of discounting was warranted in taxing remote area housing and other remote area benefits.

I emphasise that while the Government has shown its willingness to respond to reasonable community representations on the operation of the fringe benefits tax law, it has not and will not yield to pressures to alter the basic structure and principles of the tax. The general effects of the amendments being made by the Bill were set out in the two announcements mentioned earlier, and I do not propose to take up the time of the House in discussing them in detail at this time.

In giving effect to the announced measures it has been necessary to modify the operation of one of the proposals. On 29 October last year it was announced that the general rule for determining the reduction in taxable value arising from employee contributions was to be changed so that any contribution by an employee was first set off against the private component of the benefit. While that will continue to be the general rule in practice, its operation could have produced inequitable results in cases where the contribution was not in fact related to the private component. As explained in the explanatory memorandum accompanying the Bill, the reduction rule now being introduced will apply flexibly to reflect the particular circumstances under which employee contributions are made.

A further reduction rule applies under the law to ensure that employee expenses borne by the employer are not subject to fringe benefits tax where the expenses would otherwise have been deductible for income tax purposes in the hands of the employee. Presently, expenditure of a kind that would otherwise be subject to the negative gearing rules is excluded from this `otherwise deductible' rule. Consistent with the Government's decision to remove the negative gearing rules for income tax purposes with effect from the 1987-88 income tax year, the exclusion will cease to apply for fringe benefits tax purposes with effect from the 1987-88 fringe benefits tax year, which commenced on 1 April 1987.

Before concluding I draw attention to two proposed changes to the fringe benefits tax law that have not been possible to include in this Bill due to time constraints. In his announcement of 29 October 1986, the Treasurer said that the fringe benefits tax liability arising from any discounts of purchase price under home ownership schemes in remote areas was to be amortised over the period, if any, of the relevant purchase contract until unrestricted title passes to the employee. These rather complex proposals have been the subject of lengthy discussions between officials of the Treasurer's Department and representatives of the Australian mining industry. While it will not now be possible to bring the amendments forward until the autumn sittings of the Parliament the industry has been advised in detail of the arrangements that will apply.

The second matter arises from discussions in the tax liaison group. As noted in the 29 October 1986 announcement the liaison group, which was established in 1984 by the Commissioner of Taxation with the major legal and accounting bodies, was to be used as a forum for further consultations with tax practitioners on technical and practical aspects of the tax reform package. The Government has decided to accept the proposal emanating from that group to introduce amendments that will facilitate genuine arrangements under which employers may be reimbursed by employees for the whole or a part of the fringe benefits tax liability attributable to the employee's benefit, or from a third party such as a manufacturer who arranges incentives for employees of a retailer. These amendments will be introduced in the autumn sittings of Parliament next year.

I commend the Bill to the House, and in doing so I present for the information of honourable members Part A of the explanatory memorandum on this Bill, which contains a general outline of the amendments and a comprehensive explanation of the operation of the main features of the Bill. As honourable members will see the Bill is a lengthy one reflecting the number of concessions granted and the structural features of the existing law that have made it necessary, at a technical level, to repeat a number of the revised reduction rules. Nevertheless, the details of the changes are, as explained in the explanatory memorandum, relatively straightforward. Detailed clause notes will be circulated to honourable members in the next few days.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUFFY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade Negotiations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
