This Bill is a part of the package of sea installations Bills-the first of which were introduced into the House earlier this month. The full package of Bills will extend the application of Australian laws regulating customs, migration, quarantine and taxation to installations in Australia's off-shore waters.

The measures proposed by this Bill are two-fold. First, the Bill will extend the coverage of the sales tax law to areas within 200 nautical miles of the territorial limits of Australia, the territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands, and the Coral Sea Island Territories-in some areas this will extend beyond the present boundary of the outer limits of the continental shelf. The reach of the existing sales tax law does not generally extend outside geographical Australia, although since 1982 it has had a limited application within the Australian continental shelf area in relation to installations attached to the seabed for the purposes of exploring for or exploiting natural resources.

The second measure contained in the Bill expands the types of off-shore installations which will be subject to Australian sales tax law when installed in these areas. Broadly, this is when they are either attached to the seabed or are in these areas for a specified duration. The amendments will apply to off-shore installations that are located in Australian waters for a number of specified purposes, including tourism, recreation, business activities, marine archaeology, fishing, scientific activity or transport activity. The effect will be that any installation used for the purposes of any of these prescribed activities will take on the status of a place in Australia from the date of its installation in Australian waters. As a consequence, any transaction or act affecting goods on such an installation which would be taxable if the goods were in geographical Australia will be taxable as if those goods were in Australia. In addition, any installation which is brought from overseas to be installed in Australian waters, and any goods on it at the time it is brought in, will be deemed to be imported into Australia and on that basis, will be subject to the sales tax law in respect of that importation.

The amendments made by this Bill will, in relation to installations that are attached to the seabed in Australian waters, operate with effect from 21 January 1987, the date these measures were announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). In the case of other installations, the Bill will apply on and after today. The revenue impact of the measures proposed by this Bill will depend on the development of such installations in our off-shore areas and so cannot be determined at this time. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend section 6 of the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979 to fix the overseas students charge rates for the 1988 academic year. The levels of charge are indicated in the Bill. The increase in the charge, proposed in the Bill, for university, advanced education and technical and further education (TAFE) courses, raises the contribution of a student who commences the course from 1 January 1988 to 55 per cent of the full average cost of a place to the Commonwealth. Charges for university, advanced education and TAFE courses commenced before 1 January 1988 will continue at the current percentage rate of the full average cost of a place to the Commonwealth. The actual increases in the charges for these continuing students reflect the increase in cost to the Commonwealth.

The increase in the secondary level charge from $300 to $328, which will apply to both continuing and new students, reflects the movement in the consumer price index. The amount of the overseas students charge for university and advanced education courses will be reduced by $263, the amount of the higher education administration charge payable to institutions by all higher education students in respect of the enrolment. The net overseas students charge-the higher education administration charge not included-raised $49.6m in 1986-87 and is expected to raise $64.8m in 1987-88. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.
