SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the luncheon recess I was indicating my support for the ending of the two-airline agreement and my support for the statement made by the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan). I had also made mention of the fact that the statements by the Opposition that this was an attempt by the Government to privatise Australian Airlines were sheer nonsense. Whilst it was true that there was a debate on privatisation going on within the Australian Labor Party, so far as I am concerned I am fully in support of public enterprises and will be fully in support of Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd and, indeed, a number of other public enterprises, remaining in public ownership and remaining the property of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: I made mention also of the report of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Aircraft Noise entitled Aircraft Operations and the Australian Community. I am glad to note that the Government is sympathetic to a number of the recommendations contained in that report-particularly as I was Chairman of that Committee. I note also that the Government eventually will be responding in a very comprehensive manner to those recommendations.

In the very short time that I have left to me to speak in this debate I would like to mention that it was a bit disappointing to us that the Department of Aviation had rejected better air traffic control radar as a solution to some of the problems arising from the noise levels from flight paths. We were very impressed by the demonstration of the Australian Electronics Industry Association of various on-board navigation systems and a number of other navigational aids which certainly could assist, not only in regard to noise level, but also in regard to the safety of aircraft. Indeed, it was a bit disappointing that the Department did not appear to appreciate the benefits that might be derived in redeveloped air routes by the installation of additional navigational beacons and radars in locations such as Launceston and Perth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Launceston is a good city.
—Yes, indeed. I enjoyed my visit there with the Committee when we talked about aircraft noise. The Department's planning philosophy has to include environmental considerations.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In one of my first speeches in this House after entering Parliament in 1975 I recommended the sale of Trans Australia Airlines (TAA), the deregulation of the Australian airline industry and the abolition of the two-airline agreement. I suppose that some 12 years later I should stand up here and say that I am proud that finally this has been achieved. I have stood on my record over that 12 years because I have mentioned this proposition on a number of occasions and even at one stage voted against my own Party in the re-creation of the two-airline agreement in legislation in 1981. Therefore, although I have some joy in what we are debating today, we must be absolutely certain that this is not all we do. We have to go a great deal further down the road before we get a totally efficient and fully effective and properly priced airline system in Australia. But this is the first move.

SPEECH.PARA: I fully support the comments that were made by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), today in this discussion, when he pointed out that it was absolutely essential that Australian Airlines, formerly Trans Australia Airlines must be sold, must be privatised, if we are to get a true competitive airline system in Australia. This is one of the things that greatly concern me because, through the media and through this place, as we have just heard, there has been a great debate in the Government concerning the privatisation of Australian Airlines. One of the very great difficulties in the whole airline industry, right from the time of the creation of TAA, has simply been the fact that that organisation has been grossly undercapitalised. It is a fact that air fares in Australia have had to be set on the least efficient operator. I say this as no particular criticism of the management of Australian Airlines, but rather as a criticism of successive governments. Nobody has ever been prepared to put TAA, or now Australian Airlines, in a position where it really could effectively compete against private enterprise. The cheapest way is to allow Australian Airlines to be privatised, to make sure that it has enough capital to get in there and compete in terms of equipment, promotion and efficiency against what we have now in Australia, one major domestic operator.

There is a great deal of concern throughout the community that if Australian Airlines is not properly capitalised, we could well have a situation where very much the major routes of Australia would be confined to a monopoly situation in the hands of Ansett Airlines of Australia. I am sure that that is the last thing that any of us in this House would want, and I am sure that we on this side of the House will do all we can to make sure that that does not happen, because Australia very much needs competition in the domestic airlines services. In the early days of 1976, when I first advocated deregulation of the Australian domestic airline industry, we could see the problem that had been building up over a number of years, and this decision by the Government is probably only about six or seven years too late. Over the past six or seven years we have seen a situation where Australians have very much been disadvantaged through lack of deregulation in terms of what they pay and what they get in their domestic airlines services.

I have a particular interest in the tourism industry and during a period when I was not in this House I worked with one of the State tourist promotional bodies and had a great deal to do with airlines and airline negotiations. To show what effect the lack of deregulation has had on the Australian domestic airline industry, let me cite a couple of things. One of the things that happened was that, some three or four years ago, we had an attempt by the then management of East-West Airlines Ltd to get into the cheap air fare market, and I was involved in some of that. East-West Airlines put in for charter operation between Sydney and the Gold Coast at a return fare of $99. This was hailed by the tourism industry as a major breakthrough, because I think at that stage the cheapest fare that was available between Sydney and the Gold Coast on the scheduled carriers of TAA and Ansett was $213. We all know what happened. It took a matter of days before Ansett managed to come into the market with a fare of $106. It could do it because under the situation that we had, the Independent Air Fares Committee, which thankfully is going, set the fares, and the fares had to be set on the least efficient operator. That is one of the things that have happened in the past few years. We have had a situation in which Ansett has very much had an advantage. It really had room to move if it wanted to, if it was ever faced with any competition; and it did move, at no real effect to itself.

The second thing that happened was the prospect of putting in charter operations domestically in Australia. The two major domestic airlines quivered and quaked a bit about this because they thought it may have been an attack on their scheduled services and their high priced fares between some of the major points in Australia. A great number of studies were done on what would happen if, for example, one put an Airbus on a charter operation between Melbourne and Cairns late on a Saturday night, returning early Sunday morning to Melbourne. The effect there was a return fare from Melbourne to Cairns of $199, and there was still a profit in it. However, under that system, we did not have the capacity for flexibility, we did not have the availability of these fare levels, which could really boost domestic tourism.

If one looks at domestic tourism in Australia and the way that people travel to and from their domestic holiday destinations, it is interesting that better than 80 per cent still use their cars. The reason why so many of them do not fly is purely a matter of cost. It is fascinating that surveys have revealed that only 14 per cent of Australians have ever been in an aeroplane and there is a massive market sitting out there of about 85 per cent of Australians, which a cheap domestic operation could capture. That could be a real stimulus to the domestic tourism industry. Of course, under this highly regulated system, the majors were not interested in tapping that particular market. Both of them were prepared to go for that high dollar market, and especially the business market where the major profits are.

I hope that, as a result of this move to deregulate the industry, we will see a return to innovative fares and the emergence of operators prepared to go into the low fare holiday market and open up the skies to all Australians. It is essential that we make sure that not only do we capitalise on the big influx of international visitors who are coming into Australia but also that we stimulate the domestic market as well. I mentioned that 85 per cent of Australians have never been in an aeroplane. What is even more horrifying is that 42 per cent of Australians do not have an annual holiday. One reason for that is simply the fact of cost. I believe that airline operators wanting to get into that low fare market as a result of deregulation after 1990 should look at areas like the western suburbs of Sydney, which potentially is a huge market, which could give added stimulation and an even more solid base to the Australian tourism industry.

We have to look at other areas as well. We have to look at the whole operation of Australian airports, which must be deregulated. We have this proposed Airports Authority staggering away at the moment, trying to find out what it is all about. There are some great arguments for opening up the whole of that airport scene and looking at the prospect of privatising airports. If we do privatise airports and get rid of some of the bureaucratic red tape that exists around these things, we will be helping the industry to expand. There are some interesting cases involving places overseas. The one that I always mention is the situation in Manchester, in the United Kingdom (UK), which is not part of the British Airports Authority. Manchester Airport is an independent; it goes out there and promotes itself as an ideal centre for airlines to operate in and out of, and it does tremendous business. To a very great extent, Manchester has become the headquarters of the whole of the UK charter business. It is also worth looking at what the United States airports do in terms of promotion. If we could look at that sort of deregulation for the Australian airports and make that an industry within itself, we would be further along the road of getting true value for money back into air travel, which is really what it is all about. We should be talking about consumers and what they pay for their air fares and the right to travel.

Before somebody accuses me of doing away with safety regulations, I would be the first to say that we must ensure that we maintain the safety standards that have been enjoyed by Australia. It is simply not true for honourable members on the other side of the House to come in here and say that we have to be very careful of deregulation because in the United States safety standards have dropped dramatically since that came in. In actual fact, there have been fewer deaths through air accidents, and fewer major accidents in the United States in the period since deregulation. I would suggest that there would be very few airlines in the world, and certainly not in Australia, which would be prepared to forfeit their safety records, because one fatal air crash can write millions off their income. I suggest that most international and domestic airlines would not be looking at any major safety sacrifice. That is not to say that we must not be vigilant in Australia. We should maintain the safety standards that we have enjoyed.

When one looks at what has happened in the United States, at the stimulation that has been brought about by deregulation, at the variety of air fares that are available to the people of the United States, it is amazing what can be done. As an exercise earlier today I went to the Parliamentary Library and saw that an airline such as Alaskan Airlines was offering in last weekend's Press tickets anywhere on its network for $69. That is not bad because one can fly from Alaska to Los Angeles for $69. PSA, the airline that operates through California, has been offering fares anywhere on its routes for $40. Southwest Airlines was offering fares anywhere on its routes for $49. One could even fly from Los Angeles through to Chicago on Southwest for $65. Sure, there are some restrictions on those fares; sure, not everybody has such offers available, but by golly it has been an incentive for people to book early or to take midnight flights to get value from the fares that have been offered.

Whilst we do not have that sort of competition in Australia, I think there is a facility, if we can get our airport situation right, to provide major excursion areas at low cost. I come to the sour point that is often raised here-I see the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) opposite-about the whole situation of airport curfews. Perth Airport will be curfew-free, Melbourne Airport will be curfew-free and the new Brisbane airport will be curfew-free but we are stuck with the situation of Sydney. That really is a worry. However, I make this point: it was admitted from the other side this morning-I think by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton)-that aircraft are becoming quieter and quieter.

The honourable member for La Trobe promoted the fact that Australian Airlines had gone for the Boeing 737-300 series because of its quiet operation. With the increasing introduction of low noise aircraft we have the wherewithal to consider easing the curfew restrictions even in Sydney. We have to be able to give the two major domestic airlines and anybody else who might want to come into the game as a result of deregulation the opportunity to achieve maximum utilisation of their aircraft and airports. I hope that part of the deal involved with the Government's deregulation will be a loosening up of the curfews. While the aviation discussion paper on the Government's decision does not refer to international operators, they have been mentioned previously in the debate. The restrictions on international services to and from Australia are of great concern to a number of us on this side of the House.

We heard a pathetic answer from the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) today during Question Time about passenger delays on flights from overseas. The plain facts of the situation are that the inter- national airlines industry in Australia has been strangled through indecision. The indecision has come from the Ministers, the Department and Qantas Airways Ltd. We have to get that protection out of the way as well. It is ridiculous that an inter- national carrier that wants to bring visitors to Australia-they are all presently bringing in more than they are taking out-has to wait three or four years to get approval to operate into Australia. Now that the Government is coming around to supporting a freer market I hope it will look at making sure that it does as much as it can to free up the international aviation market as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) would not be surprised that I disagree with a few of his comments. Whilst I am sure he is not promoting such ideas, those who will benefit financially will seize on his comments about deregulation and air safety as some vindication of what can eventually result only in a lower safety margin for air traffic in this country. The concept that somehow the American system can be brought here seems to me to be risky to say the least. The concept of cheap tickets and cheap airlines is really cheap thrills because what it would eventually mean in this country, as it does in America, is, `buy a cheap ticket and see if you make it'. The air transport situation in and around Los Angeles at the moment is a disaster. There are near misses on almost a daily basis there and I would not have anything to do with going anywhere near that situation. The honourable member's comments about a curfew-free environment for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport are quite interesting. It should be known to the honourable member that his coalition government between 1975 and 1983 did absolutely nothing about trying to find a second Sydney airport site. If they had got on with the job and done something about it, it would probably be up and running today and it could have been the curfew-free airport that the honourable member talks about. Indeed, the Sydney second airport program that this Government has embarked upon can eventually, in my view, lead to such curfew-free operations. But to suggest that Kingsford-Smith Airport, with 1.1 million residents immediately surrounding it, could be curfew-free or anything like it is to propose an absolute travesty of justice for the people who have to live there, with all the well-documented health effects and so on that they already suffer without having to be woken all night by jet aircraft. This Government is doing something about the airport needs of Sydney. It will take many years to solve the problem. It has to be pursued logically. It will take a long time to alleviate the problem because those opposite, when they had the opportunity, did nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, it is with some sense of history that I rise to support the legislation before the House. It was 35 years ago in this very chamber that the then Minister, the Hon. Paul Hasluck, rose to introduce the Civil Aviation Agreement Bill which is the forerunner of today's two airlines agreement. When that Bill was introduced some 35 years ago it was said as a prelude that it was attempting to secure a competitive domestic aviation industry for Australia. Unfortunately, the Menzies Government, in trying to protect against a public or a private airlines monopoly, helped to create what we have today as a duopoly-a situation where there are only two operators in a market both of whom operate together as if they were a monopoly. In attempting to secure competition, the Menzies Government obviously failed miserably. In fact, in the debate on that very same Bill, the Hon. Dr Evatt, the then member for Barton, observed:
This . . . scheme is the very anthesis of active and competitive air services . . . in fact, for all practical purposes, the agreement will put an end to real competition.
But criticism has not been limited to debate 35 years ago. In 1979 the editorial of the Australian Financial Review made this observation:
There is little doubt the two-airline policy as it operates now is strongly inimical to competition, cheaper air fares, and cost efficiency in both the major airlines.

The situation that exists today in our domestic airlines industry is in fact very similar to the situation that existed in Australia's banking sector prior to Labor taking office in March 1983. Before deregulation of the Australian banking sector, the banking sector was dominated by only four major banks, including the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. There was no real competition, no initiatives and no incentive to service customer needs. The answer there, as it is in relation to the domestic aviation industry, was not to privatise the only government operator in the market; the answer was to open the market up to new competition to allow more operators in the existing market. Changing the ownership of one of the existing competitors will achieve absolutely nothing to the end suggested by those opposite. In 1983-84 the Hawke Government issued 16 new bank licences, thus allowing more banks to operate in the market. In this way, a closed market was opened up to competition.

TALK.START.PARA: —And repealed the legislation to turn TAA into a public company.

—I do not know whether the honourable member opposite is trying to buy one of the airlines with his spare cash but I do wish that he would be quiet and listen. Privatising the Commonwealth Bank in 1983 would have achieved nothing-just as privatising Australian Airlines will achieve nothing today. By scrapping the two airlines agreement, Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia will be forced to compete to become more responsive to the needs of consumers. Notwithstanding all this, the Hawke Government is aware of the fact that the free flow of market forces will not in itself provide the total answer. Even so, it is clear that the present regulatory system is not economically efficient or economically appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: The scrapping of the two airlines agreement will create a more competitive environment. The benefits to the Australian economy and Australian consumers will include: greater incentives for existing and new participants in the industry to become more efficient and response to consumer needs; a wider range of air fares, including a greater availability of discount fares; growth, particularly in the price sensitive leisure travel market; and a greater variety in the types, standards and frequency of services provided, as well as the use of more appropriate aircraft on some routes.

While no-one can predict what will occur following deregulation, if the deregulation of the Australian banking sector is any guide, this initiative of the Hawke Government will be an outstanding success. Just as deregulation of the banking sector allowed new and existing operators greater scope to pursue new opportunities, so will deregulation of the Australian domestic airline industry. The independent review of economic regulation of domestic aviation-the May review as it is more commonly referred to-found that there were a large number of routes that are presently infrequently serviced. Such routes will provide scope for new operators to service them using more appropriate aircraft.

Deregulation will also provide greater benefits in the area of price quality trade-offs. Currently, both Ansett and Australian Airlines are obliged to operate on identical economy fares, and because these airlines are virtually guaranteed 50 per cent of the market there are few incentives for competition on the basis of price. Competition has been based effectively on the areas of standards and frequency of service-rather than on price and consumer needs and demands.

After 1990, the airlines will be free to offer a wider range of fares and to place fewer conditions on them. Experience overseas has suggested that once airlines can compete on the basis of price, and not on the basis of non-price considerations, more consumers will take advantage of the services provided by the airlines. In addition, a deregulated environment will bring greater efficiency in a number of important areas. For example, in relation to timetable scheduling, the ending of the two airlines agreement will mean the ending of the inefficient practice of parallel scheduling. In turn, this will mean a more efficient use of airport facilities. It is a pity that the honourable member for Fadden is still not in the chamber. I suggest that that particular impact of deregulation will ease a lot of the problems that currently exist at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

In relation to aircraft utilisation, in a deregulated market there will be a greater incentive for airlines to serve all segments of the Australian market, rather than concentrating on the high yield air routes of Sydney and Melbourne. In addition, there will be a more effective utilisation of existing aircraft resources. Further, airline deregulation will not mean an abrogation by the Government of its traditional responsibility in the area of airline safety. In fact, if it were to mean that, I would oppose any deregulatory moves. As a member who represents the area in which is located Australia's biggest airport I am well aware that any diminution of air safety processes is hazardous not only for those who undertake air travel but also for those people who live in the vicinity of airports, located in electorates such as the one that I and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Bowen), who is presently in the chamber, represent. In fact, Australia's already outstanding aviation safety record will be strengthened by several new initiatives of the Government.

The Government will also continue to play an important role in a number of other important areas. First, the deregulated aviation industry will become subject to the operation of the Trade Practices Act, especially sections 46 and 50, which deal with anti-competitive activities resulting from monopolistic activities or anti-competitive mergers. Secondly, air fares will be scrutinised by, and be subject to, the Prices Surveillance Authority. Thirdly, to ensure that airport facilities are utilised to further the Government's policy of airline deregulation, the Federal Airports Corporation will move to ensure that new operators have equal access to airport facilities.

The removal of the two airlines agreement will be welcomed by Australian consumers, who for too long have had no choice in relation to air flights. The death of the two airlines agreement, I am sure, will be mourned by no-one. Indeed, its constitutional validity has been in doubt from the very day it was introduced. In fact, had the Hawke Government not moved to scrap the agreement it would probably have been only a matter of time before its validity was challenged in the High Court of Australia.

In conclusion, I shall make this final point: the deregulation of Australia's domestic airline industry has been achieved by the Hawke Labor Government. It was not achieved by the Liberal or National coalition, which had seven to eight years in government to do so; it was not achieved by the so-called advocates of free enterprise, the deregulators, about whom the biographers now argue. It has, in fact, been done by a Labor Government. It was this Labor Government which floated the Australian dollar, which de- regulated the Australian banking sector, and which introduced company dividend imputation. The deregulated environment that the Labor Government is hauling Australia into is of immense benefit to all our citizens, and the ending of the two airlines agreement will be no different. The deregulation of the Australian airline industry is an exciting initiative of this Government and one that I hope will be supported by all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In practical terms, it is true, I believe, that the regulated two airlines agreement served Australia fairly well over quite some time. Originally, Trans Australia Airlines (TAA) was formed in Australia by the Commonwealth in about 1941. At that time the population of Australia was about 8 million and because of the advances in aviation it was necessary to have services available to the people of Australia, particularly those who lived in the remote areas. So, over the years, and until a few years ago in fact, the two airlines agreement certainly served a purpose. I concur in the Government's opinion that it is time that the agreement was terminated, and I am sure that all members of the Opposition have a similar view. Perhaps it should have been terminated three or four years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous Administration had seen the opportunity to do that and had legislated accordingly in making TAA a public company, with all the shares initially owned by the Government. That was a step in relation to deregulation that was taking place in a very positive way. I am sure that it was acceptable to the aviation industry generally in Australia and certainly to the Australian consumers.

We must remember that, from a geographical point of view, Australia covers a very large area and that it has a very scattered population. As every day advances with the progress that we are making there will be a greater demand for the provision of services for the travelling public and for the traffic of goods. So we have a responsibility to legislate accordingly. The present measure may be acceptable, although not completely acceptable, to the Opposition. I shall point out some of the matters that concern me greatly. I believe that it is the intention of the Government to privatise Australian Airlines. I think that this measure is simply another step down that path. I point out that the Government is five years behind the Opposition's policy on Australian Airlines. Since the review that was undertaken in 1981 the Liberal and National parties have had a clear policy on this matter. In 1982, the coalition incorporated this policy into legislation, about which I have already spoken. That entailed the gradual transforming of TAA into a public company, with all shares initially owned by the Government. Some five years later the Government is now saying that it will do the same thing. It has repealed the legislation that we passed previously.

Further, the Liberal and National parties' election aviation policy in 1984 advocated progressive deregulation of the airline industry. It should be noted that the first day on which notice could be given to terminate the two airlines agreement was 26 January 1987, and yet the Government has not done so until now-some nine months later. Nine months ago East-West Airlines Ltd operated many services around Australia, and gave consumers more choice at a lower cost. In the interim, East-West has been purchased by the Ansett Transport Industries group and, as a result, consumers have less choice, not more. It is interesting that Ansett would not have been able to purchase East-West if the Government had not awarded its Coastwatch contract to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd. Skywest's loss of the Coastwatch contract forced its owner, Ric Stowe, to sell East-West and Skywest to Stan Perron, who on-sold, within 10 days, to News Ltd and Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd, both of which have shares in Ansett. Subsequently, the Coastwatch contract was awarded to Skywest.

If Ansett's takeover of East-West is given the go ahead by the Trade Practices Commission, Ansett will possess nearly 60 per cent of the market share. That is rather alarming. With the recently concluded Christmas Island Casino agreement specifying the use of BAe146 aircraft, it now appears that the Government is doing Ansett another favour, given that Ansett has an option on the entire BAe146 production run for the next five years. The outcome of the termination of the two-airline agreement, which we are currently discussing, will undoubtedly make Ansett the dominating airline in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Labor Party doing that?

—The honourable member for Wide Bay asks whether the Australian Labor Party is doing that. It is startling that that is occurring in Government ranks. Fortunately, the Left at least, and Mr Halfpenny, are aware of what is occurring. That is why Mr Halfpenny is seeking an inquiry. Incidentally, Ansett is also tipped to get the contract for the next VIP fleet. An article in the Age newspaper of 1 October 1987 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The TNT-Ansett group is well position to win a $10 million-a-year contract to provide five new VIP aircraft for the RAAF, to be used to ferry politicians and dignitaries around Australia.
The Defence Minister Mr Beazley, yesterday announced that the Government would soon call tenders to replace the existing VIP fleet of seven 20-year-old aircraft.
Mr Beazley said the Government wanted two large jets to carry 30 to 40 passengers in a ``VIP configuration''

The publisher of the authoritative `Australian Aviation', Mr Jim Thorn, said yesterday there were a number of aircraft which could meet the requirements, but TNT or Ansett or one of its associates was very likely to win the contract because it had the aircraft, the aircrew and the ground maintenance and crew facilities needed. Other likely contenders were Pacific Aviation, Skywest and Lloyds Aviation, all owned or part-owned by TNT, which in turn is half-owner of Ansett.

Issues raised in that article concern me. I am most concerned about the actual developments that will take place over the next three years. An advisory group is being set up under the arrangements to monitor the transfer of Australian Airlines into this deregulated reorganisation. The Government, in its plan, seeks, firstly, to allow Australian Airlines to become incorporated; secondly, to remove the day by day restrictions on the company and, thirdly, to set up the advisory group comprising five members.

What will be the outcome of this measure? At present the airlines involved enjoy a 50 per cent share of the market. I am concerned in that one of those must become the major airline of Australia. We hope that the airlines will operate hand in hand, in competition, and that they will offer a service at a fee which we believe is appropriate to the travelling consumer. I wonder how the Government intends to apply the Trade Practices Act in terms of unfair competition. I hope that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) or somebody on the Government side will say whether or not the Government intends to sell Australians Airlines. I know that the shadow Minister has made such a request before. He has not received an assurance that that will not happen. There are indications that the Government will do so. A committee of five members representing different groups within the Australian community, who are knowledgable on these matters, will be locked into a position. Mr Deputy Speaker, can you not see the Government using the Australian Council of Trade Unions and Mr Kelty as tools to lock the unions into the sale of Australian Airlines? Will this committee not make up its mind and recommend to the Government what should be done with Australia Airlines over the years ahead? We will wait and see. I do not want to see Ansett's position jeopardised in any way. If the Government decides to sell Australian Airlines, as I believe it will, in the years ahead and Ansett or Australian Airlines at that stage owns 70 per cent of the market in Australia, what will be its position in terms of the Trade Practices Act?

In the last Parliament we considered the television legislation. The Minister responsible, the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy), is in the chamber now. We saw the open issues. I am not taking the Government to task on that, as I thought that it was quite all right, but we must consider future developments. The honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) told us very proudly how the Government had deregulated the banking sector and so on. How far down the line does the Government propose to go? I am concerned that the travelling public in Australia should be beneficiaries of the competition that we expect them to get. The Opposition wants to make sure that, as a result of the termination of the two-airline agreement and the possible sale of Australian Airlines at a later date, there will be fair competition between airlines servicing metropolitan areas and the various country centres of Australia.

It is quite all right to say that there will be room for competition. At times I draw a parallel between the airline industry and the print media. The bigger media groups have taken over newspapers. In country towns there is no opportunity for anybody to start up a newspaper in opposition to the major newspaper. The same situation applies with airlines. The Government might say, `What is to stop them?'. The first thing that will stop the little fellow is the bigger fellow cutting his prices. It will not be long before the bigger fellow in the newspaper industry or airline industry forces the little fellow out of the field. Those are the things which we face in this country.

As I said earlier, there was something in favour of the regulation of airlines up until now. The proposal will be all right if we repeat what the British and the Americans have done. Under the provisions of their trade practices legislation, no company can own more than 30 per cent of the market. That is important. I plead with the Government to heed that and to not be influenced by union pressures or by big business in Australia. Let the Government give everybody a go. I am pleased that the earlier legislation provided that this measure would be introduced over a three-year period. We know what happened in America at the time of deregulation: everybody welcomed it. I understand that some provincial cities within America with a population of a quarter of a million, after a few months of deregulation, did not have an air service. We do not want that to occur in Australia.

I conclude by mentioning Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, because the honourable member for Barton raised the matter this afternoon. Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport needs attention. The House will know that Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport carries more traffic than any other major airport in Australia. Of all tourists who arrive in Australia, two out of three travel through that airport. It handles at least 50 per cent of air freight in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear that my friend the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) is pleased that three years notice must be given before the two-airline agreement is terminated. I find that interesting because the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), who is also present and who is at the moment congratulating the honourable member for Lyne on his contribution, made some different comments. He suggested that this Government has been moving too slowly. I feel that there is a bit of a contradiction between the views of the honourable member for Deakin and the views of the honourable member for Lyne who thought that it was good that three years notice must be given. But I am sure that the Liberals and Nationals will try to sort that out.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased to support the motion which is before the House. I wish to take up some comments which have been made in this debate by members of the Opposition. The shadow Minister, the honourable member for Deakin, put out a Press release on 7 October this year on this question. That Press release had the following headline: `Deregulation a Smokescreen to Hammer Labor's Factions'. As an aside, if the honourable member for Deakin has watched Yes Minister, he would be aware of a character called Bernard who is the private secretary to the Minister. If the honourable member had someone like Bernard in his office, he would point out to the honourable member that a smokescreen cannot hammer anything. I am sure that in future the honourable member's Press releases will not contain mixed metaphors such as that. In that Press release the honourable member for Deakin is quoted as making the following statement:

Mr Beale, speaking in the House of Representatives on a Matter of Public Importance, said that the Government had delayed deregulation by over 9 months, as January 26, 1987 was the first day that notice of termination of the Two Airline Agreement could have been given.

It is interesting to look at the history of the two-airline agreement. It was not a Labor government which introduced the two-airline agreement. As the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) has suggested, in 1952 the Liberal Minister for Aviation, Mr Hasluck, introduced the legislation which established the whole philosophy and basis of the two-airline agreement. In 1972, when the Liberal-National Party coalition had the smell of death about it, legislation was rushed through the Parliament, because the election of a Labor government was imminent, to extend the life of the two-airline agreement by many years.

The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) made the comment in today's debate that this decision by the Government to terminate the two-airline agreement is six or seven years too late. It is interesting that he should pick that figure of six or seven years. Which parties were in government six or seven years ago? The Liberal-National Party was in power at that time. In 1981 there was a very vigorous debate within the coalition as to whether the two-airline agreement should continue. As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, there was no public inquiry. There was no great examination by some independent group of the major issues. The Government of the day, the Executive, simply took it upon itself to sign a new agreement which locked future governments into the two-airline agreement for many years.

The Liberal Party in those days was quite faction ridden between the wets and the dries. Some people who were on the back bench in those days, and quite often these days can be seen on the front bench, sought to use the two-airline agreement as a way to establish their dry credentials and to use this matter to further their career. If I remember correctly, certain backbenchers appeared on Nationwide night after night, explaining why the two-airline agreement should not be extended. Yet, when it came to a vote in this chamber, when they were put to the test, they went to water. Only the Western Australian Liberal Party members were allowed to cross the floor and vote with the Australian Labor Party, with the addition of the then National Country Party member for the Northern Territory. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), who is at the table, was not a member of parliament at that time so I do not blame him for the lack of courage shown by the other members of the Opposition.

When the actual vote was taken in this chamber on 3 June 1981, the result of the division was 54 ayes and 55 noes. So the amendment moved by the current member for Tangney (Mr Shack) was defeated by one vote, because a few members on the conservative side of politics decided to abstain during that crucial vote. The honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), who served with great distinction as this country's Minister for Aviation, in those days was Opposition spokesman on aviation. He moved an amendment which would have provided for the imposition of a five-year limit on the two-airline agreement. If that amendment had been accepted by the Liberal and National parties, the two-airline agreement would have ceased to exist on 26 January this year. For years and years, the Liberal and National parties have claimed that they were the ones who wanted to deregulate; that they were the ones who wanted to create more competition. Yet, as far back as 1981, they were blocking attempts by the Labor Party to seek to place that five-year limit on the two-airline agreement.

Claims by the honourable member for Deakin that in 1981 there were major changes to the two-airline agreement are absolute nonsense. In fact, he has gone so far as to move an amendment today. He has included in this amendment some outrageous sub-clauses which condemn the Government. In his contribution today, the honourable member for Deakin said that he has a legal opinion to the effect that since this outrageous amendment was carried in the Senate, if this chamber does not agree also to accept that amendment, both Houses of Parliament will have failed to give notice that the two-airline agreement has been terminated. The honourable member for Deakin, by using a sneaky tactic, is seeking to delay further this Parliament giving notice of termination of the two-airline agreement. So I am starting to doubt the motives of the honourable member.

On the other hand, this Government commissioned the May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation in March 1985, which worked very hard over two years. It received more than 80 submissions and by January 1987, the then Minister for Aviation was able to call for public comment on the five options that were given to the Government by the May Review. I am very proud of the fact that this Government, before the 11 July 1987 election, announced to the people of Australia that if the Labor Party was returned to government it would introduce legislation to terminate the two-airline agreement. That is what the legislation before the House does.

The Government is taking action on four fronts. I will go into detail on the decision that the Government has taken. First, we are eliminating the controls which currently exist on the importation of large sized aircraft. At the moment a detailed determination is made by the former Department on the amount of passenger capacity on all the major trunk routes. That is something which has hindered market forces from encouraging the major airlines to provide sufficient seating capacity on the major trunk routes. Eliminating these capacity controls will ensure that there is much more genuine competition between the two major airlines. The Government has eliminated the Independent Air Fares Committee and, in its place, it is giving the Prices Surveillance Authority the responsibility to ensure that fares are set at a fair level. In addition, we are extending the powers of the Trade Practices Act so that they will apply to the aviation industry, to ensure that no one company can develop a monopoly on the domestic aviation service. Obviously, that has the support of the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), who is in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good member, too.

—He is a very good member, as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who is at the table, suggests. The Government's decision also will allow the entry of any new operators who wish to take the commercial risk of starting up a new airline.

SPEECH.PARA: These decisions as a whole will result in several benefits for people who travel by air. There will be a greater range of air fares and packages available to consumers. I believe that there will be a significant expansion in the number of discount air fares and special holiday packages which can be purchased by consumers. It is very interesting to compare the extent of discounting in Australia with that in the United States because in the US about 90 per cent of air travellers receive some discount. If we look at the average discount received by air travellers in the United States, there is a benefit of approximately 60 per cent off the standard air fare. By comparison, in Australia only about 45 per cent of air travellers receive discounts. East-West Airlines Ltd has shown that there is a market in Australia for a no-frills service, if it is matched by a no-frills price. I hope that choice will be offered to more air travellers in Australia.

The Government has also announced that it is establishing a civil aviation authority which will have responsibility for air traffic control, communications, navigation, fire fighting at airports, and other important matters. Air travellers can be very certain that that civil aviation authority will ensure that safety standards are not compromised by the Government's decision to relax the two-airline agreement. The honourable member for Barton earlier in today's debate mentioned that many questions have been raised about safety standards in the United States, following the deregulation of its aviation industry. Contrary to comments made by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), there has been a great reduction in safety standards in the United States. He claimed that there has not been an increase in the number of deaths or aeroplane crashes in the US since the aviation industry was deregulated. However, I make the point-and it has received a great deal of publicity in Australia-that many airlines in the United States have received very substantial fines from the organisation that monitors airline safety standards. Several airlines have received fines amounting to many hundreds of thousands of dollars because they simply have failed to carry out routine maintenance, which has placed their passengers at risk.

The Government has announced that Qantas Airways Ltd, once again, is to be allowed to provide travel on some domestic routes for international passengers. That is an important concession which will be of great benefit to Qantas. In addition, indirectly it will have some benefit, for example, to Australians who might fly with Qantas to overseas destinations. It works the following way: if someone is purchasing a ticket to the United States some of the American airlines can offer additional flights at a very cheap price. For example, if a person flies with Continental Airlines Inc. or United Airlines, the airline might say that for a very small additional cost the person can also receive some travel within the United States. Under the current American-Australian agreement, Qantas cannot provide seats on United States internal air travel. Qantas, in the future, will be able to negotiate deals with airlines such as United and Continental on domestic Australian flights. I hope Qantas will be able to offer its Australian passengers flying overseas special deals which will be very beneficial to those passengers.

The last point I want to touch on is the claim made indirectly by the honourable member for Lyne and other honourable members in this House in recent days; that is, this Government is doing special deals with Ansett Airlines of Australia. Several people have hinted that, because the Chief Executive Officer of Ansett, Sir Peter Abeles, has a special relationship with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), this Government is making decisions which are in the commercial interest of Ansett. The people who make those allegations quote some Press reports but do not have the guts to say what they are really trying to hint at. Are they suggesting that in some way this Prime Minister is doing special deals with Ansett because of that relationship? If they have the guts to say that, I simply say: why did this Government take the decision to grant Qantas these interlining rights when Ansett Airlines strongly and strenuously opposed that? In addition, why did the Government decide not to grant Ansett the contract for providing blocks of Public Service travel rights within Australia? These are two examples in which Ansett has not been successful. Yet honourable members in this House have the gall to allege that Ansett gets some special treatment. Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that you would be aware that this Government would ensure that the proper standards always apply and that Ansett is treated in a fair way but does not receive any special treatment. I support the motion before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In order that other members get a chance to speak to this motion, the Government has arranged that we speak for a limited time. I thank the Government for that but, of course, I would prefer to have the opportunity to speak for a lot longer. What we are doing today is assembling to bury the two-airline agreement. There is joint agreement on both sides of the House to do that. All of us, for different reasons, welcome it. The two-airline agreement has outlasted its useful purpose. There have been many comments today from many speakers. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), on this side of the House, made a very important contribution. He is recognised as having a detailed knowledge of the area.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I have been in this place-and I am only in my second term-I have had a very keen interest in airlines. During the last Parliament I served as secretary and chairman of our aviation committee. It was always interesting to meet people from Australian Airlines, Ansett Airlines of Australia, Qantas Airways Ltd, the then Department of Aviation, budget air services such as East-West Airlines Ltd and many others. All of them had a realistic view that one day this two-airline agreement would have to come to an end. But the interesting thing is that many people on the other side of the House have done a complete back flip. The honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), the former Minister for Aviation, was very slow to come to the trough of deregulation. He set up the May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation. For that, I applauded him. When one looked at the submissions to that inquiry, they were interesting. Not one member of this chamber, or of the Senate, other than me, put a submission to that inquiry. With all the posturing and screaming from both sides of the House, I found it very interesting that no one took the opportunity to make a detailed submission.

It can be said that the final decision on this matter is really a triumph for the theory of contestability, because that is what the deregulation arguments are all about. We are trying to make markets contestable; in other words, level the field so that anyone can get in and have a go. There is an adherence to the maintenance of safety standards. Honourable members on both sides of the House have emphasised that. No one, in any way, is indicating that there should be a diminution of safety.

The amendment moved by the shadow Minister for transport and aviation, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), is in three parts. The first part notes the long overdue adoption by the Government of our policy-it was our policy that the Government has adopted. The second part of the amendment states:
. . . further notes the Government's de facto decision to privatise Australian Airlines . . .

Australian Airlines will need to be privatised in one form or another-call it commercialise, or what one likes. The existing arrangements, its $300m capital starved condition, cannot go on if the airline is to be viable. The General Manager, James Strong, has been telling the Government that for some time, as, indeed, has the Board. The Government must listen. The third part of the amendment condemns the Government in a number of areas. One important area that no one in this debate has yet mentioned is in relation to the staff of Australian Airlines. They want to know what is going on and what will happen to them in the future. It is about time the Government made a commitment to them by setting out its future policy options.

I am a Tasmanian-and proud of it. We have suffered under the two-airline policy for far too long, so I am exceptionally pleased to help throw a handful of dirt on the coffin of the two-airline agreement as it disappears out of sight. I am unsure as to whether the Government will change its mind and try to bring an early termination before 1990. I hope that it will be able to do so. Under the agreement, that can be done with the concurrence of the parties to the agreement; that is, the Government, Australian Airlines and Ansett.

The concern about airline purchases needs to be addressed in these few minutes available to me. The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) mentioned this matter and I have had a considerable amount to say about it. It is important to note that Lloyd Aviation Group, Australia's fourth ranking airline, is now effectively controlled by Ansett. East-West Airlines, the third largest airline in this country, is effectively controlled by Ansett. Kendall Airlines, the largest regional carrier in New South Wales, is controlled by Ansett.

TALK.START.PARA: —New South Wales and Victoria.

—New South Wales and Victoria. At present 60 per cent of airline passenger traffic is now controlled by Ansett. When we take into consideration the power it has through computer networking and booking systems this control gives Ansett immense market power. Certainly, this concern needed to be addressed before the Government permitted one airline company to have a very large dominant position.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been some mention of the role of the Trade Practices Commission. I wrote to the Commission to ask it what it was doing. It wrote back to say that it was conducting an inquiry. But we have not heard what it is doing. What is Mr McComas doing? We want to know. From the abolition of the two-airline agreement we want to see a substantially increased level of competition. We do not want to go from a duopoly to a monopoly. That is what we will see happening unless we have some answers and some action from the Government. Until the Government responds there will be a very big degree of uncertainty about the future of the aviation industry in this country.

It is an industry that has great potential for growth. The honourable member for Fadden pointed out that about 80 per cent of Australians have not travelled with an airline. There is great potential for growth. There is room for the Mayne Nicklesses, the Brambles budget air services, the Ipecs and many other operators, all Australian companies, to get in there and provide services. We have to sort out the problems with airports. We must have some decisions from the Government. We cannot just sit back for the next three years and hope it will all sort itself out because whilst we are waiting, as the honourable member for Deakin pointed out, the existing major operator will get streets in front and that, I believe, denies what the Government is trying to do, and that is get rid of the two-airline agreement. I appeal to the Minister that we get some decisions, that he make them soon, that he let us know what is happening with Australian Airlines.

At the end of the day I welcome the fact that the motion has been moved. We have wasted too much time already; we ought to stop wasting time and get on with looking after the consumers. People want to fly. I can cite costs that people are paying in this country. We did some surveys in Tasmania. Do honourable members know that airline fares rose by 99 per cent over a given period as against the inflation rate of about 45 per cent? We have an Independent Air Fares Committee which is effectively a cost-plus air price setting mechanism. As the honourable member for Fadden said, the least efficient sets the price for the rest. We have had windfall profits taken by Ansett because of that system. It has to come to an end. We in this place are charged with looking after everyone in this community. We have to put in place a system whereby the consumers get the opportunity to utilise that system.

The two-airline system got the airlines running in this country. They are running well; now it is time for a new system. Let us not waste any more time. Let us get on with it and do the job properly and give the consumers of this country what they want. After all, is that not why the Government is introducing this legislation? Is that not why the two-airline agreement is now being buried? The ground swell of community opposition to seeing competition only on biscuits, coffee and uniforms has to come to an end. People want price competition-real competition. The only way we can get that is to embrace contestability theories and get rid of this two-airline agreement. We have to do it quickly or Australia will get left behind, as we are in so many other fields.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this motion to deregulate the Australian airline industry, I am delighted to support the action of the Government which is finally implementing Opposition polity, a policy that we have had since 1984. It is somewhat interesting that a government that for so long ridiculed the Opposition's policy should finally find itself implementing aspects of that same policy.

SPEECH.PARA: It is relevant at this stage to look at the statements made by members of the Government as to how they once viewed that policy. In 1984 the then Minister for Aviation stated:

If the Opposition goes the whole way with its enthusiasm . . . deregulation will be thrown in for good measure. If the Opposition follows this scenario there is every chance that Australia's aviation system would slide into chaos.
And what was that policy that was going to slide Australia's airlines into chaos? It was a policy that states:

Negotiations would take place between the Government and the airlines for the purpose of obtaining agreement to the early termination of the two airlines agreement. In the absence of agreement, three years notice will be given to . . . terminate it as soon as possible . . .

It seems that even in the Australian Labor Party (ALP) ideology and realism can eventually collide with sufficient force to change at least some of the most committed ideologues. Indeed, it is very pleasing to see a change in the traditional Labor Party opinion, opposing anything that would weaken government intervention in the airline industry. Even so, the document fails through indecision over the future of Australian Airlines and, apart from that, it is at least nine months too late.

The regulated environment in which airlines in Australia have traditionally operated has long outlived its usefulness. This environment has cocooned Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines for 35 years and stifled efficiency. If one compares Australia with the United States of America and uses the standard industry measure of passenger kilometres per employee, Australia is less than half as efficient as United States airlines, and that is taking only major trunk routes into account.

What of the two domestic airlines themselves? There has been much controversy as to the relative efficiencies of public and private enterprises in a regulated environment. The controversy of 15 years is summed up in the economic record detailed by Michael Kirby. When talking of airlines in Australia, he concluded:

While there may be some empirical evidence that the state firm is less efficient than the private one, this difference is likely to be small compared with inefficiencies of both operators, which are due to the current policies of economic regulation.
It is the regulation that is the main culprit in Australia's relative inefficiency and, thus, I wholeheartedly support the change the Government is proposing.

When the two-airline agreement was first introduced, it was to protect Ansett airlines from undue competition from Trans Australian Airlines. Today, the situation has been reversed. With the purchase of East-West Airlines Ltd and the likelihood of combining with smaller commuter airlines, with the possibility of expansion overseas and with expansion into tourist resorts, Ansett is now in an exceedingly strong position, a position that is a compliment to its managers. It has just spent over $1 billion on 27 new aircraft and has ordered the entire five years new production of BAe147 aircraft.

What of Australian? The General Manager of Australian, Mr James Strong, recently stated that Australian could compete against Ansett only if it received adequate capital. With its recent decision to defer its $650m purchase of the airbus through lack of funds, this issue is absolutely critical. Its present capital base is a mere $130m and, with this low government furnished capital base, it simply cannot afford the new aircraft. This under-capitalisation forces Ansett to borrow and pay large interest bills. If it is to compete adequately, it is essential that it receive sufficient capital to remain competitive with Ansett. Senator Walsh understood the implications of this when he stated on 20 October:

Australian and Qantas would become an increasing burden to the public sector and, under the present arrangements, Australian Airlines and Qantas would add substantially to the public sector borrowing requirements.
This is quite correct. The May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation recognised Australian Airlines' position when it stated:
Australian Airlines was commercially and financially disadvantaged by its Federal Government relationship.

On this background, what is the Government's response? Quite simply, it is indecision. The Government's response has been to establish an advisory group to frame options for capitalisation of the airline; a committee that is to report back within six months-just in time for the ALP National Conference in June 1988.

There is no reason whatsoever for an advisory committee to report on the glaringly obvious requirement for an expanded capital base for Australian Airlines. This dithering and indecision will further stifle Australian Airlines in its attempt to compete effectively with Ansett. The airline cannot push ahead with investment decisions until it knows who will be owning it.

With this delay, Australian Airlines will be far behind Ansett in preparing for the new airline environment. Its ability to retain its market share against Ansett must be seriously in doubt. We run the very great risk that, instead of a two-airline policy, we will be left with a near monopoly of one and a bit airlines. What do we hear from the Government on the point? We hear very little. Perhaps we are to have a corporate structure. However, there is no obvious reason why a corporate structure should suddenly make Australian Airlines competitive with Ansett when Ansett is already removing Australia's market share from underneath its feet. If Australian is to compete effectively with Ansett, the Gov- ernment has no choice but to push ahead with privatisation. Senator Gareth Evans realised this point when he stated in his original announcement:
The announcement today on the deregulation of the airline industry will further commit the Government to the privatisation road.
If the Government dithers any further and capitulates to its left wing, it will not be the privatisation road along which we move, it will be one more step down the Argentinean road.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on this two airlines agreement and the deregulation of the industry, I just pose the question why the matter was not completed on 26 January when that date was available to the Government to institute deregulation. Nine months later we see this deregulation taking place. Members of the Government have mentioned the massive deregulation they have introduced in this area and that area, but I believe that if deregulation is to succeed in the airline business, as is suggested, the Government ought to do something in connection with deregulating the industrial situation in Australia in order to make the airlines properly competitive in the future. But we know that that is one area in which it will not deregulate. The industrial situation has the Government by the throat, and it will stay that way.

SPEECH.PARA: The document produced by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) and his Department indicates that the Government's objectives are the increased responsiveness of airlines to consumer needs, a wider range of fares and types of services to provide enhanced travel opportunities, increased competition and pricing flexibility leading to greater economic efficiency in the industry, and a continuation of Australia's world-renowned aviation safety record. I believe that these objectives can be achieved and, speaking in relation to Queensland, the Northern Territory and Western Australia, deregulation of fare structures should be a boon. For that reason I believe that those States will accept the proposition.

However, one thing has to be borne in mind. If we are to deregulate and get the benefits from that, the Government has to realise that the airports throughout Australia have to be of a standard that enables them to take the aircraft available. That is essential if these particular benefits of deregulation are to be achieved. I can speak only of a couple of airports in the north that at this stage will not have adequate capacity: one is Darwin, which has been badly neglected-it will be a port of convenience as far as deregulation is concerned-and the other is Townsville. Of course, there are many others right throughout the north.

We are looking at deregulation through termination of the two airlines agreement, but I suggest that the nine months delay in bringing this forward has given an opportunity to one airline and not the other. It is no good deregulating the system if one major airline-Australian Airlines-is put in a disadvantaged position. Over the 4 1/2 years this Government has been in office Australian Airlines has not received the support, particularly government support, to enable it to capitalise and reap the benefits that have been available to Ansett Airlines of Australia.

For comparison, I shall make a list in this regard. Most of these things have happened over a period of years. Ansett has upgraded its resorts right around Australia. It has embarked on the acquisition of Boeing aircraft, and I understand that at the moment it has some of those on lease overseas, waiting for this deregulation to take effect. It has interlining rights with Qantas Airways Limited, and it now participates with Cook Island Air, Air Vanuatu, Ansett New Zealand and Air Pacific. It has acquired East-West Airlines Ltd, and with it Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd. My colleague the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) has already indicated the surveillance contract aspects of that. Also, reading from the newspapers, it has cornered the market on the BAe146-200QT aircraft for production over the next five years. This is a fine aircraft but the fact that Ansett has been able to corner the market indicates that it has been prepared for this event. Members of the Government say that Ansett has not been given special deals, but I draw attention particularly to all the aspects of that list which suggest that there has been some assistance.

Meanwhile, although the profit of Australian Airlines last year was good, it is undercapitalised. It is operating in a declining market but there is no doubt about it, with the privatisation which is now as much a part of this agreement as any there will be no problems in that regard. But can Australian Airlines become a more efficient competitor under the threat of privatisation and the stumbling that will take place in the intermediate period? There will be little time for other airlines to compete throughout Australia, and so what is now a two-airline policy could well become a one-airline policy.

The advisory board investigating what will happen with Australian Airlines is made up of a rather interesting panel. It is supposed to be able to provide the answers to Australian Airline's particular problems. First of all, Qantas is not regarded as being suitable for merger with Australian Airlines at this time, and one can only wonder why, particularly with the interlining rights that will be given under the new agreement. The members of the board are of interest. They are a Mr Ted Harris, who I am told is a sometime tennis partner of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke); a Mr Carter; a Mr Bill Kelty, who is the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions; Mr Peter Redlich, who is a former President of the Victorian Branch of the Australian Labor Party, from the left wing, and Dr Peter Wilenski, a former Private Secretary to the Prime Minister and Cabinet in Mr Whitlam's time. So I think the conclusions of this board are foregone, and its attitude on the unions is locked in, bearing in mind that there is still some debate on privatisation. Of course, Mr Kelty is known to be not only the beneficiary of a large salary from his own organisation but also as a member of boards, including the boards of the Reserve Bank of Australia, the Economic Planning Advisory Council and quite a few others. One wonders whether he is on this advisory board for any reason other than to make sure of the decisions it makes.

One must also look at the specialisation of Ansett staff over a period of just a few years. In an article headed `Sir Peter's cabin crew', reference is made to Terry Burke, older brother of Brian Burke, of Western Australia, who is going to be admitted as a director of Ansett W.A.; Mr Neil Batt, now Opposition Leader in Tasmania but a former senior executive of the TNT group; David Hurley, Neville Wran's ex-Press Secretary; Emmanuel Klein, former senior private secretary to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown); and Barbara Ward, who has turned financial analyst with TNT.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there anyone left?

—I do not know whether there is any room left on the board for anyone else. It is important to point out that Ansett has had particular benefits from this Government and it is also being assisted in this deregulation. Finally, in connection with deregulation, this afternoon the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) asked a question about the future of Christmas Island. I have seen the heads of agreement which specifies that approval will be given for BAe146 aircraft only and, bearing in mind my earlier comment in connection with the full run of that aircraft for the next five years being available to Ansett, I believe that what we are seeing here is a deregulation on the one hand but a very regulated market in one area on the other. My time has been limited. There is a lot more I would like to say but I will be satisfied with those few points.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HUMPHREYS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, am I to understand that the Minister for Veterans Affairs is replying to the debate?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I point out to the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) that the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) is not well and is not able to be here. I apologise on his behalf. I think I am quite capable of taking this matter through the House. I know quite a bit about the airline industry. I have been travelling on the airlines for the past ten years and I have been looked after well by both Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia. They both employ people, and I am happy to fly on either one. I thank all honourable members for their contributions, especially the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) who made a very worthwhile contribution. It always amazes me that when the Government puts forward a proposition such as the termination of the two-airline agreement, the Opposition comes forward and implies that it has all the wisdom and knowledge and that nobody on this side of the House has any knowledge and that we are not able to manage the affairs of the nation. I want to remind honourable members opposite that they were in government for 23 years and did nothing about the two-airline agreement. However, they are in here today telling us what we are doing wrong and that they have all the wisdom. They had plenty of opportunity to change things, but they did nothing. I ask them not to come into this House claiming that they know everything.

SPEECH.PARA: I close my remarks with a few words relating to the comments of the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). Whilst I have a lot of respect for him, I think that he should be more careful about casting aspersions on the members of the boards of organisations such as Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines. Those board members are all very honourable Australians. They are very capable and highly qualified. I can assure the honourable member that I know quite a few of them and I do not think they would do the wrong things. I do not think the Australian Labor Party would be trying to influence their views. Those people will be running Ansett and Australian Airlines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I advise the Minister that I was not casting aspersions; I was just making comments on how members of those boards were appointed.

—I think that everybody listening to this debate will know what the honourable member for Dawson was doing. Once again, I thank honourable members for their contribution to the debate. The Government will not be accepting the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Mr Beale's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 October, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK INDUSTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 and cognate Bills contain a number of significant amendments to legislation affecting our great livestock industries. I will briefly detail these amendments, to put the debate in perspective. First, there is the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill. That amends the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977 and includes the involvement of the Australian Pork Corporation with the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) to develop marketing schemes for meat and livestock, such as computer aided livestock marketing (CALM) and Ausmeat. It includes a requirement for the AMLC to consult with the industry in its corporate planning process, changes to the operation of the AMLC annual general meeting, introduction of equal employment opportunity policies and removal of redundant provisions from the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act. It also amends the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985, with changes to the operation of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation's (AMLRDC) annual general meeting, and introduces a requirement for the AMLC to consult industry in its corporate planning process. Then there is the Australian Meat and Live-stock Policy Council Act, and amendments to that include removing the requirement for the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council (AMLIPC) to hold an industry conference every two years. The AMLIPC will still retain its power to call conferences when required. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984 is being amended as well, and these amendments include provision for Committee members to be appointed for periods of up to three years, and remove the requirement for preparation of an annual report.

SPEECH.PARA: The second major amendment concerns the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill, which increases the maximum levy rates for both the AMLC and AMLRDC components as follows: cattle from $6 to $18; sheep from 60c to $1.50; lambs from 60c to $1.50; buffalo from $6 to $18; goats from 60c to $1; calves from $2.10 to $6.30; and bobby calves from 60c to $1.80. The Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill brings the same increases in the maximum levy rate as potential export charges. In addition, there is the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill. These two Bills seek to improve existing arrangements for the collection of registration charges in establishments processing fish and poultry for export.
