The amendments allow more equitable arrangements for registration charges to be collected from small establishments. These are technical amendments which have the support of the industry and the Opposition, and I will not refer to them again.

I wish now to concentrate on the major issues in this series of Bills. First is the change to the annual general meeting voting procedure. In 1984, the then Minister for Primary Industry, the present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), introduced a requirement for an annual general meeting for the meat and livestock industry of Australia so that there could be a form of participatory democracy whereby the AMLC was made accountable to the meat producers of this country. I believe that it was an honest attempt by the Minister to provide the possibility of a mass form of accountability and democratic participation. However, it has not worked. In fact, it has now become a farce. It has not worked for two reasons: First, the problem of the level of industry participation in it, and secondly, the voting procedure used.

With the level of industry participation, there are about 76,000 meat producers in this country eligible to participate in this annual general meeting, so one can understand that if they all wanted to participate, it would be rather hard to find a meeting place. In 1985, there were 36,000 voter registrations-registrations of producers which would entitle them to vote. By 1987, with the annual general meeting coming up in December, it is now under 20,000 and the number of those who in any way took advantage of this, either by proxy or attendance in the last annual general meeting was, I understand, about 10,000. There is also the additional problem, as there always is with proxies, that there is no flexibility to participate in the process of the debate and any sort of amendment that might be possible. Overall, on that basis alone, the scheme is impractical.

The absurdity comes in with the voting procedure used. There are two separate rolls-one for producers and one for processors. At present, 75 per cent of producers registered and 75 per cent of processors registered must vote against a meat and livestock levy motion to defeat it, and that is a completely impractical voting procedure. The amendment that we are considering today is that 75 per cent of those voting-that is, by proxy or in person-must vote against the AMLC proposed motion for a levy increase to defeat it. In practical terms, that means that only 25 per cent of voters on one of the two rolls-the producer roll or the processor roll-needs to support the motion for it to be carried. If we apply that back to the 1985 annual general meeting, when, I am advised, 29 processors were registered, one would need only eight of them voting in favour of a motion to carry it. At the same time, one could have 22 registered processors basically against the motion, let alone all the unregistered processors, and 76,000 meat producers against the motion, but eight processors carry the day. That is the height or the depth of absurdity, and what is more, it is wrong in principle. Surely, the standard procedure, if one is to follow the annual general meeting principle, is 50 per cent of those voting, either present or by proxy and voting in favour-in other words, a simple majority of those entitled to vote-must carry the day.

I hope that the Minister has the ability to admit that the experiment has failed. So far, by this amendment, that does not appear to be case. Parts of the industry were always opposed to this proposal, but were prepared to accept it as a pilot. That is fine, but it has now failed, and it is significant that the Minister, to my understanding, has not extended that same concept to any of the other statutory marketing authority rearrangements in which he has been engaged.

There are other problems with this annual general meeting concept. There is the cost of maintaining the register and of holding the annual general meetings. There are the restrictive requirements, because of the way that the levy motion debates are structured. The industry wants an accountable procedure so that it is possible to have practical arrangements for the discussion and the determination of levy motions. It does not want tinkering from one level of absurdity to a slightly lower level of absurdity, which is what we have with this amendment. My predecessor, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), when he was referring to this absurdity, on a number of occasions indicated that the coalition parties in government would consult the industry to change the present absurd voting requirements and procedures to a system which was practical. In an amendment which I shall be moving at the end of this second reading debate, I shall be showing that the coalition parties believe that a more sensible arrangement is one somewhat similar to that already in place with a number of other statutory marketing authorities. We give notice to the appropriate organisations, that is the Cattle Council of Australia, the AMLC, the Sheep Meat Council and the processors that we will be discussing a more appropriate form of industry accountability and determination than is presently the case. For that reason, at the end of this speech I will move for substitution of the following words:

whilst not opposing the Bill, the House is of the opinion that recommendations for levy changes in future should be made direct to the Minister by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation only after it has consulted with the appropriate industry organisations.

I now move to the overall major problem facing the livestock industries of this country at present; that is, the proposal to increase the maximum levy rate from $6 to $18 per head for adult cattle, or more correctly, the reason why such a dramatic increase in the maximum rate is contemplated and is not being opposed by the Opposition or the industry. The current operative levy rate is $3.30 per head for adult cattle and the maximum rate is $6. It was known before the residue problem occurred that increased promotion expenditure was necessary and therefore one could understand that the $6 maximum rate would probably not be sufficient and if ordinary practice were followed and ordinary conditions applied the new maximum rate would be doubled by legislation, to $12. But the chemical residue problem has altered the situation. Hence, we now have the frightening prospect for individual cattle producers in this country of moving at some stage potentially to paying up to $18 per head, because the proposal that is before the industry at the moment for residue testing and potential buy back et cetera, over a three-year period, could involve over $100m.

However, the levy proposal itself is the least frightening aspect of the total residue problem. First of all, there is the potential problem of our export markets. Beef in particular is one of the great export industries of this country. It has a very big potential in the future because there is an ability to increase export tonnage and there is a growing world demand. So the threat to this industry is the first great problem that this residue problem has created. The second is the reduced prices to individuals. Even if the markets remain open-and thank goodness they have, and they will-there is still a reduction in the market price. The graphs in some of the weekly rural newspapers show the impact of that already because the image of Australian meat overseas has been damaged and logically there is a discount by buyers in the market because of the uncertainty and because of their cash flow problems coming from the cost of testing and so forth. There are already 340 farms in Australia which have been quarantined because of the level of chemical residue in their soil. Those farms have a frightening future of dramatically reduced income because they really have no future in the medium and short term for producing and selling livestock. This carries with it the potential of devastation to rural communities where the cattle industry is important and where processing works are an important part of town employment. It has to be understood by people who are not actively affected by the chemical residue problem that the standard of living of all Australians is reduced if our export markets for this great industry are affected.

When the industry was faced with this residue problem it responded magnificently and it is responding magnificently now. It got on with the job of restoring the credibility of the product and guaranteeing the purity of the product. A voluntary levy has been put in place to cover the cost of residue testing until the AMLC annual meeting in December. That, incidentally, highlights again the lack of flexibility of the annual general meeting procedure and requirements. There is a co-operative attack on the problem. The Australian quarantine service, the Cattle Council, the Meat and Live-stock Corporation and the exporters all have co-operated and responded remarkably well.

The procedure being followed involves testing of every lot of livestock sold for export, at a cost of about $40 per lot. That highlights the extra cost that is incurred by the industry, particularly in some States, including my own, where the average lot size is quite small. That follows through the tail tagging and the tracing back to the properties, which in turn is building up a computer picture of the level of chemical residues on every farm in Australia from which livestock is sold. As I said earlier, my understanding is that well over 300 farms have already been pinpointed as having such levels of chemical residue in their soils, and they have been quarantined. Those measures have been put in place rapidly and once the process has been finalised Australia will be able to guarantee the purest meat products of anywhere in the world. That will be in the next few months. I think that is a tremendous achievement by an industry.

That brings me to the specific motions on the levy at the AMLC annual meeting to be held on 3 December. As I said, the voluntary levies in place at the moment vary from, I think, $1.50 in one State to $3 in several to $5 in Queensland. The AMLC proposal is for a levy of up to $5 for residue testing and buying back as necessary of any meat exported before 25 May and $3 for promotion. Once the residue testing requirements are reduced, the level of the levy will be reduced to reflect that. That will provide a total operative rate of $11.30 out of the maximum possible rate of $18. If this legislation is passed the levy will commence on 1 January and I think it will be about April next year before any of the moneys start flowing back through the system. That will be a heavy burden on producers. It will mean that the total commitment by the livestock industries to the AMLC in one form or another will increase dramatically to about $75m per year, of which about $35m per year-at least in the first year-will be for residue testing. At the meeting in December the Sinclair Hill proposal for boosting promotion also will be considered, as will changing the way in which levies are collected from a per head basis to a percentage of sale value basis. I understand that there is support for investigation of what the percentage method would bring and what equity it would give to those in the industry. I would support the investigation of that method.

The fundamental question that the cattle and sheep producers-particularly cattle producers-meat exporters and primary industry people in general are asking is: Why should the meat producers of this country have to pay the full amount for that testing? If the coalition were in government, they would not be paying for any of the export testing costs, including those increased residue testing requirements which are essential for export and therefore are an integral part of the export inspection system. There are two reasons why the coalition supports industry people in saying that they should not be required to bear the full cost: first, even with the present Government's policy-I noticed the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy evidently does not like this so he is leaving the chamber-for export inspection charges, the Government states that it will meet 50 per cent of the cost. That is Government policy and residue testing is an essential export inspection procedure. It has been put into place in the export works and therefore the Government, with its existing policy, should automatically cover 50 per cent of that additional cost required for residue testing.

On 22 September I asked the Minister in this place: `Why has the Government not automatically accepted its responsibility as it should? Why has it not acceded to the request made by the Cattle Council to do so?' At that stage the Minister indicated that the Government was still considering the matter. Some five weeks later the Government has given no indication that it will live up to its level of responsibility in meeting 50 per cent of the export inspection charge. The Government has to understand that if it wants to regain and maintain good relations with farmers and farmer organisations it must be consistent with its policy. If it indicates that it will meet 50 per cent of the inspection costs it must stick to that. When it comes to other things, like wool promotion, when it says one day that it will meet a certain percentage it must stick to it the next day. If the Government does that it might once again achieve some sort of credibility with the farmers of this country-which it does not have at present while it keeps breaking its promises.

I refer again to the policies that were separately enunciated by the National Party and the Liberal Party during the last election campaign-which were identical-namely, that a coalition government would cover 100 per cent of export inspection charges, because we recognise that it is a national responsibility as part of improving and assisting the export capability of this country. Who created this residue problem? It certainly was not the farmers. They are not to be blamed in any way for the residue problem, because they were carrying out the recommendations of the State departments of agriculture on the use of chemicals which were legal and which they were advised by those State departments to use. A really genuine and severe criticism of the State governments of this nation and of the State departments of agriculture is necessary for what could at least be called lethargic behaviour and for what could also be called irresponsible behaviour in not moving to ban certain chemicals such as DDT and dieldrin which have been known for some time to not be acceptable in the United States. The Federal Government should also be blamed, because through the Australian Agricultural Council and other means it should have been pushing harder on these points.

This raises the second reason for being sympathetic towards and assisting the meat producers. They are also being forced, as part of this increased levy, to provide compensation for the buy back of certain types of meat that might not meet overseas requirements or which might not be cost beneficial if put through the testing regime. I think that the request by the industry for some form of government assistance is legitimate, particularly when it comes to the disposal of livestock on quarantine properties. I think it is a legitimate request for State governments to provide some compensation because, after all, it was the actions of those State governments which created the problem. With this in mind, at the appropriate time I will move a further amend-ment.

This brings me to another point of complaint by the industry and the lack of responsibility shown by the Government. I refer to the Government's forked tongue attitude on export assistance and the national residue survey. This is a national survey of foodstuffs undertaken by the Government. It covers both the domestic market and exports and, according to the Minister's Budget Statements it will cost $5m in a full year because of upgraded residue testing necessitated by the residue problem. I understand that tomorrow, following the Budget announcement, the Minister will put in place a ministerial order, reducing the percentage of the cost of that survey to be covered by the Government from 100 per cent to 50 per cent. I think that that is unbelievable, coming at a time when the meat industry in Australia is being faced with dramatically increased charges and when the Government claims that it is assisting export industries, and where for the domestic industry, just as much as for the export industry, it has a public health responsibility. The Government should accept that and it should not be imposing a sudden additional charge on the meat industry at this time.

Briefly, in conclusion, the legislation also allows the participation of the pork industry, the Australian Pork Corporation, with the innovative marketing arrangements of CALM and Ausmeat. I certainly congratulate the AMLC and the industry for bringing in these innovative marketing initiatives. I refer the Minister to a problem with a group of pig producers in the central west of New South Wales who feel that they are not getting the financial reward that they should from the Ausmeat trims that are allowed. I have raised this matter with the Ausmeat people, and they have assured me that they will be doing their best to overcome the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are very concerned.

—I understand from the member for Parkes that they are very concerned. One amendment to the legislation ends the requirement for the Ausmeat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee to produce an annual report. The most recent report that I have in front of me indicates that for the 1986-87 year it cost $63,000 to run that Committee. With the abolition of the requirement for this report, I hope that that does not mean the end of accountability for the cost of that Committee which would be available to the average meat producer. I hope that something appears in the AMLC annual report that continues to indicate that.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislative amendments also bring in the same equal opportunity-`equal opportunity' being the words of the Government-provisions which are already in place for wool and which will be coming in with wheat. As I have indicated earlier, the Opposition is unhappy with aspects of the legislation but is not opposing it as such. The exception to that involves the affirmative action clauses. They are completely unnecessary and they are an insult to the people in the designated groups, because anyone who is appointed from such a group would be considered to be a token appointment. It also interferes with employment arrangements for the specialist type of staff that are needed for such organisations. The Opposition makes a clear distinction between equal opportunity, which we support, and affirmative action or positive discrimination, which we oppose. Therefore, in committee we will move amendments to assert the clear distinction between equal opportunity which is the removal of discrimination and the provisions in these clauses of affirmative action which actually enforce discrimination. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not opposing the Bill, the House is of the opinion that recommendations for levy changes in future should be made direct to the Minister by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation only after it has consulted with appropriate industry organisations'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 and the associated Bills make a number of amendments to legislation affecting Australia's meat and livestock industry. I cannot help but begin my speech by referring to some of the latter comments by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) on the equal employment opportunity provisions that are part of this important package of legislation. As the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) said when he introduced the Bill in the House a couple of weeks ago, it is part of the Government's policy on the reform of statutory marketing authorities that there be a provision for an equal employment opportunity program. This program is to be incorporated in the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation's corporate plans and a progress report is to be included in the Corporation's annual report to Parliament. That is no only a sensible course of action but also a very long overdue action in recognition of the place of women in Australian rural life. This Government's attitude stands in marked contrast with that of honourable members opposite. Opposition members tend to overlook the very simple statistic that probably at least 50 per cent of Australian farms are run by women. The reality is that most farms are run as family farms and there is a partnership arrangement. The woman who performs part of that partnership is an integral part of the success of that operation. I believe it is appropriate to recognise that contribution. It is for that reason that the Government has moved, with the reform of statutory marketing authorities, to create a program of equal employment opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, we know the attitude of the National Party of Australia on matters such as equal employment opportunity and affirmative action. We have heard some almost landmark speeches by prominent members of the National Party in that respect. I remember the contribution some time ago by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron). His attitude on affirmative action and equal employment opportunity was summed up by his phrase that a woman's place was in the kitchen or the other room, or a similar remark. It seems that the influence of the honourable member for Maranoa and some of the other troglodytes as to the place of women and their contribution to Australian agriculture is still very much a prominent part of National Party thinking when it comes to deliberating on such important legislation. I do not want to dwell on this aspect. I simply make the point that I find it amazing that in this era, in 1987, that attitude still pervades the National Party. Perhaps that is part of the reason why the National Party suffered very profoundly in the recent election.

The honourable member for Murray said that our relationship with farmers and farmer organisations may be placed at risk because of certain provisions that are included in the Bill; that somehow we have lost a great deal of credibility with farmers, farmer organisations and the rural community generally. The honourable member conveniently forgets what happened in this country on 11 July. On that date the Government not only was returned to office with an increased majority but also held all its rural seats, many with an increased majority, and gained at least three other rural or semi-rural seats-Hinkler and Fisher in Queensland, and that of the Northern Territory.

If that does not suggest that we have credibility in our relationship with farmers, farmer organisations and the rural community generally, I am at a loss to understand what the word `credibility' means. This Government, largely through the efforts of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, has established a great deal of credibility among people in the rural scene. I pay particular tribute at this stage to my friend and colleague the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), who was the chairman of the country task force established by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The honourable member played a very significant role during the period of the last Government and led, significantly, an all-party delegation to the United States of America at a very critical time. His role in terms of credibility in the rural sector is worth remembering.

The question of statutory marketing authorities has exercised the Government's mind for a number of years. We consider that effective and innovative marketing is essential to ensuring that we have a better and sound performance by the farm sector. Obviously, we have to react to changed circumstances and, sometimes, circumstances that are cruelly inflicted upon us. The honourable member for Murray drew the House's attention to that point with his reference to the chemical residue difficulties that this nation faces. I think that all honourable members would recognise that that is a cause of great concern throughout rural Australia. It is certainly an issue that has not made for partisan politics. I think that, generally speaking, that is the way in which it has been viewed by people on both sides of the House. It is a national problem. We recognise that we need to react to it and do something about it if we are to preserve the integrity and the important export performance of our livestock industries. It is a serious matter that does not have any simple or short term answers. I commend the Minister on his initiatives so far. I also congratulate the industry generally on the responsible manner in which it has accepted the challenge to react to the very cruel circumstances in which we find ourselves.

The question of livestock export charges and slaughter levies is one that has always been contentious in this House. It has certainly been the case during the 4 1/2 years that I have been a member of the Parliament. National Party representatives in the Opposition have offered simplistic suggestions from time to time. Again, that demonstrates that promises are extremely cheap to deliver in opposition but, in very difficult economic circumstances to which the Government cannot necessarily find an easy solution, the Government cannot accept those simplistic solutions. The question of livestock slaughter levies and export charges certainly falls into that category. The National Party's standard response to such problems is to suggest that somehow or other the Government must react immediately and that it must bear a significant proportion of the responsibility. We certainly recognise our responsibilities, but we do not react in what I would call an agrarian socialist way, as we have seen on many occasions in this House by National Party members.

The solution is not an easy one by any means. But to suggest that the Government should react to the difficulties that have been thrust on us as a result of discoveries of chemical residues by suddenly going off on a new tack in terms of responsibility for these charges does not have any credibility. We need to examine the issue sympathetically; we need to monitor what is happening, and we need to consult with those in the industry who have been affected by what has happened. In the end, I do not think that simple solutions put forward by Opposition spokesmen will necessarily be embraced by the Government.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner this evening I had an opportunity to comment on two matters that I think are important in the consideration of this legislation. One related to clause 5 (g) of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill and concerned the policy of equal employment opportunity. The second matter about which I had a chance to make some remarks related to the whole approach to the very vexed question of the chemical residue problem in Australia. The Minister, in his second reading speech on the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill on 7 October, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: On the matter of pesticide residues, I would like to congratulate the industry on its preparedness to tackle the problem. The industry, apparently universally, accepts the need to get its house in order and to take whatever steps are necessary to re-establish its reputation as a supplier of nutritious product to the world's markets.
I think that those comments certainly would be echoed by members on both sides of the House.

I refer also to the Government's economic and rural policy document of 15 April last year on the consideration of the whole area of statutory marketing authorities. In that very well researched and well received document, the comment was made that for many years the issue of statutory marketing authority (SMA) reform had bedevilled governments which had been unable to strike the right balance between the conflicting interests involved. SMAs have been unsure as to when their accountability lay to Parliament and the Government, and when to industry. On the matter of identity crisis, and the whole approach to statutory marketing authorities, while it has not been necessarily solved to everyone's complete satisfaction, this Government can hold its head rather high. While some comments were made about changes in respect of some of the matters relating to the annual general meeting of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation, most honourable members would agree that, overall, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation has acted very responsively, under the leadership of Dick Austen, to innovative marketing. Certainly, the whole question of red meats in particular has been put back on the agenda.

I congratulate the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation for its efforts over the last few years. I know the Chairman particularly well. He brings to that position a very fine record in terms of his expertise in marketing. Generally speaking, most people would applaud the efforts of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation for doing its very best to promote the whole question of marketing of our livestock industries. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in the debate on the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill and the other Bills in this package, I would like to support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). I would also like to draw attention to a few points which have been raised by previous speakers about the importance of the livestock industry and also about how the industry has coped with a very difficult problem over the last few months, namely the residue problem. The honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) congratulated the industry. I endorse those words.

SPEECH.PARA: I also bring to the attention of honourable members a very interesting point that was raised in the annual report of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation. That report highlights the very aggressive role the Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation is taking in its attitude towards research in the meat industry and the way in which it is trying very hard to direct research into what would be normally called the applied area rather than the strategic area.

One of the very interesting points that is raised in that report is the fact that the Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation would like to reduce the cost of meat inspection by 30 per cent. It has set itself an objective which, obviously, it has not yet realised. In fact, the work has not even been started. It is very interesting that over some years it has been pointed out to this Government, and to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in particular, that the cost of meat inspection has been excessively high. It has been apparent to anyone who goes to an abattoir anywhere in the country that there is overmanning. We still have to do something about reducing that cost. I draw attention to that point.

The other point to which I refer in regard to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill is the amendment that is made to the voting procedure at the annual meetings of both the Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation and the Meat and Live-stock Corporation. At present 75 per cent of both the producers group and the exporters group must be present in order to negate a move to increase the levies or to pass a motion of no confidence in the Chairman of either Corporation. This has been changed to 75 per cent of those producers present, either in person or by proxy at the annual general meeting.

I raise this point because I well remember in 1984, when the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill was introduced, I pointed out to the Minister in the clearest possible terms that what he was proposing was unworkable. I guess it is to the Minister's credit that he acknowledged this point after the Bill had been passed by both Houses. He dropped me a line to say that, if the situation proved to be unworkable-which is what I suggested would happen-the Government would be prepared to review it. I guess it has taken three years, but at least the Government has belatedly recognised that point. Certainly, we welcome that fact, although I still question whether the procedures that have now been adopted will prove to be the ideal situation. I recognise that it is not easy to get the perfect situation, knowing full well the concerns that the Minister expressed in 1984 about the voting procedure. I guess that this is a move in the right direction. I still wonder whether it will prove to be the best possible solution.

I think it is important to realise, though, that this residue problem has caused considerable consternation to individual farmers. Some farmers have had their properties completely quarantined because of this problem. It has proved to be a very serious and financially costly handicap-or will be, if a solution is not found. I suggest that, while it is very important for the industry as a whole to clear its name on this residue problem so that our export markets will be maintained and can be kept open, it is equally important to help individual farmers who, in many cases through no fault of their own, are paying a very heavy price for the residue problem.

I also emphasise very strongly to honourable members that this so-called residue problem, while serious, should not cause concern to the general public, to the consumers, because there is no doubt that, by any measure, the residue levels that are tolerated in meat are at a very low level, of the order of 0.3 parts in a million. At that rate, even if people were eating meat right on that level, they would have to eat about a tonne at a time, almost at a sitting, for it to have any real effect on them. So, this matter has been blown up out of proportion in some respects. Nonetheless, it is important to recognise that the industry has moved very quickly and very effectively to correct the matter.

There is another matter I would like to raise, which the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) drew to the attention of the House last night; that is, the misconception that has been going around the community for some years now about the fat and cholesterol levels of red meats compared with those of chicken. Unfortunately for the Australian consumer and the Australian meat producer, a myth was created which was based mainly on American figures produced mostly from lot-fed beef, namely, that somehow Australian beef would be the same and therefore would have higher fat and cholesterol levels than those in chicken. At long last, some of those figures have been exploded very effectively, so effectively that I notice that spokesmen for the chicken industry are screaming because it is hurting.

I will give a couple of quick examples. A piece of cooked rump steak, in the category of lean beef-which is grass-fed beef-has a fat content of about 6.7 grams per hundred. This compares very favourably with chicken breast with the skin on-which is the way most people eat it, although the chicken industry is very quick to say otherwise-which has a fat level of 12.7 grams per hundred. That is almost double. It is very important that consumers be made aware of this.

Also, comparing lean beef in a piece of rump steak with chicken, the cholesterol levels in milligrams per hundred grams are 82 for rump steak and 99 for chicken breast with skin. In other words, a piece of rump steak has lower fat and cholesterol levels than ordinary breast chicken. When it comes to the iron level, there is a much higher iron level in beef than in chicken. Iron is very important in everyone's diet. Rump steak has 3.9 milligrams of iron per hundred grams, compared with 0.7 milligrams for chicken. By any measure, not only are red meats healthier than chicken; they are also far more nutritious. Hopefully, that point will now be brought home to the Australian public. Meat producers have been made to pay for a myth that was created but is quite erroneous.

I would like to remind honourable members about the importance of the beef industry. To put it into perspective, it is one of our biggest export earners. In fact, it is our third biggest primary producing industry, earning last financial year $1,900m in export revenue. This was up 23 per cent on the previous year, which in turn was up 23 per cent on the year before that. Not only is it a good export earner; it is a growing industry, increasing its earnings for Australia, particularly overseas earnings which are so important because of our balance of payment problems. The industry needs all the encouragement it can get. There is a move to increase levies for the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation, for its general operating expenses and promotion. It is important that producers support the levies at the coming annual general meeting which will be held, I think, in Albury in early December.

It is also extremely important that producers be prepared to support the increase in levy for research because, again, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation has demonstrated in a relatively short time that it is determined that research will be very much directed towards what I call the applied area; in other words, somewhere in the short to medium term results will be achieved for the industry. I congratulate the Research and Development Corporation on the way it has moved from straight production research and is shifting 50 per cent of its effort towards marketing. It is quite clear that already we are starting to see results from that. It is to be encouraged. I do that with the proviso that it is still important that Australia maintain a very strong strategic research effort, the sort of research we are looking at in the longer term, the sort of research on which the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has established its world-wide reputation.

Obviously, it is very difficult when a project is started to know what the pay-off is going to be. Results may not be found for 10 to 15 years. That sort of research still has to be encouraged, but the present moves by the Research and Development Corporation into getting better direct results will build the confidence of producers who are paying 50 per cent of all the research fees and will encourage them to support more research. There is no doubt that the industry will reap the rewards in the medium to long term. Some of the developments that have already occurred really are quite astounding. There is no doubt that, as they unfold, the industry will benefit. If the industry benefits, obviously Australia will benefit.

In concluding these remarks, again I remind honourable members of the importance of the meat and livestock industry. It is one of Australia's great industries and great export earners. Its contribution has been very positive over a number of years. It has demonstrated its resilience and ability to cope with the very difficult residue problem. All parts of the meat chain are to be commended for the way they moved so swiftly to rectify that problem. I am sure that, with the ability and drive of the people who are now leading the industry, it will go a long way. But I just point out that some producers have been hit very hard financially because of the residue problem-in many cases for reasons not of their making. It is very important that those producers not be penalised for something they did not do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members will be aware, my electorate of Capricornia is centred on the cattle capital of Australia; that is, Rockhampton. So, it is understandable that any legislation which affects the meat and livestock industry is of special interest to many of my constituents and to me. I have had the opportunity to canvass the amendments now before the House with leaders of the cattle industry, in particular. I refer to the Cattlemen's Union of Australia (CUA) and the United Graziers Association (UGA).

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to say that there is general support for the Government's proposals. There is a clear appreciation within the UGA and the CUA that levies on producers are necessary if certain industry roles are to be carried out and performed by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) on behalf of those producers. Moreover, cattle producers appreciate the need to provide additional funds as this time for residue testing. This matter was canvassed by the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) and the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). It is certainly necessary, in view of the events that we have experienced recently. I have noted, too, by talking to some grass roots members of the cattle industry, that there is strong criticism prevailing of the way the United States of America has applied the rules in the latest meat crisis. This teaches us a few lessons about the way the United States of America operates.

However, graziers accept the need to give the Australian meat industry a clean bill of health on our international markets. That is why they will support and accept, regardless of the cost, the financial impediments placed upon them, and the levies, to ensure that our meat is clear of any residue. The producers I have spoken to accept the Government's decision to set a maximum levy for residue testing on cattle producers of $5 per animal slaughtered. They made the point that that is a lot of money but they are also very hopeful, as they believe the problem will be overcome in a matter of two or three years, that that levy should drop. They have also suggested, because of that expectation, that there be some type of review or sunset clause. I have explained to them that the AMLC does have that power, that what the Government has done is set a maximum, and that it is up to the AMLC, on behalf of those producers, to assess what is the financial requirement, what revenue they shall need, and set the levy accordingly. There is a belief that the residue will be eliminated and therefore the cost of testing will fall. I certainly hope that that is true. I think that will come about not only because of increased testing but also because of a new commitment amongst cattle producers. I hope that commitment flows across the general community because it has been demonstrated in recent times that it is not the graziers, it is not those on the land, who are necessarily causing the problem.

The Government has shown great wisdom in giving the AMLC the option or discretion to vary the breakup of the levy. It is always easy to criticise governments and say they are out of touch. When we give such a power to an organisation that truly represents producers, those who have to pay a very substantial part of this levy, that criticism is minimised. The Government certainly has set the maximum levy to be paid-I think that is proper-but it is up to the AMLC to set the levy components within that maximum and that is what this legislation is all about.

The proposition has been put to me that because of the need to give special emphasis to residue testing, maybe there is a case for the marketing and promotion component to be lowered at this time. Whilst I do not have any facts and figures to substantiate that argument, I promised the graziers to whom I spoke that I would at least put the argument forward. They are saying that the maximum cost of $8 is a burden upon them and whilst they appreciate that they need the $5 a head slaughtered, the idea of imposing a cost of $3 a head for marketing and promotion may not be necessary. They certainly felt that there was an argument for reducing that cost if the marketing and promotion component was dropped. This is up to the AMLC. I am sure that the Cattlemen's Union of Australia and the United Graziers Association of Queensland and their counterparts in other States would be only too pleased to argue this point at the AMLC level. Clearly, it is up to that body to balance the needs and set the priorities. There is a body of opinion which says that because the priority at this time has to be testing, that is where the money shall go.

Another area of interest that has been raised with me by the producers is funding options. This is a very important area because we are talking about the way the levy is calculated. Again I stress that the AMLC has the power to consider any alternatives to the present per head of cattle slaughtered system. As honourable members will be aware, what happens now is that the individual producer pays a levy based on the number of cattle that actually get slaughtered. Many people believe that is unfair. One might say, `As you sell your cattle and you have them slaughtered, you pay your way'. I accept the simplicity of that argument because it means that there is only one point for the collection of the levy or revenue. It is certainly easy to monitor. It can be done through the slaughterhouses or abattoirs. It is certainly easy to collect but we have to consider whether it is fair. A number of people have said to me that under the present system, regardless of what the graziers' financial return is on the animals sold, they pay the same levy. For example, someone could sell a 300 kilogram beast on the supermarket trade and get a certain figure for that beast. Another grazier from the same district could sell a 700 kilogram beast on the Japanese market. One can imagine that the returns would be quite different. Those involved in the export markets in Japan would get a substantially different return. Yet the producers still pay the same levy on the beasts. Whether they get hundreds of dollars for the sale of one animal or whether they get double that, they still pay the same levy. There is a great difference in return to the graziers yet the same levy is paid. I urge the AMLC to consider the alternatives. Some of these alternatives have been well presented by Sinclair Hill and others. They have suggested that we could have some type of system based on the dollar return to the grazier-an ad valorem approach. Others have suggested that there ought to be a combination of weight and cash return. It has been suggested to me that there ought to be some type of levy payment based on cents per kilogram rather than per head slaughtered. Whatever we come up with, we have to make sure that the administrative costs do not outweigh the advantage of the lesser payment by the producer.

At the same time, we must be looking for a fairer system and I hope that the AMLC, as it does have discretionary power, looks very carefully at the alternatives that exist, without incurring exorbitant administrative costs. It is always the fear that if we introduce a system we might bring in something that is very complex, that is very hard to monitor. Whilst it might be fairer up front in that one pays on the cash return one gets, or the weight of the animal sold, the final costs of running the system could be so high that it is not worth pursuing.

The industry seems content, otherwise, with the amending legislation before the House but I have been asked to raise a couple of other issues that affect it. I refer particularly to the ongoing moves by the southern States of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia to bring to a head on 1 January next year a significant change in the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign (BTEC). The eradication of brucellosis and tuberculosis (TB) is a very important campaign that has been supported right across the board by all sectors of the Australian cattle industry. The costs have been carried evenly across the industry, though I realise that a major part of the actual costs have been met by the Federal Government, and as well there has been a contribution from the States. The target for total eradication is 1992.

I accept that the impending date of freedom status for New South Wales and its southern counterparts has long been recognised to be 1 January 1988; in other words, January next year. But many producers in Queensland are questioning the timing of this. Admittedly they are taking a hip pocket approach, and a very parochial approach, but they are claiming, and I believe them, that this will adversely affect Queensland producers. It will certainly affect their costs in comparison with their New South Wales counterparts. We will find that whilst New South Wales will continue to pay the levy, there will be no testing fee. That testing fee has been worked out at about $10 per head. When one considers at the moment that there are 260,000 head of cattle crossing the border between Queensland and New South Wales, if it costs around $10 per head we are talking about an imposition of $26m on the Queensland cattle industry.

I suggest that not only is this an impost on the Queenslanders but also it could be an impost on the northern New South Wales meatworks at Casino, Lismore, Guyra, Gunnedah and even, apparently, Homebush in Sydney, which takes a lot of Queensland cattle. They will have to pay comparatively more for Queensland cattle than for New South Wales stock. I do not believe the store cattle they want will be available in New South Wales; they will still have to draw on Queensland supplies, and that means they will have to pay more.

We will see a virtual closure of the border between New South Wales and Queensland. Any stock coming from Queensland will have to be tested. The reason will be that New South Wales will have freedom status but Queensland will not. In a way, it is saying that Queensland as a whole will be declared dirty as far as brucellosis and TB are concerned. This will affect even those graziers who in some cases have been free of TB for 10 years. They will lose that individual free status. They are going to suffer the extra cost that that will mean, and they will also have to bear the cost and inconvenience of holding their cattle for two or three extra days.

It is understandable why Queensland graziers are concerned about this. I accept the fact that maybe the Queensland Government and primary industry Ministers over the years should have argued a lot harder against what was proposed, because it has been known that this new rule would prevail on 1 January. They have known, too, that some sort of cost would be borne by their producers. But we question-and I question on the industry's behalf-whether or not the rules will make the competition fair. I could argue against my own Queensland Government, saying that it ought to have been moving towards some sort of intermediate freedom status so that those areas that are free of tuberculosis and brucellosis would still be allowed to move their cattle into the New South Wales market; and I could argue that now that South Australia and the Northern Territory have come to some special arrangement providing the cattle move down one track, such an arrangement should be established for Queensland. But if we move ahead on that date, 1 January next year, which is only a few months away, there is a $26m cost on the Queensland market. That is the estimate of the Cattlemen's Union and it is backed up by the United Graziers Association of Queensland. I know that the BTEC groups have looked at all this and I know that this has been for years in the planning stage.

I suggest that there is another way. It has been estimated that there are only 200 to 300 properties in the far north of Queensland which still have a problem. I believe that somehow we could isolate that area and separate it from the rest of Queensland. We could set up an interim or intermediate status arrangement so that cattle can still move freely between Queensland and New South Wales. It is in the interests of the meatworks and the economies of the townships I mentioned before, and in the interests of the hundreds of graziers in Queensland in the south, central west and east of the State who supply the New South Wales market. Because of the effect on trade generally, I believe that this matter should be looked at.

I appreciate that Queensland is outnumbered because this matter will be decided by the primary industry Ministers in the various States. As one comes from the Northern Territory, one from Queensland and three from the south-one in South Australia, one in Victoria and one in New South Wales-with three against two, Queensland cannot win as it is in the minority. I query also whether the possible flow-on effect-and I suggest that it is a possible effect-is fair. If Queensland is declared effectively `dirty' when it comes to tuberculosis and brucellosis, because the border will be closed and there will still have to be testing, will that have any sort of effect on international marketing? Will it give New South Wales and the southern States a competitive marketing edge over Queensland?

It has been suggested to me by advisers that that is not the case, but it is a concern and fear of producers in my electorate. I know I can be condemned for taking a parochial view, but I do not apologise, because $26m is involved just as additional cost. When one works out the value of 260,000 head of cattle to the State of Queensland, we are talking about a lot of money. I reiterate that there is an important need for an interim status for parts of Queensland.

There is one other aspect that I want to raise in closing my remarks. I refer to the financial problems that are being faced by Queensland graziers who have affected herds. This Government has been very forthright in providing supportive compensation for those who have had to test and destroy and those who have to destock. But if a producer or grazier destocks his property, there is a time lapse that could amount to two or three years before that property is viable again. There could be three years of operating and maintenance costs before the property is back as a goer. Although the compensation is quite significant, it is whittled away. Therefore, there must be a new approach, a more flexible funding arrangement, a change in the rules, to allow these producers-and there are not many of them, but they are caught up in difficult financial circumstances-to draw on the rural adjustment scheme. At the moment they are not eligible. This proposition has been put forward by the Cattlemen's Union and I think also by the United Graziers Association, because they have as their objective the simple but proper task of trying to keep these producers in the industry.

I thought that was the final matter I wished to mention, but there is one other matter I wish to mention in the few final minutes I have left to me in this debate. It is also a matter that affects people in my area. This arises from a problem that has arisen from an interpretation by the Australian Taxation Office as to the application of capital gains on renewed leases. I am sure that this matter has been raised with most members of parliament who have rural electorates, but there seems to be some confusion and an anomaly developing. A lot of the problem arises from the Queensland land Act which provides that when a lease expires there is an immediate expectation that that lease will be renewed, that a new lease will eventuate. But, because of an interpretation by the Taxation Office, the new lease is being seen as a newly created asset. Even though it is the same property with the same owners, the interpretation now is that capital gains shall apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —What!

—The honourable member interjects, but I suggest that he talk to some of his own colleagues from country areas. I spoke to the United Graziers Association about this matter today. I talked to Baden Cameron, to Peter Morris in Longreach, and to Sean Coffey in Rockhampton. They all concur that this is a very serious problem that confronts them, because they are getting all kinds of different interpretations from the Australian Taxation Office. What is happening is that when they get a new lease that might cost $300 or $400. That is set down as the cost of the new lease. It may be a situation that will not happen very often but if in a year's time that property is sold for $250,000, that $250,000 is deemed to be total profit and will be subject to capital gains tax. I do not think that is what this Parliament meant when it introduced the capital gains tax. I totally support the concept of a capital gains tax, but I suggest that we need to clarify the situation. We need to review the application of the capital gains tax. Where leased land remains the property of the previous owner, capital gains should not apply. Where no new asset is created the capital gains tax should not apply. In conclusion, the proposed amendments certainly have the support of the cattle industry, the Cattlemen's Union and the United Graziers Association of Queensland, and they have my personal support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) raised a problem concerning pastoralists. I think he will find that that situation is exactly what is meant to apply. In fact, I remind him that immediately after the capital gains tax was introduced it was established that if a person operating a freehold business were to sell a lease of that business, the value of the lease premium would be deemed to be a capital gain on the day the business was sold.
—You are wrong.

—The honourable member tells me that I am wrong. The fact of life is that that has been publicised in a number of publications of leading accountants. That is the way the Commissioner of Taxation is dealing with that matter. It is not a matter of my being wrong; I am absolutely right in regard to the way the capital gains tax will be administered. We in the Opposition say that the capital gains tax was wrong. I do not know which matter the honourable member for Capricornia was referring to when he said I was wrong. Maybe he too is now coming to believe that the capital gains tax has implications for ordinary small business that he did not understand previously when the concept of the capital gains tax was sold to him by his Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, tonight we are speaking in the second reading debate on the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill and cognate Bills. These Bills all relate to increasing the cost of producing livestock in Australia. These Bills relate specifically to increasing costs resulting from the problems we are again having in that area. I have stood in this place time and time again to criticise the Government's meat inspection service. I am now directly involved in the business of health and day after day I say that Medicare is a disaster. However, the operation of Medicare is reasonable compared to the activities of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and its export inspection services, which are a double disaster. What a wonderful situation! It is much like the operation of this Government. The Government makes massive mistakes. It puts the country into debt. When it takes steps to reverse the horrible mistakes, it says that it is leading the world with its wonderful initiatives in running the country. We know all about that too. We find that the foreign investors are voting with their feet. They are leaving this utopia that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tells us they have got. Those investors believe that quality investments today exist in other parts of the world.

When we were in government the Department of Primary Industry (DPI) apparently managed to let people export kangaroo meat. That was eventually deemed to be the fault of the Minister, because of the old-fashioned principle of the Westminster system of government-a principle completely killed by this Government. The reality is that we got more DPI inspectors. The fact that the DPI had messed it up in the first place apparently qualified it for more jobs and more charges. Of course, now we have the problem of chemical residues. We see the Commonwealth Government running around to States such as Victoria and Western Australia and saying, `We have got the solution. We are going to give you more of our people. Let us take over'. In the case of Victoria, the Commonwealth is even offering the service at a discount compared to State charges. In fact, it will be more of the same incompetence.

We have to look at the evidence of incompetence in this particular area. I have a copy of the audit report of the Food Safety Inspection Services (FSIS) of the United States of America published in January 1987-six or seven months before the disaster of the discovery of chemical residues struck our meat industry. As I will show in a moment, it refers to things that it was doing out here in Australia in 1979, but the Department of Primary Industry still could not get it right. The Department is criticised at length in this report, which is signed by Robert E. Miller, Acting Assistant Inspector-General for Audit, United States Department of Agriculture, Office of Inspector-General. I will read a few extracts from this report. Quite frequently it mentions the FSIS. Page 9 talks about risk analysis of foreign inspection systems. It states:

If controls over these areas were sound, the Foreign Programs Division would have reasonable assurance that the meat products processed and exported from these countries to the United States were wholesome. The development of ``systems approach'' resulted from recommendations in an FSIS November 1979 Task Force Report.
This is when it told the rest of the world how it expected things to be managed at home. It goes on:

Other information, such as a country's yearly residue testing results submitted to FSIS by foreign officials, would also play a major role in the assessment process . . . Our review of Foreign Programs Division files and discussions with Division management officials showed that the ``systems approach'' had been implemented for approximately 24 countries.
On page 10 this report goes on to tell us:
We noted several systemic problems during visits to Australia and New Zealand which, in our opinion, were attributable to the lack of continuing work using the risk analysis systems approach.

In other words, FSIS was out here a year or so ago-this report was published in January 1987-noticing that things were not right in this country. No one can tell me that its officials came out here wearing trench coats and fedora hats. Our people knew they were here and no doubt told them of their concerns. Under the heading `Residue contamination: Use of Chemicals that were Prohibited or Restricted in the US' the report states:

We found that Australia and New Zealand were routinely using and, in some cases, not testing for animal drugs and pesticides which were not permitted for use in the US . . . In 1984, the Food and Drug Administration determined that Albendazol was carcinogenic, and its emergency approval was withdrawn effective January 15, 1985.

Yet in this paragraph the report tells us that Australia was still using that chemical during the time of the officers' visit. On page 12 under the heading `Differences in Residue Tolerance Levels' the report goes on:
Products exported to the United States must meet U.S. standards for residue levels.

During our review in Australia and New Zealand, we compared the U.S. and foreign countries' tolerance levels for various substances. We noted differences in the tolerance levels for six chemicals. For example, the U.S. tolerance for DDT was 5 parts per million in a sample of fat, and the Australian tolerance for the same substance was 7 parts per million in a sample of fat.
Honourable members should not think that the officials did not tell us that while they were here. On page 13 the report states:
Department of Primary Industry does not-
it is talking about Australia here-

monitor or follow up residue abuses reported to the individual states. We visited two Australian state government agriculture departments. We noted that in the State of Western Australia, suspect herds were not being quarantined. In the State of New South Wales, suspect herds were occasionally quarantined; however, there was no monitoring of the herds in quarantine by the state authorities to ensure that suspect herds were not moved or sold for slaughter.
Also on page 13 under the heading `Effectiveness of Foreign Sampling Plans' it states:

In Australia and New Zealand, we also examined the process by which samples for residue testing were determined. Both countries selected areas for sampling based on substance usage in a particular geographic area. However, the sampling plans do not meet FSIS statistical requirements.

The people criticised in that report are the people who are asking this Parliament tonight to give them higher inspection charges so that they will do the job better. There is not much evidence that they have done the job well in the past. They are a disaster, as are their efforts to take over Australia. They are trying that now, and they will win in Victoria because the farmers are letting a few lousy cents overcome their common sense, and that means that we will not even have a yardstick.

What are the costs? They were not even able to take notice of what the American importing officials required when they were out here and wrote this report, but now they tell us that they want to double and treble all the costs. That is their solution, just as it is that of everybody else in the system: `When we make a mess of it, give us more money and we will fix our mistakes'. We have this Treasurer who tells us the same sorts of things: `When we make a mess of things, give us the credit; in fact boom us up. I am the world's best Treasurer because I am now running around trying to patch up the mess I put Australia into'. What are the costs? At the moment, farmers pay a maximum $6 export charge-the old livestock inspection fee-on cattle. The meat inspectors want that increased to $18 maximum. They want that level of flexibility and there is only one certainty about that. We have been told before in this place that we do not have to worry because the figure is only a maximum and it will be a long time before we get there; but they always seem to get there in a heck of a hurry. It is not an amount of money that the farming community can afford.

I heard today that apparently the Government is relaxing a little bit as to whether it will contribute to the residual testing program and the compensation for the meat that is currently stacked in America because the Americans do not want it because we ignored the recommendations and the discussions that we had with the American officials; we had to wait until we had container loads of contaminated meat in America to take any notice. Now we want to blame the farmers for the inactivity, and the continued encouragement of, and allowance to use, chemicals that other parts of the world, particularly the importing countries, have banned. More importantly, while all that is going on, an efficient service is provided in my electorate. It probably does not include residue testing, but one can get a bullock inspected for local consumption in my electorate, by the Shire of Northam, for $3.20, not the $18 that this Bill suggests is necessary to meet half the cost at Federal level. One can get sheep tested for 40c whereas the maximum requested under this legislation is $1.50 to cover half the cost.

The point about it all is that the wrong people are being asked to pay. It would not be a bad idea if we had a levy on meat inspectors, and every time we allowed these horrid mistakes to occur, they paid the levy, they paid the increased cost. It is not a case where we should have to have the farmers of Australia paying to check every piece of meat-I know that it is not that, but lot testing-when it is a long time since they should have been encouraged to stop using these chemicals and the proper tests should have been done, and they should be done on the property. We have discovered in Western Australia that where power lines pass through farmers' properties, frequently the residue levels of dieldrin and other such chemicals are five times as high around those wooden electricity posts as they are on any other part of the property. That is, of course, because, as is typical, the electricity authority went through and all it was concerned about was protecting its posts. The cattle have grazed on that, and that has contributed to the quarantine of certain properties and a total loss of income for certain farmers. It is a problem, and the problem is increasing.

Now we have this quite remarkable situation in Victoria where the State Government, or more importantly, the State Parliament, because the Parliament threw the proposal out previously, is going to reconsider and do a New South Wales and hand the whole thing over to the Federal authorities. They are the people who have been responsible for all the things that I have just read from that American report. It is about time that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) let all Australians read that report. As I understand it, it has not been tabled and it has not been published, yet it would certainly have been in the hands of the Department since February, many months before the problems concerning this residue in meat in America, and subsequently in Japan, were actually identified.

The Victorian State Government tried once to get this somewhat expensive little problem off its hands-it was contributing 25 per cent of the cost of the fees and the rest of the costs were being met by the industry-and it failed, because at that time the farmers had the good sense to know that they needed a yardstick for efficiency and a yardstick for cost. But things did not work too well for the farmers because the Government had the last say. It took away the 25 per cent contribution and has now created a situation in Victoria for the farmers and the industry whereby inspection fees are higher than the half-price equivalent offered by the Commonwealth. But just how long do farmers think this half-price will last, and for how long will the half price that they are being promised be cheap?

I implore any farmers in Victoria who are listening to the debate tonight to rethink the position of their representatives, because their representatives and the leaders of the farming community in Victoria are now demanding that the Opposition reverse its position and vote for this legislation. They say that it will be cheaper. If they think it will be cheaper, they should talk to some of the people around Australia whose properties have been quarantined and who have no living at all because of the mess-up by the Federal Department of Primary Industries and Energy and its Export Inspection Service. It is a case of too little too late. The problem has to be resolved by the taxpayer, and on this occasion a very specific part of the taxpaying community; namely the meat producers and processors.

The Commonwealth Government, to empire build, is taking over the responsibility of a State government. There is no good reason why the Commonwealth should be involved in the inspection of locally consumed meat, particularly when there is evidence that, at a 100 per cent charge, certain authorities around Australia can do a good job. Let me assure honourable members that nobody has been in any health difficulty as a result of the inspection services of the Shire of Northam. There is no reason why the Commonwealth should take over that service. It is estimated that it will cost $6m or $7m to do so-and we are being told how hard things are. Things are not too hard when Commonwealth departments want to increase their sphere of influence.

How many Victorian meat producers have thought about the problem that they will have when there is one meat inspectors union in Victoria? We saw the tragedy of the Mudginberri abattoir where the workers wanted to work, where there was a market for the meat and where the State Government was prepared to give financial assistance in the circumstances. Who stopped it all? The Federal meat inspectors. They would not go on to the property and could not be forced to do so by this Minister. He was too frightened to do anything about that; Bill Kelty had told him that he was not allowed to. We know that the Federal Government even broke the law in that case, as was proved in the courts of this country. It then tried to sneak in through the back door and change the law. Thank goodness we have a Senate that was able to stop that.

What will be the reality if the Victorians give away this inspection service? I know that Mr Burke, the Western Australian Premier, would dearly love to give his meat inspection services to the Commonwealth also, but I think we in Western Australia have a bit more intestinal fortitude to fight it a little longer at least, and it will certainly be what I urge. If the Victorian farmers think they can save a few cents now and that they will get in front by accepting the services of the Commonwealth, they have another think coming. They will see ever-escalating costs. The Minister has been reported in articles in the National Farmer as saying that it is his intention eventually to achieve a situation where 100 per cent of inspection charges are levied against the farmers. That is the message, and one never knows how far the Government will get. It is unbelievable that the Victorian industry would be so foolish as to contemplate giving away its independence in this way and hand it over to a group of people who have consistently failed Australia on these matters. They failed Australia on the substitution racket; we know how many of them were in it. I remind the House that I went to the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry and gave my evidence in relation to solutions that might come forward. I was attacked by the Queen's Counsel representing the meat inspectors, who said, `But look at all the corruption you would have if there were private enterprise meat inspectors'. I said, `What do you think this inquiry is all about? Taking the Government dollar certainly has not guaranteed the integrity of your members'. They let us down then, and the evidence in this American audit report is that they let the Australian farming community and the Australian nation down again over chemical residues. Through this legislation they want the producers to pay up to fix the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill, the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill, the Live-Stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill, the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill. The introduction of these Bills is further proof of this Government's efforts to increase exports by reducing red tape. Australia's overseas trade can only be improved by moves to make statutory authorities more responsive to market demands.

SPEECH.PARA: In this cognate debate, I wish to direct my remarks to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill and the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill. This is due to the importance of the beef industry to the Australian economy and within my own electorate of Rankin.

During 1986-87, export revenue from the beef industry amounted to about $2 billion-an increase of 23 per cent on the previous year's figures. Two of the main factors accounting for the improvement was the industry's ability to take advantage of a devalued dollar and improved marketing campaigns. Over 550,000 tonnes of beef and veal were exported last year, with the majority going to four major markets-the United States of America, Japan, Canada and Taiwan. The United States is by far the largest market, importing 340,000 tonnes of beef in 1986-87-an increase of 19 per cent on 1985-86.

I am sure that the future outlook of the Australian beef industry is bright. Exports are running strongly, domestic consumption is improving and the size of the national beef herd is increasing steadily. The industry seems to be in a good position to utilise any further fluctuations in our exchange rate and openings in foreign markets. However, the image of the industry has been dealt a severe blow with the discovery of pesticides and antibiotic residue in shipments of Australian beef to both the United States and Japan.

The first shipment of contaminated meat was found in the United States on 30 January of this year. Nine shipments were rejected before the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service implemented a more stringent testing system on 25 May. By comparison, there was only one detection of chemically contaminated meat in the United States in 1986. Following the findings in America, Japanese authorities discovered five residue violations in Australian beef. Four of the cases had been produced prior to 25 May and contained dieldrin and DDT. The other shipment was produced just after that date. While no export restrictions were imposed by either the United States or Japan, the chemical residue crisis posed a serious threat to the meat trade.

I am pleased to say the Federal Government was quick to act on this issue. A national action plan has been implemented and it provides $600,000 for publicity and testing of meat in America. A program co-ordinator has been appointed in the United States and inspection staff have been employed to supervise sampling. The States have passed laws concerning sales and use of organochlorine pesticides, especially DDT, and a procedure for testing and traceback of infected stock has been introduced.

The Federal Government has also increased funding to the national residue survey as another means of tightening up on testing of Australian meat. The survey was established to ensure that Australian beef met American requirements, and over the past two years over 3,400 tests have been carried out. Last year's budget for the survey was only $1.3m, and this has been increased to nearly $6m for 1987-88.

The three livestock Bills currently before the House are also part of the Federal Government's strategy of improving the image and efficiency of the Australian beef industry. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill's main aim is to streamline the operation of the Meat and Live-stock Corporation. Both the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill and the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill will impose charges-one on the export of livestock and the other is to be levied on slaughter at abattoirs.
