The charges will raise funds for increased market promotion, research and, in the case of cattle and buffaloes, bovine disease eradication. Funds raised under the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Bill will also enable the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation to purchase and dispose of meat which runs a high risk of being contaminated by pesticide residue. Money will also be provided for any programs which the Corporation undertakes to avoid a repetition of the chemical residue crisis. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation has developed a five-year plan to take advantage of the extra revenue raised. The plan calls for a more efficient marketing and promotion system. Moves have been made with the establishment of two systems-Ausmeat, an organisation responsible for quality standards, and CALM, computer assisted livestock marketing.

More emphasis needs to be placed on the need to identify and develop new marketing opportunities. To this end, promotions will concentrate on foreign markets. This accounts for about 53 per cent of all beef and veal sales. Successful domestic advertising campaigns which have increased meat consumption will be used as role models. Priority will be given to advertising in the four major meat markets-the United States, Japan, Canada and Taiwan-and also in developing markets such as South East Asia and Africa. It is a good insurance policy for Australia to develop further markets, particularly in light of the increasing protectionism of many of our major buyers.

One outstanding possibility is the Pacific region, destined to become one of the fastest growing economic regions in the world. For example, Korea has been importing in excess of 50,000 tonnes carcass weight per year. There is also an increasing demand for Australian beef in Japan and the United States, despite import controls. The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation has already introduced an advertising campaign for the Middle East. The campaign is similar to the successful short cuts campaign in Australia. Advertisements will appear in all media emphasising the quality of Australian beef. If successful, the campaign will regain ground lost to subsidised imports of the European Economic Community (EEC). In 1977-78 the Middle East imported 75,000 tonnes of Australian beef, a figure which had decreased to only 2,500 tonnes in 1985-86.

Unfortunately, the Australian beef industry's long term prospects will be affected by factors over which it has no control. Protectionist measures are currently being considered by the American Congress. The United States Trade Bill contains provision for extension of rural subsidies, import quotas on lamb and further reduction in the purchases of sugar cane. Many Australian farmers and marketing authorities blame the undermining of world prices of grain, especially wheat, on the readiness of the United States to subsidise domestic produce. The same undermining is likely to happen in the international beef industry if the United States subsidies are approved. The United States has already cut imports from September of this year. The Australian Government agreed in September to cut back on beef exports to 327,500 tonnes. By agreeing to the restriction the Government stopped the imposition of an import quota which would have cut Australian exports to the United States to 282,500 tonnes.

Another destabilising factor on the world markets may be the changes in dairy policy, particularly from the United States and the European Economic Community, which both face the major problem of oversupply of dairy products. The EEC has decided to reduce this problem by slaughtering 2.5 million dairy cows. This will lead to an increase in the amount of manufactured beef on the world market. There is a long term need for the reform of world agriculture policies. Australia has taken a leading role in this area with the formation of the Cairns group. At this point I pay tribute to the previous Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, for the efforts he put into the formalisation of the Cairns group.

However, despite the fact that international markets are dominated by protectionist policies, Australia still managed to increase its sales of beef last year. This is due in no small part to the forward planning of both the Federal Government and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation in protecting access to Pacific markets. It is vital to the future of the Australian beef industry that the Andriessen-Kerin agreement continue. This agreement prohibits the EEC from selling subsidised beef in a number of our major markets in the Pacific region. It is expected that Australia's beef production levels will be around 1.5 million tonnes in the 1990s. This is some 50,000 tonnes more than at present. New markets have to be identified and developed to absorb the surplus. Australia needs to export more beef to convince the world that we have the best beef product available. It is particularly important in Japan, where the Japanese consumer has been given the impression that grain fed fatty beef is preferable to the lean beef that comes from the Australian market. I am sure that if the Australian Government put that effort into making the Japanese buyer aware of the much higher quality of Australian beef, that market could develop considerably. However, we have to be very conscious of the enormous trade pressures on Japan from the United States to accept imports to bring about a balancing of the trade differentials between those two countries.

I am pleased that this Government has taken the necessary steps to increase the funds available to Australian beef authorities to allow this to happen. Money raised from the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill will play a great part in promoting the public image of Australian beef. If we are to remain a major world trading partner we should promote our beef throughout the world, not only in our existing markets but also in new markets. Promotion is the key to success. I commend the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) for introducing these Bills, and I commend them to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a raft of Bills tonight-the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill, the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill, the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill-concerned with amending much of the legislation dealing with the meat and livestock industry in Australia. Central to these discussions is the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) and all the bodies and organisations that go with it, such as Ausmeat, computer aided livestock marketing (CALM), the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation was established in 1977 under an Act of Parliament and has a full time staff of 185, which is up from 168 last year. Basically, the AMLC has as its goal to set up the best marketing system it can for those in the livestock industry, whether they be producers, processors or sellers. This involves activities such as identifying both present and potential consumers of our livestock products, and supplying them with the product they want in the best and most efficient manner possible. Not only do Australian producers supply virtually all of this country's domestic market, but Australia has become the world's leading exporter of both meat products and livestock. In the 1986-87 financial year the value of our meat exports reached $1,900m, which was an increase of 23 per cent on the previous year. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two short tables from the AMLC annual report showing the beef and veal export markets and the lamb export markets for the last financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. When we look at those tables we can see that we exported some 554,000 tonnes of beef last year, which was up from 468,000 tonnes the previous year, which is a healthy lift. However, there is one note of concern in the beef table, in that 81 per cent of our exports went to just two countries, and 92 per cent of our exports went to just four countries. Therefore we are somewhat vulnerable to having our exports slashed if one or two of those countries withdrew or substantially wound back their imports for whatever reason.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the AMLC should give a high priority-as I am sure it does-to expanding exports to other countries as rapidly as it can as some sort of insurance policy. It is interesting to note that apart from the four main countries listed in the table, that is, the United States of America, Japan, Canada and Taiwan, only three other countries, namely the United Kingdom, Hong Kong, and interestingly enough, Papua New Guinea, take more than 5,000 tonnes each.

The lamb industry increased its exports marginally last year from 49,350 tonnes to 52,900 tonnes. That industry is not in quite the same situation as the beef industry. It exported 79 per cent of its product to four countries. I believe there is enormous potential for it to export to many other countries in increasing quantities, particularly once we can educate countries, such as Japan and the United States of America, which seem to have some prejudice against eating lamb, which is only very slowly being broken down. It is interesting to note that the United Arab Emirates is now Australia's biggest purchaser of chilled lamb. Mutton exports last year were up from 94,000 tonnes to 110,000 tonnes, and Japan and Iran are by far the biggest importers of our mutton.

We exported 3,000 tonnes of buffalo last year, mainly to West Germany. We exported 4,900 tonnes of goat meat, mainly to Taiwan and the Caribbean. We exported only 3,356 tonnes of pig meat, although that was triple the 1,032 tonnes of the year before. Most of last year's tonnage went to New Zealand, interestingly enough, and the United States. So I think there is big potential to increase exports of pig meat.

We exported 49,000 tonnes of fancy meats, which was up 9,000 tonnes on the previous year's effort. In total, we exported over three-quarters of a million tonnes of meat, the exact figure being 770,579 tonnes, which was up from the 658,035 tonnes of the year before.

As well as in carcass meats, we lead the world in livestock exports. Last year we sent 7.7 million live sheep, mainly wethers and a few rams, to the Middle East for slaughter. That figure was up from 6.3 million the year before. Most of that increase came about because Libya re-entered the market with an order of 780,000. Also Algeria came in for the first time with an order of half a million. I believe that that figure could be doubled in the near future. As well as live sheep for slaughter, we sent away a modest 12,600 breeding sheep, which consisted mainly of first-cross ewes to Algeria. Some 60,000 cattle went away for slaughter. Most of those would go through a feed lot before they would be slaughtered overseas. Twenty-one thousand breeding cattle were sent away. Forty-four thousand goats went overseas, which is a surprisingly high figure. This returned something like $15m, so that is a growing industry. As well as that, we exported close to 4,500 buffaloes.

The domestic market, of course, is still our most important market. Last year we slaughtered 630,000 tonnes of beef, 240,000 tonnes of lamb and 120,000 tonnes of mutton. It is interesting to note that the average Australian now eats 39 kilograms of beef and veal each year, 15 kilograms of lamb and seven kilograms of mutton. That adds up to 61 kilograms of red meat per year. I am pleased to note that the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation is trying to reverse the steady decline in consumption, especially in beef, that has been taking place in recent years. It has been doing this in a whole host of manners, which is quite impressive when one reads its annual report. For example, its short cuts advertising program, as it was called, which was mainly shown on city television over the last 12 months or so, is now starting to bear fruit. It is taking note of the fact that 60 per cent of married women now work full time or part time and that 50 per cent of homes have a microwave oven installed in them and that, therefore, meal preparation these days must be increasingly geared for speed and convenience. This advertising program has been directed towards those ends.

As well, the AMLC has been pushing the nutritional value of red meat in particular. Contrary to popular belief red meat has on average only about half the fat and cholesterol of chicken meat. I spoke in the adjournment debate last night about that matter and I have noticed that speakers, I think on both sides of this House, have highlighted it in this debate tonight. This is simply a myth that has been perpetuated in this country over the last three or four decades. I am delighted to see at last that accurate scientific studies have been done in Australia and that the reverse has been established. No doubt it will take some time for the message fully to sink in, but the Australian people can eat trimmed red meat with full confidence.

The aim of the AMLC is to increase the use of meat served in meals per household rather than increase the amount of meat eaten per meal. To that end, the AMLC has used a lot of promotional material. I see that it sent out such material to 85 per cent of the fresh meat retail outlets in Australia, which includes 6,800 butchers and some 1,500 supermarkets. In addition, material has been sent to schools, which I think is a good, long term investment. Material has also gone to 40 per cent of the waiting rooms of general practitioners' surgeries around Australia, which is some 3,200 waiting rooms. The Corporation has been involved with sporting bodies and it has consulted the National Heart Foundation of Australia, which, I am delighted to see, now endorses the desirability of having red meats in a balanced diet.

I wish now to make a few comments on Ausmeat, which is the official national organisation for quality standards of meat and the accurate description of meat. The aim of Ausmeat is to ensure that when someone buys meat of a certain description, he can be confident he will get what he pays for. That is particularly important for our reputation in export sales. To do this, Ausmeat is rapidly moving towards establishing a standard carcass for the beef and sheepmeat industries and, more recently, for the pig industry. I think that everybody would support that move towards standardisation.

However, the legislation has some disquieting aspects regarding the provision which formalises the ability of the AMLC to work with the Australian Pork Corporation in the development of marketing schemes for the pork industry. According to page 36 of the AMLC's annual report, the Attorney-General's Department has indicated that the inclusion of the pig industry's activities in computer aided live-stock marketing and Ausmeat are in breach of the AMLC Act. This legislation overcomes that. However, as the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) said, a large number of pork producers from the central west area of New South Wales have complained, particularly to me, that they were not consulted regarding these changes. They are particularly upset about the changes to the carcass trim definition being suddenly implemented without them knowing about them. The pigmeat industry has had its act together, as far as a standard carcass goes, for some years now. But now that standard is to be changed and parts such as the foretrotters, kidneys, kidney fat and flare fat will be trimmed from the carcass at Ausmeat-accredited abattoirs. That includes all export abattoirs, and will eventually embrace most, if not all, other abattoirs. This extra trim, which used to go with the carcass to the butchers, is now thrown down the chute at the abattoirs to be processed into meat meal, which sells at a much lower price. The complaint I have been getting from the central west producers is that they will only get the same price per kilogram for the remainder of the carcass, even though it is upgraded, as they get for the less heavily trimmed carcass.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that being passed on?

—It is not being passed on, as yet, in the central west, which may surprise some people. That is unfortunate. As 2 kilograms or more of trim is being removed from each carcass, the producers in the central west have suddenly found that they are getting $2 to $3 less for their carcasses. The butchers are not paying more for the upgraded carcasses. That is something that producers cannot afford in these tight financial times.

SPEECH.PARA: As something like 98 per cent of pigs killed in Australia end up on domestic tables, perhaps a compromise can be arranged, through discussions between Ausmeat and the producers, so a satisfactory arrangement can be reached, without jeopardising the Ausmeat concept, with which I think everybody is in agreement. I hope that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) will take time to listen to these complaints and facilitate this, as many producers, such as John Wardle, John Neels, Tony Cheshire, and Des Reynolds, have contacted me with their very genuine concerns.

I now say a few words about CALM-the computer aided live-stock marketing concept-whose aims are: an accurate description; direct sales; better transport co-ordination; less weight loss of beasts sold; less bruising, and less handling stress. CALM kicked off with sales in November of last year. I note that the Minister launched the national commercial operations on 1 July this year. The sales through CALM have grown steadily from a modest but promising beginning. Many are still waiting on the sidelines to see how it goes. There have been some teething problems in setting it up, getting the computers in place and programming them, et cetera; but these troubles are gradually being ironed out. As at 30 June this year some 402 cattle assessors and 307 sheep and lamb assessors had been accredited, so there is no doubt that the CALM system will continue to grow.

I would like to make some comments about the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation. I have in my hand its annual report, in which it states that it spent $16 1/2m last year. The Research and Development Corporation has been concentrating on areas of livestock production, processing, storage, transport and marketing. It is starting to range fairly widely with its research projects. Looking through some of the titles I see that it is all good research but, as I have said, it is ranging widely and I am starting to wonder whether some of it would be best done by other organisations. The Corporation is doing projects on sowing salt bush in salty sites, investigating plant poisonings and developing vaccines in trying to improve pastures around the country. These are all worthwhile projects but I wonder whether they are best done by this organisation. I hope it does not grow into a bureaucracy.

I would like to make some comments, as did the shadow Minister for primary industry, on the equal employment opportunity clauses in this Bill. This is the first step towards quotas. An annual report will have to be brought down each year, which will be an extra cost on the industry. While none of us in this chamber is against equal opportunity, nevertheless I believe that the clauses are so worded that the legislation will discriminate positively towards women and other groups. This will only bring tokenism into employment opportunities for women and therefore in the long run it will be degrading for women. I shall say more about that matter when we get to the committee stage of the debate.

There are clauses in the legislation regarding the annual general meeting that the AMLC holds every year at which registered producers and registered processors may vote. I am sorry to see that it appears there is waning interest amongst the producers. Not long ago 36,000 were registered. I believe the number is now down to about 20,000. I would encourage as many producers as possible to register because some matters which are vital to the hip pocket will be raised at the annual general meeting not only this year, which I believe will be held on 3 December in Albury, but also in future years.

The voting procedures have been a shemozzle until now and, while there are improvements in the Bill, there is still lots of ground for improvement. For example, the amendments specify that a motion to impose a levy will be defeated if, and only if, 75 per cent of those people present, either in proxy or in person and in each register, oppose the motion. The Cattle Council of Australia quite rightly has pointed out that the onus is on defeating, rather than supporting, the motion-which is, of course, a flip-flop on what would normally apply under the Companies Act. A minority of shareholders on one or other of the registers could ensure that a motion was carried even though a clear majority was against it. One need only refer to the 1985 annual general meeting, when 10,300 producers were registered to vote-they either attended the meeting or gave their proxy vote-but only 29 processors were present. Of course, if all 10,300 producers had voted against the increase and 21 out of 29 of the processors had also voted against the motion, it could still have been carried, even though the overwhelming majority would have been against it. I would like the Minister to clarify whether a simple majority of the processors and the producers is needed, or whether a 75 per cent majority of those on both registers is needed. I think that that needs to be explained. There seems to be some confusion about it.

Lastly, I comment about the Selection Committee, which appoints people to the Research and Development Corporation and the AMLC. It does not now have to bring down an annual report. Last year's annual report, which shows that $63,000 was spent to re-elect four people to both of those corporations, was only two and a half pages in length, and was printed on very simple paper, and would have cost only a few cents per copy. It is a disturbing trend and I cannot see the logic of it. I cannot see how costs would be cut in that area. Other honourable members have spoken about the levy increases and residue increases, so I will not speak about those matters on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over recent years the primary industry commodity sector has undergone very major changes. Farmers have recognised the need to improve their efficiency. In more recent times the same can be said of the processors and sellers. The Government has played its part, in partnership with the farm sector. Its record, I believe, is second to none. Of course, it is part of the Government's overall program for Australian industries generally to ensure that they are in the best possible position in this latter part of the twentieth century to take advantage of the markets that are emerging and the ones which we already have.

SPEECH.PARA: The statutory bodies have been restructured in all commodity areas. This action has given them the opportunity to serve the industry more effectively. This has clearly been of benefit not only to all sections of the industry but to the Australian economy as a whole. Now, according to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC), its long term goal is to create an optimum marketing environment for producers, processors and sellers of Australian meat and livestock, and thereby to enhance their profitability.

In a climate that can be fairly described as difficult, the AMLC, in carrying out its charter, has, I think it must be accepted, achieved considerable success. It would be remiss of us not to mention the splendid efforts on behalf of the industry of its Chairman, Mr Dick Austen, and the Managing Director, Mr Peter Frawley. During the recent problems caused by the detection of unacceptable levels of pesticide residues in Australian beef exports, to the United States in particular, these men exercised a disciplined leadership role in the industry. Working in co-operation with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, they were able to take the heat out of the debate. Negotiations were worked through to achieve the most satisfactory result which could be expected in the difficult circumstances.

There has been a very wide-ranging debate on the package of legislation that is before us. I would like to address most of my remarks to the amendments which form the major thrust of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. The purpose of the Bill is to amend the four Acts associated with the meat and livestock industry to incorporate a number of minor changes to the consultative process and the procedure at general meetings, and also to implement an equal employment opportunity plan for the AMLC. It also formalises the arrangements of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation to work with the Australian Pork Corporation in the development of marketing schemes for meat and livestock. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation, which was established by legislation in 1977, was amended in 1984 to give the organisation the primary function of facilitating the marketing of meat in Australia and overseas. Therefore, it is principally concerned with commercial matters. Having a strong element of accountability to the industry, it receives most of its funds from the industry.

Two recent and very innovative projects initiated by the AMLC that are having, or no doubt will have, a major impact on the industry are, as has been suggested before in the debate, the computer aided livestock marketing system (CALM) and Ausmeat, which is a marketing tool designed to allow a buying system to operate across the industry. The aim is to make the industry more sensitive to consumer and processor needs. A very competitive market, direct delivery and reduced handling stress on livestock are the results. The benefits are obvious both to producers and to buyers.

It is particularly pleasing to note the progress of the CALM system, bearing in mind that it was only in November 1986 that developmental sales commenced. During this introductory period-over 500 producers, 180 agents and 80 buyers used CALM. The experience gained in the use of the system and the interest generated has enabled the commercial stage of the operation to be established on a solid base. To 30 June 1987 the sales figures through the use of CALM were $8.75m for cattle, $2.88m for sheep and $0.15m for pigs. I do not think that there is any doubt that this system soon will become a major influence in keeping the industry competitive.

The second major initiative is the national produce distribution system, which is part of the major role of the Ausmeat national committee. As with a number of initiatives the Government has taken, the AMLC's Ausmeat is composed of a very comprehensive representation of industry interests. It has two major responsibilities. Firstly, in recognition of the Government's determination to encourage Australians to be conscious of quality standards, Ausmeat is charged with the responsibility of ensuring that all meatworks throughout Australia operate according to rigidly defined standards of quality. Secondly, Ausmeat has responsibility for establishing a uniform, descriptive language for meat and ensuring that all accredited meat establishments work accurately within a standard measurement and according to correct description. Once again, there is now strong evidence that, as a result of Ausmeat's activities, the marketing system for the meat and livestock industry is increasing in efficiency and effectiveness.

While the Australian Meat and Live-stock Act 1977 is being amended by the House, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 also affects the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council Act 1984 and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984. The four bodies covered by the Bill were established as part of the revised industry structure set in place by the Government. Given the level of co-operation shown by the industry generally, there seems little doubt that these changes were long overdue.

I just want to say a few words about the role of the former Minister for Primary Industry, now the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Since the Labor Government took office in 1983, the Minister has been responsible for more constructive measures to enhance and support the role of primary industry than has any other Minister for primary industry. I have no hesitation in saying that. In any discussion with farmers in my electorate of Ballarat the comment is heard over and over again that this Minister is an outstanding Minister and a good bloke. He is generally recognised as being well informed, diligent and sympathetic to the farming community, but determined to act on behalf of the industry for the good of Australia. These comments are often expressed even by farmers whose political viewpoints are diametrically opposed to those of the Australian Labor Party. They know value when they see it. Furthermore, I doubt that any other Minister in this portfolio has been more prepared than this Minister to meet farmers and farmer groups on their territory.

That the bodies I mentioned earlier must be efficient, streamlined and in keeping with a strong market orientation goes without saying when their contribution to the economy is taken into account. For instance, it is anticipated by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics that in 1987 beef and veal exports will gross $1,185m. This represents 580 kilotonnes and, by any standards, the cattle industry is a major contributor to the economy. It is imperative that it functions efficiently in the market-place. When sheep meat, pork and goat meat are added, the picture is even more dramatic. Therefore, in the context of the international market-place, one can see how significant these developments that have been put in place by this Government really are.

In many respects this package of legislation is mainly housekeeping in nature. I wish to make a few comments on the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill. It was first introduced before the recent election, but since then the problem with pesticide residue has forced the industry to take stock of itself. I guess that it was a great shock to most Australians, many outside the industry, to learn of the very sad situation that had arisen. Possibly, in some respects, it might have been a salutary experience for all Australians although one which we would rather not have gone through. The major purpose of this Bill is to bring changes to the per capita slaughter levy. The original legislation increased the slaughter levy from $6 to $10. At the time it was felt that this would be enough, but the new residue testing regime and marketing program that has been required means that it will increase from $6 to $18.

I suggest that the increased levy has the support of the major producer bodies, such as the Cattle Council of Australia and the Sheepmeat Council of Australia. The levy rates on the slaughter of sheep will increase from 60c to $1.50, and for lambs 67c to $1.50. For the slaughter of calves the levy rises from $2.10 to $6.30, and for bobby calves from 60c to $1.80. Levy rates of slaughter for buffaloes and goats will also be increased. While the Bill increases the maximum rates, it does not necessarily mean that there will be an immediate increase in the operative levy. The current rates must remain until the decision to increase the levies is approved at the annual meeting of the AMLC to be held on 3 December this year. If the meeting agrees to approve these increases, that decision is required to be submitted to the Minister. It will then be put to the Parliament by way of regulation. Obviously, it will be some time before the levies take effect. It probably will not be until the first quarter of next year. I believe that the industry should be commended by the Parliament for the very responsible way in which it has accepted the need to move very quickly to tackle the problem caused by the pesticide residues.

I would like to make a few comments on the pesticide residue problem. In the aftermath of the discovery of the pesticides in May, much has been done to screen products for both the domestic and export markets. It must be said that the controls put in place since May are beginning to pay dividends. The testing programs now show where the contaminated meat is coming from and a number of properties already have been quarantined. All sectors of the industry have demonstrated their willingness to monitor the issue.

One thing which people outside the industry do not recognise is the high cost of the testing program. The AMLC has sent out a notice of motion suggesting that $5 per head of the increase be set aside for residue testing. Again, this demonstrates the bona fides of the industry. I have an export abattoir in my electorate-Glenburn Estates run by the Siegel family. I think it is only appropriate to commend all those involved with the firm, employers and employees, unions and management, for their willingness to tackle the problem head on. Because so many of the stock received by the abattoir come in small lots, or from small small lots, the cost of testing to this firm is considerably higher than it would be for a plant in a major beef producing area of the country. Apart from the fact that the company wants to stay in business and is therefore prepared to meet the cost, the proprietors also have a genuine concern as responsible Australians for the state of the industry and, in particular, our standing as an exporting nation in world markets.

In spite of the residue problems, I do not believe there are reasons for being pessimistic about the industry. The United States of America and Australia have negotiated a voluntary restraint arrangement for the year, similar to arrangements we have already entered into. We have lived with these conditions before and there is absolutely no reason to doubt that we can live with them again. All sectors of the industry and the Government recognise the importance of maintaining US market access. The Japanese market appears also to be sound, as Japan has indicated it is prepared to take more than previously negotiated. The European Economic Community has indicated that it will not be shipping subsidised meat to the Japanese markets. Our responsibility as good marketeers is to provide quality and appropriate cuts at the right price. If we are successful, we will be able to compete against the US. Again the Bills are not controversial; they are necessary to help the industry and I commend them to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to speak on agricultural Bills, particularly of this nature. Of course we are reminded that the calling of the premature election resulted in this legislation not being debated early in the year, which probably would have been of greater benefit to the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It is appropriate to remark that the results of the arrangements put in place by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) a couple of years ago have shown some good results and, unfortunately, some bad results. The fact that there have been some bad results has led to the Minister coming to the Parliament to effect these changes. I compliment him on having the courage to come here and admit he was wrong. It does not give us in the National Party of Australia any great personal pleasure to say that we told him a couple of years ago that his proposals for annual meetings were just based on academic theory and would not work out in practice. We told the Minister, and we have been proved right. At the time he brought in these proposals there were 170,000 cattle units in Australia, and 36,000 people sought accreditation. At present, we have only 10,300 producers. We told him at that time that he could not transpose theory from academics into a practical situation as far as rural industry was concerned. Had he taken the trouble to look at the voting results of primary industry statutory authorities he would have been only too fully aware of the fact that farmers will not vote in elections like those he proposed, and they will not attend meetings.

The annual report of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation summarises its annual meeting in Perth on 2 December last year. It is a cause for great concern that only approximately 350 producers attended that meeting out of 170,000 cattle units in Australia and 10,300 registered producers. We talk about co-operation and consensus-and I do not oppose the implementation of increased funds for promotion; I am happy to support it-but I have great difficulty in understanding how we can have legislation based on consensus and yet we had at a meeting in Perth in December last year a motion opposing significant increases in promotion levies being passed by 12,611 votes to 4,708. The only other comparable figure that I know of is the majority I get in my own electorate. It would be wrong of me to put a view different from what that very high vote indicates I should put and different from the vote of opposition to significant increases in promotion levies given at a public meeting set up to get a consensus point of view. I make the point that at that meeting, following a report by Dick Austen, the proposal for increased funds for promotion was defeated. The meeting endorsed a proposal which increased funding for promotion when the Corporation, after consultation with the industry, put forward and justified its proposals.

This brings me to the core of this legislation. Should we be wasting producers' funds in having an annual meeting which producers will not attend and which passes resolutions of which the Minister takes no notice? I find difficulty in understanding the sense of that. If I were a less kind and less reasonable person, I would say that the meetings are sheer nonsense. The facts speak for themselves. I believe that the hard-earned producer's dollar would be better spent in having a type of regional conference or seminar which would not be as costly for people to attend, and at which decisions could be made after an educational program had been set in place. One would hope that decisions having been made on a reasonable basis, at meetings attended by more than 350 people out of a total membership of 10,300, those decisions would be taken note of. Surely that is a reasonable and logical argument to advance. I do not want to be unkind in saying that annual meetings are a nonsense, but I want the facts to speak for themselves.

It is appropriate to recall the remarks of the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) who said that the meat industry was doing pretty well at present. I smiled wryly when I heard Labor members recounting the significant export value and domestic value of our industry. They seemed to get an attack of the jitters. They did not mention that exports of live sheep for slaughter were up by 14 per cent to 7.7 million head. I wonder why they get nervous when they talk of the export of live sheep. That figure has increased by 14 per cent, and in meeting tough competition in national market-places one would produce the article that people want. I say on behalf of the National Party that we want to ensure that the industry gets the maximum return for the minimum cost. Obviously, the way to do that is to increase the number of live sheep and live cattle that are exported. Alternatively, one must do something to increase productivity in the processing works.

I do not want to do away with jobs, and I am fully aware of the fears and frustrations of the wives and families of meatworkers who are worried about losses of jobs in the processing industry. Equally, I am aware of the fears and frustrations of the wives of cattle and sheep producers who are faced with declining returns, because of increased costs and because they cannot export to the best markets. I think I can be excused for smiling wryly when I find Labor members talking about the export of processed meat products but not giving equal emphasis to what I believe to be the significant trade in live cattle and live sheep. I would like to see that section of the industry increased.

I get concerned when I see ever-increasing costs. When one totals the increased costs contained in all these Bills, one finds that the processing and marketing cost of a steer being processed for export, which brings $500 per head, is $40.55 per head. That does not include yard fees. It does not include transport costs. Of course, it does not include the costs of getting the beast up to the processing weight. It is an enormous cost. We have to be aware of costs, particularly the costs incurred in developing what we might term the upper section of the market, because that is where the competition really is. That is the competition we have to meet if we want to get into those high-priced restaurant markets in the rapidly growing, affluent markets of the Middle East and South East Asia. That places an extra burden on what we might term the feedlotters because they have to purchase what we in the trade call forward stores. Therefore, we have to contain the costs.

Of course, promotion is very important. It is necessary to realise that overseas markets will look for a product that is good, appears good and is marketed and packaged in an attractive way. I again want to be honest and acknowledge the significant achievements of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) in the international market-places. Perhaps they could have achieved more, but at least they have had the courage to put before the leaders of the United States of America, the European Economic Community and Japan our belief in fair competition. I happen to be of the opinion that some of the tenders for the better cuts of meat for the Japanese market are written in such a way that the American market automatically supplies the product. One can understand the leverage that the United States uses on Japan, given the favourable terms of trade that Japan has with America.

I compliment the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) on his logical and obviously knowledgable contribution about red meat. Of course, he was supported by the honourable member for Wannon. One of the very good things that research and promotion has done is in the nutritional and educational areas. It is interesting to note that red meat has been endorsed by the National Heart Foundation, which has included six cuts of red meat in the Heart Food Festival. As the last two speakers from the Opposition have said, those cuts of meat were endorsed on the basis of their low fat and low cholesterol levels. I was particularly taken by the slogan that the meat industry adopted for that particular exercise. I would like to repeat it. Some Government members, as they move around the cities, may repeat it and it might become contagious. The slogan is `Eat these to your heart's content'. The short cuts advertising program was also excellent.

The honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), who spoke previously, mentioned the many splendid achievements of the computer assisted livestock marketing system (CALM). I wonder why honourable members opposite always seem to be selective in their quoting. I would have thought that a very essential part of the CALM program was the assessors, both for the cattle section and for the sheep-lamb section. The honourable member talked about the producers, the agents and the buyers, but the assessors also have a very important job. They have to know their job and also have to establish credibility. I think that, in addition to the statistics cited by the previous speaker, the 402 cattle assessors and 307 sheep assessors should also have their contributions recorded.

As far as research and development is concerned, I think that one of the great things that has happened in the cattle industry has been in the area of what we might term the embryo transplant program. Of course, that was developed by a great veterinary surgeon from Warwick in the electorate of the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall). I refer to Sid Miller, who worked in close association with the Inverary poll hereford stud operated initially by J. H. Anderson and now by his son Don Anderson. That has had great economic advantages for the cattle industry where, in effect, in the final analysis, the `poorer relation' of the sexes in the breeding program becomes of equal value to the male. The female is able to produce almost as many cattle in a year as the male animal. That has been of great advantage to the industry. We can adapt better feed to beef conversion ratios and we also have the ability to improve the quality of stock by access to higher quality breeding stocks.

Obviously, I want to talk about chemical residue. It needs to be clearly understood in a debate such as this that the problem of chemical residue is basically not one caused by the industry that has been afflicted with the problem. It is what we might term a global problem, caused by chemicals used basically in the sugar, horticultural and grain industries. I am not making any charges against these industries as they used these chemicals in good faith. These chemicals were used on the advice of well known scientists and were approved by various State Departments of Agriculture and Primary Industry. But the problem is there and I now have some difficulty in accepting a proposition that a section of an industry that is affected, through no fault of its own, is called upon to bear the full burden of the cost. It seems to me that it would be a more reasonable arrangement if the Commonwealth Government, consistent with its approach of paying for 50 per cent of export inspection services, also contribute in a more meaningful and significant way to the costs incurred in chemical residue testing in State and Commonwealth laboratories. I offer that as a constructive comment in justice and in logic.

I am not really sure what is happening under the present voluntary arrangements. The most recent information that I have is that 70,000 tests have been carried out at a basic cost of $50 per test, making an overall sum of $3.5m. Residue Testing Pty Ltd, the company involved, has only about half that amount in its coffers. Where will the extra money come from to pay the accounts sent out for tests done by various State and Commonwealth laboratories in Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia? I understand that the arrangements are slightly different in Western Australia and Tasmania. I ask the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to give serious consideration to that matter because in the final analysis a government has some responsibility when an industry is unfortunately-through no fault of its own-afflicted with very heavy costs. That is particularly necessary when one considers that perhaps there is a valid claim by the industry that the Federal Government did not react quickly enough in recalling chemicals that were already distributed through other industries, and did not advance educational programs quickly enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —States, Tom.

—I am just offering what I believe is a constructive suggestion in a very difficult situation for many people, Minister. The Government is increasing the costs of promotion, research and disease eradication to a total of $15.55 per head under the present arrangements. That is a significant drain on ordinary cattle producers. I believe that it is consistent with the established arrangement of the Commonwealth meeting 50 per cent of export inspection costs that the Government consider helping an industry which is a victim of unfortunate circum- stances outside its control.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the hour, I shall be brief. I understand we shall be having a debate in the Committee stage, when I shall be speaking about other matters. I rise to support the Opposition in its attitude as outlined by the shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), in relation to this group of Bills, and to make a couple of other points. In March 1985 we debated in this House certain Bills relating to the meat and livestock industries and the annual general meetings of industry members. Those subjects have been canvassed at length in the debate today and I want to refer briefly to the circumstances of the Acts that brought about the amendment that we now consider.

SPEECH.PARA: In March 1985 the Hawke Government had not been long re-elected and the then Minister for Primary Industry stood fairly high with primary producers, and particularly with members of parliament from his own side of the House who represented rural industries. I remember members on that side being extremely intolerant of any criticism of the proposals being put forward by the Minister in this place. Criticisms of the meat and livestock Bills that were being debated at that time were swept aside. The central issue that we debate in these Bills is that those criticisms have been vindicated. We pointed out the shortcomings of the legislation at that time, and we were scornfully rejected by the Government, but they are being revealed more and more. Finally, producers are realising that they were sold a pup back in 1985.

Some positive benefits came from the arrangements made at that time, and they were acknowledged then by the Opposition in the debate, but there was an element of delusion in the ready acceptance by certain members of the industry of the proposals put forward. Put simply, it was that many producers who were consulted prior to that legislation simply did not understand the mechanisms of government and of statutory corporations. Dissatisfaction with those mechanisms now surfaces, and producers are increasingly critical of the accountability of organisations such as the Australian Meat Livestock Corporation (AMLC) and those who fund the organisation. I would like to refer to a couple of things that I said in the debate on that occasion. I said:
There are some positives in this Bill but there are also some negatives. I believe that the negatives could be substantial if the meat producers are not vigilant in their cause.
My concern was that it was all too easy to dazzle producers with the science of corporations and annual reports, without them realising what the substance was. I went on to say:
I think that the meat and livestock producers, who expect quite a bit from the changes that are contained in this package of Bills, may be expecting a little too much.
Events have vindicated my view, as I outlined them then, and as they have been demonstrated in recent debate. I went on:

. . . the industry had been sold a bit of a pup . . . When I hear a member of the Government saying to producers `Look, you are going to get the annual report, then you are going to have an annual general meeting, and this annual report is going to be the basic document for that meeting; this is how we will be accountable to you', I think there really is something the producers are not being told, and I want to tell them. I want to tell them that it is highly likely that by the time that annual general meeting is held, with them arriving at it with the Corporation's latest annual report in their hands, that report is likely to be 12 months out of date.

The procedure for annual reports is as specified in the Audit Act, and there is reference to that in this Bill. But all that the Audit Act requires is that, as soon as possible after 30 June, the Corporation must present its annual report to the Minister who, within 15 sitting days of Parliament after receiving the report, must table it in Parliament. In the normal course of events, that is usually about eight months after the end of the financial year accounted for in the report . . .

This Bill provides approximately three months after the tabling of the Corporation's report in Parliament there will be an annual general meeting. It is very easy to see that we are really running into about a 12-month time frame following 30 June of the previous year. The report is going to be quite out of date in terms of its reporting of the activities of the Corporation. The meat and live-stock producers are going to attend this annual general meeting-I believe at a cost of about $200,000 out of the Corporation's budget, and they will also have paid for the report they have in their hands-it is not going to be a gift; its cost will also be paid out of the funds available to the Corporation. I say to the meat and livestock producers that they are not getting very much accountability.

That is the basic reason for the crankiness of producers at the moment. They have discovered that they have been sold a pup. Only those very close to the central decision-making process have a real say in the procedure. That is the reason that we have calls from producers for real decisions to be made at annual general meetings; not just an opportunity to say yes or no to AMLC decisions, but to participate genuinely. For a genuinely participatory scheme there must be ongoing consultation with the organisations that represent producers. I will say now, as I was not quite so crude in 1985, that in those terms the annual report is not worth a tinker's damn. The facts are that the annual report contained things that are well out of date. In terms of monitoring what a corporation is doing with the producers' money, it is really a farce to suggest that this would have ever been so. Those criticisms were made at the time.

I am pleased to see that we are making some limited progress on the subject. But two and a half years later it seems that our progress is at about the rate at which annual reports are issued-rather out of date and a little too little too late. I hope that the Government will seriously address the concerns of producers to make sure that they get true accountability for those measures for which they are paying, and I hope that the Government realises at last that those who are paying the bill, in the case of the Corporation, for research in the area, are quite dissatisfied and they are entitled to better results.

I will speak only briefly on the beef residue problem. It is, I understand, a very real problem for the Federal Government but it is a tragic problem for beef producers. Some very sad stories have been documented in the newspapers of people who have been really destroyed by the beef residue problem and who seem to have nowhere to turn. I note that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), by way of interjection on a previous speaker, referred to the responsibilities of State governments and I would like him to know that I do not totally disagree with him. However, this is not an issue for point scoring between Federal governments, State governments, or anyone else. It has the potential for creating a social disaster as well as an industry disaster, given that many towns in this country are dependent on the beef industry. I refer particularly to those towns in which the major employer is the local abattoir. Of course, there are two in my electorate but I will not pump the local electorate issue tonight because I know that many members on both sides of the House have that very real concern. Whatever the politics or the political complexions of the State or Federal governments in question, I only hope that their No. 1 priority is not their party political allegiance but their very real concern for the people whose welfare they are charged with caring for, and that that will be the prime issue in our meeting the challenge of the beef residue problem for our beef export industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments on the debate. First of all, I would like to thank all those honourable members who have spoken. I believe that the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), made a well-reasoned contribution to the debate, putting forward many concerns that are relevant to the industry at this time. In general, although the Government disagrees with the amendments he foreshadowed, we believe that there is a large degree of concurrence about the way the parties in this chamber see the beef industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to thank, in particular, my colleagues the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) and the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) for their contributions and just briefly touch on some points made by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright). He touched on the question of provisional freedom under the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign. That was discussed at the Australian Agricultural Council meeting and the special meeting dealing with the milk question in a more informal setting. Correspondence is under way between the State Ministers to see whether we can get a resolution of that problem. Similarly, with respect to the capital gains tax and the question of how that may apply to leases, I have made representatives to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), as have other parties.

I would like briefly to touch on some points made by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan). I do not want to go back into the history of all this but I actually went through that very long period of negotiation with the industry against a history in that industry of distrust between the producers and the processors that had reached such a point that the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) was rendered almost useless as an effective body. The discussions and negotiations I entered into with the Cattle Council of Australia, with Maurice Binstead; the Sheepmeat Council of Australia, with Mr James; and the Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council with Mr Bowtell, were long and I think all points of view got through. Of course, we had to reach a lot of compromises and there was a lot of discussion on the way. What we set up with the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation led to part of the model for the statutory marketing authority reforms, with all the work we put into this whole concept of accountability after a lot of discussion in the Parliament, particularly in the Senate.

The annual general meeting is one way of dealing with this accountability. The reporting back by people elected to these boards is always very difficult; the reporting back by industry leaders is always very difficult; the whole concept of consultation is very difficult. Of course, the board members themselves have an obligation to put forward what is happening to the industry on every possible occasion, and they do this. In the other mechanisms in place under the general statutory marketing authority reform, and the way in which the Wool Council of Australia, the grain industry and the dairy industry operate, there are all sorts of variations of models, with their pluses and minuses. Quite frankly, we will never solve the problem. Anyone who goes to the annual general meeting of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation believes it is a very successful way of getting discussion of industry issues on the day. I should tell the honourable member for Moncrieff that the annual report of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation for the year ended 30 June 1987 has already been tabled in this Parliament and it will be discussed at the annual meeting to be held on 3 December. That is not too bad compared with what happens in other industries. It is evidence, of course, that this system is working.

I shall focus on this annual general meeting because it has been an issue of contention for a long time with the industry. I state that the existing provisions were included at the request of the industry. In the first place in all those negotiations the big fear was that a radical group would take over the annual general meeting. We found that maybe the provisions were a bit too tough and that is why we have moved this far now. Under the current provisions relating to the annual general meetings of the AMLC and the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation, a motion of no confidence or a motion to reject an increase in levy rates requires a majority of 75 per cent of all registered `shareholders' on each of the producer and processor registers. The proposed change to allow 75 per cent of those shareholders voting in person or by proxy to achieve the same result will give to such motions a reasonable chance of success.

As I said, the original provision was included at the request of the industry. The proposed changes move some way to free up the situation, as sought by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray. He also made some comments about Ausmeat, and the carcass definition for pigs. The concern expressed was regarding the standard Ausmeat definition for pigs. I am aware that some sectors of the pig industry in the central west initially believed that they had been disadvantaged by the Ausmeat definition and, as a consequence, the Australian Pork Corporation negotiated with the Ausmeat committee of the AMLC for an additional category of carcass which includes many of the components required to be removed under the standard carcass definition. Both the Australian Pork Producers Federation and the Australian Pork Corporation are supportive of the pig industry's participation in Ausmeat. I simply say to the honourable gentleman that if further difficulties do arise they can be sorted out promptly between the appropriate bodies in the above manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ausmeat has assured me that it is taking that matter further.

—That is interesting. On the whole question of chemical residues, as everyone has conceded, the Government acted quickly in conjunction with the States and the industry to implement an integrated action plan to prevent recurrence of the recent meat residue problems and it sent a delegation of senior officials to the United States, Canada and Japan to address those countries' concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question of assistance, the Government has already provided $10m to the integrated action plan, and I have indicated to industry leaders that I am prepared to look at any proposal on its merits, but that any further government assistance would have to be well targeted at a substantial problem area. The fifty-fifty cost sharing arrangements proposed in the Opposition amendment would disburse assistance in a broad, untargeted manner, irrespective of need. Given the Government's funding commitment, I will not go through all the details now but it is only proper that industry funds its share. As we already know, in these Bills there is a capacity for the industry to take a decision in this regard, at the annual general meeting, about how it wants this matter addressed. Again, we are trying to give the industry the chance to make more and more decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party's move to taxpayers funding 100 per cent of inspection costs just highlights the differences between the Liberal Party and the National Party. I just would not know where Senator Stone would swim in all of this business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Both the Liberal and National parties have exactly the same policy, that is 100 per cent payment for export production.
— Order! There is no point of order.

—Comments were also made in the debate, particularly by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who made his characteristically nasty approach to the debate. I would just like to address the question of costs and some of the allegations he made about the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service. Over the past three years the initiatives by the Inspection Service have enabled the number of inspectors to be reduced by some 230. This has resulted in substantial savings to the industry of well over $7m. Dual inspection in export works has been completely eliminated at a saving to industry of some $5m to $6m. The honourable member for O'Connor might be very proud of the system in Western Australia, but there were three systems there, plus one, and that was the nil system. Every report and every resolution by people on both sides of this House about a national inspection service, going back to 1956, including reports such as the report of the Kelly Committee of Inquiry to examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems, have always said that it is essential to have a national meat inspection service, and that that is by far the best way to approach this problem. While ever we export meat we need a Commonwealth stamp on the meat, because that is the requirement of the countries that buy our meat. The honourable member for O'Connor can indulge in all the fantasies he likes, but that is the fact of the situation. The meat export charge has been held at the 1984 level. The slaughter floor charge this year will be some 2 per cent below the level in 1984. The real level of the charges is some 25 to 30 per cent below that prevailing in 1984, when the split charges were introduced. Further studies are continuing in an effort further to reduce meat inspection costs, with emphasis on ancillary inspection in the export area. As we all know, the introduction of a fee for service charges next year will provide incentive for the industry to use the inspection resource more efficiently and further reduce costs to the industry. There is unequivocal evidence that the Commonwealth provides a cheaper service, contrary to the statements of the honourable member for O'Connor, even if the Commonwealth's recovery was at 100 per cent and not at 50 per cent. He raised Victoria's move towards a single meat inspection service, where the industry has requested the Victorian Farmers Federation to support the move to a single meat inspection service because of the cost savings to the industry. I know one firm whose savings will be in the order of $600,000. Just because there was a bit of vested interest in the opposition to the first move by the Victorian Government, there is no reason to penalise the industry in the way that the honourable member for O'Connor would seek to do.

SPEECH.PARA: He also raised the report of the United States (US) Office of the Inspector-general (OIG) on the Food, Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS). I would like to stress that Australia has received no official request from the FSIS for changes to the Australian system. The OIG's report was an audit of the FSIS inspection system as it applied to overseas countries and it commented on FSIS systems, not Australian systems. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy inspections systems are based on FSIS requirements, and they are equivalent to the US meat inspection service. I would also add that the FSIS itself also disagreed with a number of the OIG criticisms before the Congressional hearings in the US. Finally, where any of the points raised in the OIG's report pointed to improvements to be made to the Australian system these have been implemented on Australia's initiative. We have not been requested by the US to implement those changes.

I do not have time in this debate to go through this whole question of chemical residues. But, of course, it was very relevant to raise the general concern. The honourable member for O'Connor is trading a little bit of dangerous information and he wants to use it to denigrate the Australian product. I could tell honourable members a lot about statistical requirements. If we really look into it we see that the requirements in the US for addressing the problem that we have had to address are exactly the same as we adopted. We could look at statistics until we were black and blue in the face. The honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) inadvertently had the wrong figures, but the most recent figure for the number of tests we have now conducted is 128,269. From all of that data we have found a violative level of 0.31 per cent.

I have already said that I will not go into details, but I will just tell honourable members that we rely on a national residue survey which has now been enhanced. There is a lot of confusion in the minds of the public about what is a maximum residue level. That level has very little, if anything, to do with health. If we want to look at the health aspects of that maximum residue level we have to calculate average daily intakes and do studies into toxicity in species that may be affected by that average daily intake. The maximum residue level is an assessed level of insecticides that one could expect to be in the general environment as a result of the use of those chemicals. It has nothing to do with health.
Australian Meat and Live-stock Bill
Australian Meat and Live-stock Bill

There have been criticisms that we have not put enough pressure on to the States with respect to registration and deregistration. We in the Australian Agricultural Council have been putting on the pressure-and the minutes will record that-for well over a decade. Even at the last Agricultural Council meeting, when I put it to the State Ministers that our Directors-General and my Deputy Secretary should meet to see what we could do about uniform registration and deregistration of chemicals, of course, the State bureaucracies wound up their Ministers when they finally sat down and said, `We will not make much progress in this area'. But I hope we will eventually. It is absolutely essential that, when we get a system of agricultural and veterinarian chemical registration, we have a uniform central point of notification and a central point of clearance with the States then going on to register and deregister. They should fully live up to what would be a sensible system throughout Australia and not go their own merry way with or without resources. There is a heck of a lot I could say about this whole question of the chemical residue problem we have had, but the attack on the Australian Agricultural Health and Quarantine Service by the honourable member for O'Connor was quite intolerable. I will write to him, as I will to other honourable members, attacking any point that was made in respect of which the comments were just plain wrong, vexatious or in need of some clarification.

The only other question I want to comment on concerns the equal employment opportunity provisions-and we went through all this the last time we put in amendments relating to the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Act. I would just like to advise honourable members, with respect to the other statutory authorities where such provisions have already been incorporated, that the sky did not fall in. There is no sense in some people trying to disguise rather primitive or old-fashioned attitudes about this matter. I simply say that both the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act and the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Act clearly state that nothing in the Acts shall be taken to require any action incompatible with the principle that employment matters should be dealt with on the basis of merit, as does the legislation relating to statutory marketing authorities.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Lloyd's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
