DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Higher Education Administration Charge-Family Heritage Australia Pty Ltd-Right to Life Association-Film and Video Classifications-Postal Services-National Wage Case Hearings-Political Demonstrations

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Kerin) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the opening of this Thirty-fifth Parliament, the Governor-General, speaking on behalf of the Government, referred to an `agenda of reforms' which the Government claims are designed to build `a fairer and more compassionate Australian society'. Actions speak louder than words and, unfortunately, the manner in which the Government is implementing some of these so-called reforms bears no relation to its stated objective, as one of my constituents, Mrs Rosamond Ewan, has recently discovered.

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs Ewan is studying part time for her Batchelor of Arts degree at the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education. She is doing this course by correspondence, and is majoring in politics and psychology. She has successfully completed 15 of the required 24 units. In her endeavours to complete her degree, Mrs Ewan has faced many challenges, including a continuing battle with severe arthritis, and having to defer her studies owing to injuries resulting from two unfortunate accidents-neither of which was due to negligence on her part. But she has persevered and has conquered these not inconsiderable difficulties. Now this so-called fair and compassionate Government has confronted her with a further obstacle which even her considerable determination and courage cannot overcome.

Mrs Ewan is over 65 years of age. She is a war widow, and her pension is her only income. From the $184 she receives each week, she must pay $80 per week rent for her flat. The remaining $104 must cover all her other living expenses, the cost of maintaining her car, and the costs associated with her studies, including books, accommodation on campus during weekend and vacation schools, and travelling expenses.

Mrs Ewan has been refused exemption from the $250 per year higher education administration charge. Last month the Department of Employment, Education and Training informed her that exemptions from the charge were based on need, and that the age of students was not a consideration. The same letter also states that in deciding its priorities as to which needy students could be granted exemption, the Government was most concerned about people needing work skills. Obviously, some people over 65 would not meet this requirement. This written version of the Government's policy is, however, less brutal than the earlier verbal advice received by Mrs Ewan-and confirmed in a phone call from my office to a senior departmental officer-that mature age students would not be granted exemption from the tertiary fee because they are only benefiting themselves in furthering their education and there is no flow-on advantage to the rest of the community.

Mrs Ewan is involved in a wide range of activities which benefit the community. She is a justice of the peace, President of Lilydale Voice of the Elderly, and a member of the Lilydale Consultative Committee, a group providing a valuable liaison service between local citizens and their shire council, and involved in the work of local church and youth groups, children's services, senior citizens, family and personal support groups, and other community-oriented activities. She is a member and past President of the Lilydale Returned Services League Ladies Auxiliary, which Government members do not know anything about. She is a member of the Combined Pensioners Association and President of the Yarra Valley Branch of the Pensioner Party of Australia. She serves on the State Executive of that Party, and has stood as an endorsed candidate on its behalf in elections for the House of Representatives in 1984 and the Senate in 1987. She is also a member of the Walking Stick Club, which, through a program of regular outings, assists house-bound and disabled people, and lonely senior citizens, to remain involved in their community.

Mrs Ewan is a student member of the Australian Psychological Society, and on completion of her studies, intends to continue and extend her voluntary community work by assisting people who need, but cannot always afford, the services of a trained psychologist. But first she needs to obtain her degree. The remaining nine units will take her just over two years to complete, and she will have to pay out $750 in higher education administration charges-$750 she simply does not have. Honourable members should compare this $750 with the $250 it would cost a full time student to complete eight units.

Is this a commonsense and reasonable policy? Where is the compassion when a war widow is told her pensioner status is not regarded as sufficient or legitimate grounds to exempt her from a fee that other pension recipients do not have to pay, because, despite the clever use of words by the Department, she is too old? Is it fair that part time students, even if studying only one subject a year, pay the same fee as their full time counterparts? There is no excuse for charging the same fee for totally different services, and no justification for denying older people in necessitous circumstances the opportunity to further their education on the basis that once one is over 60, one is a useless non-contributor, unable to give anything back to the community.

I am appalled by the insensitive, insulting treatment Mrs Ewan has received. No doubt others in the same boat have suffered similarly. If this Government is as fair and as compassionate as it claims to be, I urge the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) to take immediate action to reconsider the plight of my constituent, and others similarly affected and waive the higher education administration charge in their cases.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today I mentioned the goings-on of a company by the name of Family Heritage Australia Pty Ltd. I thought that the House might be interested in knowing what was in a letter sent to me by that company. I understand that similar letters have been sent to a lot of people around Australia. What this company seems to do is simply send a letter to random people. It picks them out of the phone book or from the electoral role. This is the sort of letter sent-this one addressed to me:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Sciacca,
Did you know that a first edition book entitled ``THE BOOK OF THE SCIACCAS IN AUSTRALIA'' is about to be published and you are listed in it?
A great deal of time has been spent to search through several million public records to locate and compile an extensive registry of Sciacca families living in Australia.

I do not know where the company got the information because it cost me $50 just to get a birth certificate. I had to wait about two months because I had to get it from the little town in Italy where I was born. So it is an absolute con job; that is probably the best way of saying it. The letter continues:

In addition, you will find general and informative chapters about the origin and meaning of names, the history of our Australian forefathers, coats of arms and heraldry, as well as practical guidelines about how to research your own family genealogy.
Then it says:
You'll learn:-
How the Sciacca family got its name and what it means, as well as historical spelling variations. Where the Sciacca population resides in Australia with a household count . . .

About a coat of arms granted to an early Sciacca. Besides its original heraldic description, there is also an interpretation and illustration of this Sciacca coat of arms, which is hundreds of years old.
How to document the Sciacca family tree and research your ancestry.
``THE BOOK OF THE SCIACCAS IN AUSTRALIA'' is sure to be a valuable addition to your living room library.
This remarkable collection of information is available only in ``THE BOOK OF THE SCIACCAS IN AUSTRALIA' . . .

It is an absolute con job on the public of Australia. I understand that this matter has been mentioned on The Investigators. It has been the subject of inquiries by the Consumer Affairs Bureau in New South Wales and a number of other States, but these con people are still selling these things and finding people who are prepared to send the $39.90 for the book. I am particularly concerned to take these few minutes to urge the public, the consumers in Australia, not to be conned by this Family Heritage Australia Pty Ltd, not to feather the nest of this company that uses terribly deceptive ways to con people into buying its product. If we read through the fine print, we see that the company can probably get away with this because it says such things as, `If you don't like it send it back'. How many people would take the time and trouble to repack the parcel, address it, pay the postage, and do everything else involved in sending it back? This is the biggest con job that I have come across, even in my time as a solicitor. As a solicitor, I saw a lot of con jobs and the way people sometimes rip off other people. But this must take the cake. In conclusion, I say to the House that the main reason I am so concerned about this matter is that it lies very close to home, because both my cousin and my brother sent away and purchased the book.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the last election campaign, I received a letter from the Right to Life Association, New South Wales branch, which included a questionnaire designed to assess attitudes to pro-life issues. Although it is not my usual custom to answer questionnaires during election campaigns, I did so on this occasion. There was a misunderstanding by me as to the form the answers should take. Due to this misunderstanding, the direct opposite view was formed-quite understandably, I now see-by the New South Wales Right To Life Association people. I was very disturbed by this and gave an assurance not only to Mrs Kath Harrigan, the Honorary Executive Secretary, but to a great number of my constituents that I would be making a statement to the House to publicly state my views. The questions asked were as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: If elected will you support or initiate moves to prevent the use of taxpayers' funds through Health Legislation for reimbursement of the costs of deliberately induced abortion?
My answer to that is yes. The second question:

If elected will you vote for legislative moves to prohibit destructive experimentation on human embryos as sought in the majority report of the Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985?
My answer to that is yes. The third question:

If elected to Federal Parliament will you support or initiate measures to ensure that Human Rights Legislation provides for the protection of human life from its beginning at conception to its natural end?
My answer to that is yes. And the fourth question:

If elected will you support or initiate moves to stop Australian Aid Funds being directed to Government Agencies and International Family Planning organisations involved in the provision or promotion of induced abortion?

My answer to that is yes. I very much regret the concern this misunderstanding has caused a great number of my friends as well as certain other constituents in the electorate of Cook. I believe strongly in the answers I have now given to these questions and apologise for the inconvenience it caused many people. I make this statement of my views not because I was then a candidate, but because I hold the views as a matter of deep conscience and belief.

While on my feet, I would also like to raise the issue of film and video classifications. I guess, Madam Speaker, you could say this is my puritan speech tonight. Not owning a video machine, I am not in a position to know what really goes on in video shops, because I never have cause to enter them. But recently I want to a local cinema to see an M-rated film called The Untouchables. For a mature audience, this is a very entertaining film, although containing what I consider to be an unnecessary level of blood and gore. I was interested to note, however, that when I saw it, a group of young sub-teenagers were present. Judging from their reactions to particular scenes, it was obvious to me why this film had an M-rating. In some scenes, I thought it should have had an R-rating-judging by the scenes which excited the sub-teenagers present.

Upon inquiry I find there is still no way cinema management or their staff can enforce the guidelines associated with the PG and M classifications. Only with R-rated films-and in the case of the Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory, X-rated films-are cinema and video shop owners legally bound to observe the classification guidelines. The Film Censorship Board definition of PG is parental guidance recommended for persons under the age of 15. The definition for M, or mature, is suitable for persons 15 years and over. It seems ludicrous to me that if we go to the trouble of instigating a film classification system which determines that an M-rated film is suitable for those over the age of 15, we do not make this legally enforceable. It seems to me that if a film is deemed unsuitable for young people, they should not be given access to it. What is the point of classifying a film if no one takes, or is allowed to take, any notice?

Perhaps this is one area to which this Parliament should turn its attention. As we look around us today, it would appear that society is being engulfed by waves of violence. Certainly this is the case in the Sydney metropolitan area. I would hazard a guess in suggesting that the level of violence may just have something to do with the glorification of violence we are seeing on the small and large screen. The adverse effect of violence amongst the impressionable minds in our community is obviously not being given enough weight. Let us not be tolerant. Violence is obscene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the recent municipal council elections in the city of Ballarat, a Mrs Cathryn Laffey was successful in being elected as the representative of Parkwood. Apart from congratulating Cath I want to make a couple of comments. Cath is a financial counsellor with the Ballarat Children's Home. She has assisted many hundreds of people, particularly those with very low incomes, to manage their budgets.

SPEECH.PARA: A very interesting postcard came across her table recently. I comment on this because quite often people are very critical of public servants. People do not believe they are very diligent or set out to overcome any difficulties they might encounter. I want to give the lie to that. The postcard was written in Katmandu but was posted from Britain. Unfortunately, it does not give any address. It is a little difficult for a postcard to be delivered to the appropriate address when there is no address, not even a country. Obviously the British postal services thought there was someone in Britain who wanted to congratulate this Mrs Laffey for having been elected to something. It did not say what she was elected to, but that she was elected to something. The only clue they had, apart from Mrs Laffey's name, was the name of Ballarat on the card. The card said:
Congratulations on your election. If I have not already said, I expect great things for Ballarat.

The postal services in Britain thought she might have been elected as a member of parliament, so after Mrs Laffey's name they put `(M.P.)'. They looked up somewhere, in some register of towns, the town of Ballarat. There are two Ballarats-one in California, and the real Ballarat, in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would have been worried if she was the MP for Ballarat.

—She is a very fine woman. The postal services looked it up and decided to try Ballarat, Victoria, Australia. Sure enough, it came to Ballarat, Victoria, Australia, and Mrs Laffey received her congratulatory card. I want to congratulate the British postal services. I am sure all concerned are waiting out there to receive their copies of this address.

SPEECH.PARA: A similar sort of thing happened some time ago concerning Australia Post. I notice that the erstwhile former Minister for Communications, the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy), is here, and no doubt he will be somewhat warmed by the comments I am going to make. I travelled to Britain a couple of years ago and was slightly remiss in that I forgot to put the postal address on a card, although I did actually address the card to my staff. I also put Ballarat somewhere on it, and it arrived. It arrived at the Ballarat Post Office and, because my staff are so well known, it was delivered promptly. I must admit that I got a bit of ribbing from both my staff and the employees of Australia Post.

I just want to say that public servants are often criticised, and rarely are they praised. I believe that this indicates that we have people who are at least as conscientious and who serve the people, as public servants, just as well as those who work in private enterprise. I might say that that is a very good reason for maintaining organisations such as the postal services in government hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish tonight to take this opportunity afforded me to speak on the adjournment debate to present to the House a legitimate area of concern which has been brought to my attention by a constituent of mine, Brother Barry Lamb from Toowoomba. It is indeed enlightening to be presented with such a well thought out and comprehensively argued submission which is the product of a truly caring mind. Brother Lamb's concern focuses specifically on the limitations placed on unemployed people having a voice in national wage case hearings. Unemployed people within Australia now represent almost 8 per cent of our work force and on the basis of this figure can quite rightly be termed a majority group. It is therefore curious why a majority group would be denied opportunity for direct representation within this forum.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to the concern aired by Brother Lamb, the Government argued that the unemployed are neither ignored nor overlooked in national wage case proceedings. It further cited section 39 (2) of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 as evidence of this. Based on this Act, the Commission has an obligation to take into consideration the public interest, and subsequently it has regard to the impact of the state of the national economy on the level of employment and inflation. However, once one considers the position of the groups represented at the hearings, it is clear that what is needed is an avenue for the unemployed to speak on behalf of themselves with the same privileges extended to them as to other member groups.

First of all there are the trade unions which, while representing the interests of their members, necessarily present their arguments with the underlying view of gaining maximum wage increases and job security for those already gainfully employed. Trade unions do philosophically represent unemployment as a part of the working sector. However, as I have already stressed, their representations are geared more toward better working conditions for the workers. So too, the Government responses to represent the unemployed in this forum. However, let me suggest that the Government cannot hope solely to represent the views of the unemployed and must deal with the state of the economy as a whole.

The third and final group encompasses the employers. Yet, as is indeed predictable, it is in the best interests of this group for there to be a pool of unemployed maintained so as to keep wages and inflation down. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) stated that the Commission makes its decision based on the merits of the material put before it without regard as to the source of such material. I would suggest, however, that clearly, the quality of the material and arguments presented to the Commission will directly reflect the priorities of each group. In the light of this argument then, I seek to echo Brother Lamb's call for a group to be established which can be directly representative of the unemployed. The Government has acknowledged the chronic unemployment problem, yet it consistently denies this large group a voice in a public forum. It is about time that the Government decided whether it is merely resorting to using pious rhetoric which serves only to ease its conscience or whether, this time, it is prepared to take some constructive action to relieve this alarming problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently in my electorate there have been a number of demonstrations and protests at the Richmond Royal Australian Air Force base. The latest demonstrations were timed to coincide with protests at Pine Gap. They were intended to highlight and protest the through-flight of United States transport planes to Pine Gap. Those involved in the demonstrations demanded the Government terminate the agreement with the United States which provides for the joint intelligence facilities at Pine Gap. I want to raise issues in response to these protests.

SPEECH.PARA: On the whole, and to their credit, many involved in the protest have made use of their democratic rights of association, assembly and free speech within the boundaries of the law. For others the symbolism of their protests must be dramatised by transgression of the law, provocation of the police and defiance in the courts. Some of these people are naively over-zealous; others are consciously involved I believe in political subversion. A recent work on nuclear deterrence and morality had this warning for those who feel obliged to participate in protests over this issue:

Anyone considering engaging in civil disobedience must keep vividly in mind that the law of the land is the principal protection of the weak against the strong. Whatever threatens its fabric threatens the weak, the helpless and the innocent and gives reign to the strong, the ruthless and the immoral. Hence, lest other citizens be encouraged to violate the law for private and non-symbolic purposes civil disobedients must acknowledge the public interest, and the bonds of fairness which linked them to the law-abiding, by accepting arrest, fair trial and any lawful punishment that may be imposed.

I would add that protesters must also consider whether they would be happy to see their political strategy adopted by other groups. They must ask what the outcome would be for order and democracy if every other interest group in the country took to the streets to force, by numbers and non-co-operation, their views on the Government.
The philosophers I have quoted also raised another problem for protesters. They wrote:

Above all one must remember that the maxim `evil may be done that greater good may come of it' is what underpins most attempted justifications of the proposals against which one is protesting. The use of that maxim must be resolutely shunned. Some campaigns of so-called civil disobediences have been corrupted and corrupting because at least some of the campaigners did subscribe to that maxim.

I make reference to these comments above in a spirit of dialogue with those in my electorate who protested at the Richmond base. I do so as well because there are some in their number who do in fact subscribe to the maxim referred to above and who are willing to subvert the law.

The second issue I wish to raise is the question of Pine Gap. I have no problem with the Richmond connection with Pine Gap. I support the presence and functions of the joint facilities based there. Of all the joint US-Australian defence facilities, Pine Gap is the one I believe most easily justified in terms of prevention of nuclear war and the progress of disarmament. The Pine Gap facilities are crucial to the processes of disarmament. They cannot be located anywhere else. In terms of the satellites with which they communicate, disarmament negotiations would simply not proceed without these facilities. During any crisis these facilities would provide the intelligence necessary to prevent misadventure. They provide a source of intelligence to the President to allow him to judge the advice of the military in any such crisis. No other single diplomatic action by Australia could destabilise super-power relations and create United States paranoia as would the closure of the Pine Gap facilities. There would not be a more powerful catalyst for regional instability and adventurism. The presence and retention of the facilities contribute to our efforts to prevent nuclear war. Their removal would more than likely be a cause of nuclear war.
